TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I will be leaving Australia later this day to attend a meeting of the International Energy Agency in France. Australia has been invited to chair the meeting. In that connection I will also be visiting the United Kingdom, India and Indonesia to discuss matters of mutual interest, particularly those concerning energy. In my absence the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) will act as Minister for National Development and Energy until my return on 26 June. The Attorney-General, Senator Durack, will answer those questions which normally would be directed to me in the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 131 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth our complete opposition to any stage of the Nuclear Industry. We wish to inform you of our support for Union bans aimed against the Uranium Industry. We look towards a society that respects life, opposes violence, and recognises our total dependence on our global ecosystem.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Parliament take action to halt the mining, milling and export of Australian uranium and put people before profit.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KEEFFE

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 77 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
1. Note that legislation establishing plant breeders' rights in other countries has had serious adverse effects, namely:

(a) Virtual monopoly control of seed production has passed into the hands of a few large international corporations seeking to profit from the exclusive rights over plant genetic materials created by such legislation.

(b) The varieties of seeds available have been restricted mainly to hybrids which will not reproduce truly and will not grow without the aid of artificial fertilisers and pesticides, thus maximising corporate profits without regard for the interests of growers and consumers.
(c) The genetic diversity of crops has been eroded, rendering them vulnerable to disease and other environmental threats.

2. Recognise that maintenance of the genetic diversity of plant varieties is crucial to the continued well-being of the Australian nation, and take all necessary steps to preserve and promote such genetic diversity as a public resource and to prevent exclusive control over plant genetic materials from falling into private hands.

3. Defend the vital interests of Australian farmers and gardeners, independent Australian seed companies and their employees, and consumers of Australian farm and garden produce, by rejecting any proposal to legislate for the establishment of plant breeders' rights in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Deregulation of Trading Hours

SPEECH.SPEAKER: REID

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 1,288 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned respectively showeth:
1. That we wish to express our strongest opposition to any deregulation of trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory.

2. Past performances have proven that longer trading hours do not lead to increased sales. However, they do increase costs, because shops have to be staffed for longer periods. To cover these increased costs, retailers are forced to increase prices and reduce staff levels. This means that longer trading hours increase both prices and unemployment.
3. There is no real consumer demand for longer trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory.
4. The deregulation of trading hours would force small retail companies out of business.
5. Extended trading hours would gravely disrupt weekend recreation and family life of shop assistants.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Stop the deregulation of retail trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory, by disallowing the Ordinance which amends the Trading Hours Ordinance 1962.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MCLAREN

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 166 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned South Australian citizens respectfully showeth:
That the South Australian and Australian National Railways systems were intended to provide essential transport services to country, semi-isolated and isolated regions;
Australian National Railways' large increases in freight and parcel rates are forcing people to use Australia Post and road transport services;
Country businesses are suffering as a result of Australian National Railways' freight and parcel rate increases; and
At the direction of the Federal Government, the Australian National Railways Commission is destroying country rail services in South Australia;
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will urgently review the freight increases imposed by Australian National Railways and require the Commissioner to:
Reduce freight and parcel rates to reasonable levels, and
Encourage greater public utilisation of the Commission's services.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Can the Minister confirm the report, published in today's Bulletin, that the Government has been trying to persuade Israel and Egypt to issue an invitation to Australian troops to join the proposed force in Sinai? Was this invitation, if it was in fact made, designed to lend an air of legitimacy to the involvement of Australian troops, in much the same way that pressure was applied to South Vietnam to invite Australia into the Vietnam war? Does the statement by the Deputy Prime Minister in Argentina, of all places, that Australian troops will not be sent mean that Egypt and Israel would not meet the Government's request for an invitation? Finally, why was the announcement made by the Deputy Prime Minister, off the cuff, apparently thousands of miles from Australia, while the Government was saying in Australia that the matter has not yet been decided?

—This morning, following the report in the news, the Government checked with the Deputy Prime Minister who has assured it that he did not make the reported statement. Therefore, the latter part of Senator Button's question is irrelevant. It is not a question of the Government trying to persuade Egypt and Israel. Discussions are taking place around the world, in the absence of a United Nations force, for the composition of a peacekeeping force in the Middle East. It has been suggested that if Israel and Egypt were to make joint approaches to various nations that might form an acceptable base. But the Commonwealth Government's position is as has been stated by Mr Street, the Minister for Foreign Affairs. We have made no decisions at all at this moment and the matter remains entirely open.
—I wish to ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister affirm or deny the contents of the letter from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Street, to United States Secretary of State Haig?
—I have no information on the matter. I can neither confirm nor deny it. I will seek out the information and see whether a reply can be given.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The Minister will recall the difficult, protracted and ultimately successful negotiations between the Australian Government, the Papua New Guinea Government and the Queensland Government which resulted in the Torres Strait treaty of December 1978. I ask: Has that treaty been formally ratified? If it has not been ratified, will the Commonwealth Government proceed with the ratification as a matter of urgency?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Torres Strait Treaty was signed by the Prime Minister and the Foreign Minister on 18 December 1978. The treaty, in addition to establishing maritime boundaries and dealing with other related matters, seeks to protect the traditional way of life of the traditional Australian inhabitants in the Torres Strait and of Papua New Guineans living in the coastal area of that country. The treaty will come into force after the necessary legislation has been passed in both Australia and Papua New Guinea and the instruments of ratification have been exchanged. In addition to Commonwealth legislation, the Queensland Government will also need to introduce relevant legislation to implement the treaty provisions.

ANSWER.PARA: During the visits of the Papua New Guinea Prime Minister, Sir Julius Chan, to Australia in December 1980 and again in April this year, both the Australian and Papua New Guinea governments reaffirmed the high importance they attach to the Torres Strait treaty. It was agreed that each government would give priority to the introduction of appropriate legislation which would allow ratification of the treaty as soon as possible. The drafting of the legislation is proceeding in each of the jurisdictions concerned.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. House of Representatives question on notice No. 5876 last year asked, inter alia:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Minister's attention been drawn to evidence given by Dr D. R. Warren to the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources on 6 February 1980 to the effect that the Rundle project is of highly dubious economic feasibility.
In the answer which was given on 20 August last year Senator Carrick referred Mr Howe to an answer he had given to Senator Georges on 2 April 1980. In that answer he said:
The company--
That is Esso-
has given clearly to the public an undertaking of a multi-billion dollar investment in the project.

I ask the Minister: Does he still stand by that statement? Does he believe that statement would have had the effect of talking up Rundle shares? What excuse can he offer to people and institutions such as the Winston Churchill Trust, the Victorian Gas and Fuel Corporation superannuation fund, Bob Baudino's wife and Senator MacGibbon who have seen their Southern Pacific share prices fall by two-thirds since 18 February or by four-fifths since last October?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the latter part of Senator Walsh's question, of course the only excuse I would give is that Senator Walsh cannot understand the simple statement of facts as published in the Press, and therefore he draws entirely the wrong conclusion. I repeat, the shares in the Australian Rundle partners fell very heavily-in halves-between November and early February, at a time that he is alleging I made statements talking up the shares. So there can be absolutely no truth in the matter at all. Day by day the published figures-they have been published in the Press-showed that because of the information that shareholders had they believed that there were varying circumstances, unknown then to the Government, and the shares fell. After the Government invited the partners to make a clear statement the shares fell only fractionally. So the real fall in the shares, and the major fall, was during the time that Senator Walsh suggests that there was a talking up. That, of course, is absolute nonsense.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not recall the particular question itself or, indeed, the answer because we answer many questions. But the fact of the matter is that if it is based on the inference that anything I have said talked up the shares then factually that is wrong because the trend on the stock exchange, as borne out by the published figures and those incorporated in Hansard, show exactly the reverse.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask Senator Carrick whether he believes that the assertion which he re-endorsed in August last year that the company Esso had given clearly to the public an undertaking of a multi-billion dollar investment in the project had the effect of talking up the Rundle shares which, as the Minister said, peaked in October and November, and whether the Minister still stands by that statement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am utterly sure that nothing that the Government said had such effects at all. The fact is that it is abundantly clear that the stock market held views on Rundle which caused the shares to decline and fall. I have been particularly careful in reference to all mining and mineral projects not to do other than to state the evidence which has been given to me, basically by my Department. I have been meticulous in that because it would be utterly wrong to give evidence that either falsely raised or falsely dropped the price of shares.

ANSWER.PARA: Indeed, there was a considerable amount of soul-searching on my part and on the part of my Government when we found that there was a vast difference between what was the public perception and what was the picture as revealed because we knew that, unless the facts could come out, that action would influence wrongly the price of shares. We gave very great attention to that matter and, I think, acted with entire probity.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy, follows a question asked yesterday regarding liquefied petroleum gas prices. Overseas LPG prices have fallen. Has the Minister determined exactly what effect this will have on domestic prices?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In responding to that question yesterday, I said that whilst we were not thoroughly clear on the precise fall, the drop looked as though it would be about $A20 a tonne. I would like to clarify my answer yesterday because reading extracts of the Press report could give something of a wrong impression. There is a formula to create the price of automotive LPG and a formula that creates the country use of LPG as fuel and, of course, a market formula for other uses. As to automotive LPG, that formula will take place with a reference to the body that succeeds the Prices Justification Tribunal. There will be a determination and, clearly, on that basis and assuming the prices are as indicated, there should be a fall in the price of automotive LPG.

ANSWER.PARA: Yesterday Senator Walsh asked me whether the results of the price fall would be that the companies would get the profits or that the profits would be passed on. I had in mind specifically in regard to automotive LPG that the mechanism would ensure the passing on of such profits. As to the petrochemicals, of course they will take the export or market value. As to the domestic consumers, what I set out to indicate was that we would not be able to make any legislation this side of August, but that we expected that, in the interim, the companies, the utilities, would pass on any benefit as such to the consumers. I pointed out that there is a subsidy at this moment of $80 a tonne. The Government has made no policy determinations now, but it is possible that the Government could consider adjusting that subsidy so that the fall in price left the domestic price for gas at the same level as it is now. I cannot foreshadow that at all, but the aim would be that prior to any policy actions at all the consumers should get the benefit.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Is it a fact that the early childhood development program developed by the Whitlam Government is to be taken over by private enterprise in Victoria? Is this another example of the Government's opting out of its responsibilities to the underprivileged?

—The Government is not opting out of any of its responsibilities. The Government has been consistently trying to ensure that it carries out all its responsibilities and has been trying to increase the level of consultation with the States to achieve this end. With regard to the early childhood development program mentioned by the honourable senator, I do not have the particular details at hand but I will undertake to provide them.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Transport aware of comments that photographic drivers' licences help to combat the use of false licences in car thefts, drink driving and other crimes? Is the Minister also aware that a recent survey carried out by McNair Anderson Associates Pty Ltd indicated that some 85 per cent of voters favoured the introduction of photographic drivers' licences? Will the Minister refer this matter to the Minister for Transport and ask that discussions be held with the States and Territories on the possibility of introducing such licences?

—The Government is interested in entering into ways and means of trying to control the road toll. Of course, this abuse must be a contributing factor in that regard. I will pass the question on to the Minister, Mr Hunt, and obtain a reply for the honourable senator.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to follow up the question asked by Senator Walsh. In doing so, I refer the Minister for National Development and Energy to the answer which he gave and remind him of the many times in the Senate on which he spoke in exceedingly glowing terms about the Rundle project. I also remind him of an interjection of mine to which he always seems to respond, that is, that his behaviour reminded me of Alexander Barton, who has been described in this place as the greatest financial spiv in the market place.
—Order! Senator Georges, were you reflecting on the Minister? I was not listening closely, but did you call the Minister a spiv?
—No, Mr President.
—Mr President, what I heard him say was that he had said that my behaviour reminded him of a gentleman named Alexander Barton whom he regarded as the greatest spiv in the market place.
—Senator Georges, you are getting very close to offending.

—I am sorry. I did not intend that. I did not say it deliberately. Perhaps it was unconscious behaviour on the Minister's part, but at the time it reminded me of Alexander Barton, who puffed shares in the market place on a very flimsy basis.
—Senator Georges, do not reflect on the Minister in any way.

—Let me ask him this question: The Senate is concerned as much with the puffing of the shares-that is, the talking up of the shares of Rundle-as with the fall off in the price of the shares. In reply to a question on 5 June about the viability of the Rundle prospect, the Minister said:

QUESTION.PARA: It seems to me that my job is not to influence the market in any way except to ensure when evidence comes to me that what may be the public perception is based on the reasonable facts that are available.

That was the Minister's statement. Was he told on 18 February of the significant but unrevealed engineering and cost difficulties? If so, why, in the light of his answer of 5 June, did he allow the investing public to remain ignorant of the facts available to him even though he was questioned in the Senate on 5 and 26 March?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The very first thing to say is that at all times when I made statements in the Senate they were based not on my own beliefs but upon the advice that I had received from the Department, from the Bureau of Mineral Resources and from the companies concerned. In other words, they were statements which at no time represented a difference as between my Department, which provides objective advice, and the advice from the market place-except when, on my visit to Gladstone on 18 February, I found that there was a very great difference in perception. When I found that great difference it became absolutely necessary to conform to the very principle that I had articulated before-to ensure that the public perception was in line with the emerging facts. I took those steps. Let me make it clear: You cannot have it both ways. If there were some plan on my part-and there was none-to talk up the price of the shares and if talking up the shares was my interest, why would I take steps on 18 February which could have only one inevitable conclusion, that of depressing, over a very long period, the shares? That does not make any sense at all.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me say that I do not regard my integrity in this role as being any less than that of any other honourable senator. Incidentally, I would not have found it necessary to describe Senator Georges as exhibiting anything other than honourable behaviour. Whatever may have been Alexander Barton's ethics, let the honourable senator look to his own. As to my own, I will keep them in good order and will not need any reminder or interjection from Senator Georges on that score. The facts are quite clear: As soon as the perception was markedly different from what had been advised, whether by the Department or elsewhere, I acted and the Government acted.

TALK.START.PARA: —You did not, because I asked you a question early in March and you didn't answer. You knew all the time what was going on. It is on record in Hansard.

—I indicate the situation, because it will be helpful to Senator McLaren. The important situation was that, when we realised that there was a vast difference in perception, we sought not simply to expose that but to find what the absolute truth was. The two companies said: 'We have a fundamental difference of opinion as to the engineering facts, as to the cost facts. We will do our darndest as quickly as possible to get the information in shape'. The whole Government said to them, 'Do it as quickly as possible.' It would have been utterly wrong of us had we on 19 February publicly exposed something on which there would have been no firmness of fact for the market place. What we said was: 'Do your homework as quickly as possible and get the information out as quickly as possible'. If Senator McLaren reads the answer that I gave, he will see that it was a measured and considered answer which indicated then that there was emerging a difference of opinion, a difference of perception. I was very careful to indicate then that that was so. I could not say more because it would have influenced the market place one way or another. I think propriety was observed.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Is the Minister aware that six months have elapsed since he tabled the report on the demand for sea passenger transport between Tasmania and the Australian mainland? Has the Minister received a response from the Tasmanian Government regarding the continuation of a commercially viable sea passenger service across Bass Strait? If so, has any decision been taken?

—Mr Hunt has informed me that there has not been any final conclusion in regard to this matter and that he has asked officers of the Commonwealth to discuss the conclusions of the Bureau of Transport Economics further with State officials from Tasmania and also from Victoria. He has told me that this is likely to take place this month.

—My question, which is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, concerns the Rundle project. In answer to a question asked on 5 June as to whether his staff had complained to the Australian Financial Review on or about 5 March last year about alleged misrepresentation of a statement by him, he said that he would check with his previous principal private secretary if it was regarded as a matter of importance. I ask: Has he checked with his previous principal private secretary and other members of his staff? Did any of them admit to complaining to the Australian Financial Review as stated?

—I did not check with my previous principal private secretary largely, I think, for two reasons-I did not regard it as important and I think he was on leave at the time. In fact, another member of my staff told me something of which I was not aware, that is, that they had said-not on my instructions, as I understand it, but quite informally-to the Australian Financial Review that the headline was an exaggeration of my intention. That was their interpretation and not mine.
—Oh! Now it is coming out.

—Nothing is coming out at all. The honourable senator cannot have it both ways. The fact of the matter is that if, indeed, I was supposed to be speaking in glowing terms to talk things up then, of course, if I made adverse statements I would be talking things down. The statement published in the Australian Financial Review was a very cautious statement and could have had influence on the market. I did not seek to change that in any way. I made the mental reservation-I said to the Senate that I did-that I thought it was an exaggeration of what I had said in this place. From my recollection what I had said was that the enormity of the task, the contemplation of shifting a million tonnes of rock a day and building the retorts to handle it was such that--
—Always a victim of circumstances.
—Whatever else I may be of circumstances, certainly the interjector is a victim of himself and a self-inflicted wound.
—You never know what Laurie Power is doing.
—Order! Senator Walsh, cease interjecting.

—The fact of the matter is that the statement of mine for the Australian Financial Review was a statement of fact. It was an indication of the magnitude of the undertaking and it indicated that of course along the journey engineering difficulties may emerge. Indeed, they had. I repeat that at all times the information I projected was based upon information supplied to me from the sources that advised me.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs to the recent announcement of the Government's intention to increase Australia's foreign aid budget by 6 per cent in real terms or $93m next year. Can the Minister inform the Senate of any new aid programs to be established as a result of this increase? Further, can the Minister say whether any of the increased foreign aid budget will be directed towards the important and necessary field of library and information services for developing countries, especially those in the Pacific region? If so, will there be consultation with the National Library of Australia which has already developed effective relationships in this area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have seen speculation about the level of foreign aid that will be provided in this Budget. I make it clear that at this stage no decisions have been taken with regard to the vote that will be provided for that very important aspect of government support. It is true that there is support in the Government for substantial aid programs. With that in mind the Budget committee is looking and, ultimately, the Cabinet, will be looking at what can be provided in foreign aid this year. We are not able to make any statement at this stage and any definite decisions will, of course, be announced in the Budget context. I have noted what was said with regard to the National Library of Australia, information services and consultation with the Library. I am sure that if the aid agency of the Department of Foreign Affairs wishes to give priority to programs of that kind after representations, it would see that consultation, as appropriate, was undertaken. I am not able to give any assurances on the matter. I will refer the question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs to see whether he wishes to make some statement. I repeat that any speculation at this time on the level of foreign aid is just that-speculation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister for National Development and Energy follows questions asked by my colleagues. In reply to a question on 2 June about whether the Minister's Department had provided information for a 1980 International Energy Agency draft report which downgraded from 235,000 to 40,000 barrels a day the estimated 1990 oil production from Rundle, the Minister said:

QUESTION.PARA: Members of the IEA came to Australia . . . and sought their information wherever they wished to do so . . . they had discussions with my Department . . . there are general discussions between the Government and the IEA--
Can the Minister explain why the IEA had in 1980 a much more realistic appreciation of Rundle's prospects than he did or had as late as 2 February this year?

TALK.START.PARA: —I was asked about a submission; I think that was the word used. I then said that members of the International Energy Agency came to Australia and sought information. Following that question I asked my Department about the procedure followed. I was informed that a questionnaire is distributed to which responses are sought. My Department provided information in that regard. That is my understanding of the procedure. As to the question of whether there are differences between that approach and my own statements, I suggest in the first place that we wait for the published report of the IEA. We will then know whether or not there are aberrations. At this moment we have no reports at all before us. Let us wait for the months ahead to see what we can get.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Transport confirm reports that a section of the national highway in Tasmania has been constructed without the necessary land having been acquired? Are acquisition procedures for national highways the responsibility of the States concerned or the Commonwealth? Will such an error, if one exists, involve any additional expense in the project? If so, will it be at the expense of the State or the Federal Government? Has such negligence previously occurred? What steps, if any, have been or will be taken to ensure that any repetition is impossible?

—I have some information on this matter from Mr Hunt, the Minister for Transport. He has informed me that while national highways are eligible for full Commonwealth funding, land and associated road assets are vested in the States and the acquisition procedures for the national highways, therefore, are governed by the legislation of each State. It is also pointed out that it has been the practice in rural areas of Tasmania for the Main Roads Department to seek permission of landowners to enter property with a view to commencing road construction, including national highways, and for negotiation to take place on the price of land acquired for the roadway while construction is under way. As negotiation often can be lengthy it is not uncommon for roads to have been constructed and open to traffic for some time before the settlement price has been reached. This practice has meant that lengthy delays have been avoided in the provision of improved road conditions for the travelling public. Mr Hunt has also pointed out that some legal argument promoted recently in Tasmania suggests that, if acquisition is not completed prior to the commencement of road construction, landowners might be able to claim for the value of all improvements carried out on their land prior to the settlement being reached. It is also the Minister's understanding that the Tasmanian Government has recently introduced retrospective legislation aimed at overcoming future eventualities of that kind.

—Did the Minister for National Development and Energy note in yesterday's Melbourne Age some comments from Mr J. Ridgeway of the Public Resources Centre in Washington that 'Australia is managing its mineral wealth with less sophistication than a third world country' and that 'Australia is just a fantastic treasure trove for American companies. To them it must seem like a virgin land'? When does the Government propose a major public inquiry into mineral exploitation in Australia designed to ensure that the people of Australia get a fair return for these minerals which are, after all, the property of the people? What pressures or inhibitions does the Minister see as preventing or delaying such a necessary inquiry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not see the article yesterday. If the article states what the honourable senator says it states, it is in defiance of the facts. The fact, as acknowledged by many overseas authorities, is that Australia is moving both in the control of its own economic management and in its developmental activities in ways which are attracting the admiration of many people in the world. The fact is that the Government finds no necessity to hold a major public inquiry. All the evidence is there. The Government has foreign investment guidelines to ensure that there is a significant and majority Australian equity and co-partnership. The Government has, through its own export controls, the ability to ensure a full pricing for its exports. It has through its taxing system at all levels a capacity to take a fair return and pass it back to the public. The States have their responsibilities in pricing the basic minerals such as coal and other resources, and ensuring that they receive the full value for resources and in passing the processed resources by way of benefit to the public.

ANSWER.PARA: Step by step one can look at the huge reinvestment of profits by companies taking part in Australian development. One can look at the massive projections, not by this Government but, for example, by the New South Wales Labor Government as to the dimensions of investment and the benefits by way of employment and skills. I draw Senator Mason's attention to the publication of the New South Wales Government. That Government, in its publication, is openly indicating that what it sees as a $23 billion investment to its State will be of enormous benefit to the people of the State, accruing, in terms of job creation, an increase in skills and rising living standards. All that evidence is before us. It is only those who do not seek to see who would take the dyspeptic view.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Would the Minister maintain the assertions given in his reply in relation to the aluminium industry in particular?

—There is a current inquiry into the aluminium industry, I think by a Senate standing committee. The evidence given by the various departments and by others is available to Senator Mason. Information as to whether Australia is currently getting a world price for aluminium is available for him to seek and to find. It is a fact before his nose. The evidence that we charge a particular percentage of company tax and other taxation is there for him to decide. Of course, the question whether the cost of coal, the cost of electric power, as provided to the various smelting factories, is a real one and one that, as has been said here, is a matter for the States. I am interested to note that the New South Wales and the Victorian governments have come out flatly asserting that what they are charging by way of tariffs for alumina smelting is a fair and reasonable charge and not one that shifts the burden on to other consumers. It is not for me to decide whether that is so. I suggest to Senator Mason that he and I will pursue with great interest the evidence before the committees of inquiry. Indeed, I would want to see the full thrust of public inquiry into every activity. In the end the test of what we are doing is a number of things: First of all, are we using the resources with wisdom and prudence as against the heritage for the future? Secondly, are we using them with full knowledge of the instability of the world and the fact that we have a very heavy responsibility to contribute to the maintenance of the stability and living standards of other countries? Thirdly, consistent with all that, are the Australians taking part in this development and the older generations sharing in the benefits? Those tests can be applied. I think that if they are applied objectively the answer comes out very well for Australia.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Has the Government received the Dix report on the Australian Broadcasting Commission? Will that report be tabled before the Parliament rises? If not, how many recess days can be expect to pass before it will be made available?

—Most honourable senators are aware of the work done by the Dix committee of inquiry. I am able to confirm for the honourable senator that the Dix committee's report on the ABC has been received by the Minister for Communications. Some days ago he made a Press release indicating that the report had been received and was in his possession. The honourable senator's question relates to the matter of whether it will be tabled in this place before the Senate gets up. That decision can be taken only by the Minister in whose portfolio area it rests. I will put that question to him on behalf of the honourable senator.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I preface it by reminding the Minister that for many years the Commonwealth has made specific purpose grants to the States for urban public transport for cities with a population of 40,000 or more. In Queensland the whole of the grants have been, to use a slang term, knocked off by the Premier for use in the area south of the Kingaroy line. The razor gang has now abolished the $50m grant for Queensland which was to be paid shortly. Why was this action taken in secret? How many other razor gang actions have not yet been exposed to public view? What is the total amount in specific grants for urban public transport that has been taken from the States by the razor gang?

—As has happened repeatedly, Government decisions following the committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions have been totally misrepresented by those who seek to do so. Grants for urban public transport have not been abolished; they have been absorbed. In other words, the money has been absorbed into taxation revenue and passed back to the States in that form. I do not have in front of me the specific figures for the flow of money to the various States but they can be made available. I repeat that this deliberate tendency to construe the transferring back to the States of those functions and finance as being a cut is absolute nonsense. It is in defiance of the truth. There is an absorption of this program. As I have said, the details could be secured if Senator Keeffe wants them.

—I ask a supplementary question. This information was conveyed to me in writing by the Minister for Transport. What guarantee can the Minister give that that $50m will not disappear into consolidated revenue in Queensland and that it will be re-allocated for a specific purpose?

—Labor senators, who believe in centralism as opposed to federalism, will always mistrust States, although they will eagerly seek to secure government in those States. The fact is that the Queensland Government, as with the other State governments, is a sovereign government. We have passed back the money to the States and indicated our intentions to them. I believe in their bonafides. I believe that they will take such action. But they are sovereign governments and it is possible for the full light of public criticism to be focused on any action that they take. It is a matter for the future as to how that should be analysed.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Will he comment on the report from the Australian Industries Development Association that the way our coastal shipping and international liner trade is regulated leads to inefficiency and higher costs and profits because of the cartel nature of its operations? If this claim is true, what does the Australian Government plan to do about the situation in terms of regulatory control? Further, will the Government permit the Union Steam Ship Co. of New Zealand Ltd to compete with the Australian National Line on services to the northern coast of Tasmania to permit greater competition and provide a better service to that area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some information from the Minister for Transport in regard to the article to which Senator Watson has referred. The Minister claims that the talk about deregulation of Australian coastal shipping controls is misleading when it refers to controls other than those required for safety and is limited to the requirement to operate under Australian conditions for manning, accommodation and rates of pay. There is no restriction on the entry to the industry or on prices charged by private operators. Other countries with extensive coast lines reserve domestic shipping for national flag carriers. The high cost of coastal liner shipping mainly results from terminal costs in Australia. Consequently, one of the criticisms in regard to the use of foreign crews is not affected by that fact.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the matters referred to in connection with the north coast of Tasmania and the advent of a service by the Union Steam Ship Co., I would need to refer them to the Minister to obtain a specific reply for the honourable senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I have been prompted to ask the question because the Minister is leaving for foreign shores in a matter of hours. By way of preface, I refer to incidents which occurred at three o'clock this morning when I asked what would be the Government's attitude in the future to Estimates committees being ongoing in their operations or conversely whether their functions are to be handed to standing committees. The Minister would be well aware of what occurred, although it was 3 a.m. Although he is the chief helmsman, he handed over to Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle who gave me a polite but not very expansive answer. So I ask the question again. In view of the fact that shortly the Minister is to leave this country, has a decision on this matter been delegated to one of his colleagues? If so, who will carry the baton of responsibility or, as I suspect, will we find in the interim that our comrades in the fourth estate will have the information before we will?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was no discourtesy on my part that I did not respond last night. There was a Minister in charge of the chamber. It seemed to me that the proper courtesy was for the Minister in charge to give the interim answer. As to any attitude towards standing committees and Estimates committees, there are at this moment eight standing committees and eight Estimates committees. There has been some suggestion, however informally, by some that the standing committees and the Estimates committees should be absorbed, but that has been taken in no direction. There are those who favour it; there are those who do not favour it; there are some who believe that the load should be spread wider.

ANSWER.PARA: If there were any such thought on behalf of the Government we would do as we have done with all other things. We would, first of all, put the proposition through the Whips to the Labor Party and to the other senators in this chamber and we would invite a dialogue to see what the viewpoint would be. A number of matters including perhaps changes in the Standing Orders, different office bearers and so on are all under consideration and where they are moving towards some kind of finalisation we have indicated our views or sought information from the Labor Party. We would do exactly the same on this. At this moment there is no thought in our minds for change. But if there should be we would, of course, consult.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It was unfortunate that the Leader of the Government in the Senate referred to the Whips because as a subscriber to Laurie Oakes's brochure, I found out that the Estimates Committee D Chairman-that is the Government Whip-is described as advocating what I advocate and that is, ongoing Estimates committees. Will the Leader have summit talks with his Whip to see whether Laurie Oakes knows more about Estimates Committee D than I do?

—It will always be a joy to have further talks with my Whip. But since the nuances of what Senator Mulvihill has just said escape me, I will ask Senator Kilgariff what has transpired. I know no more than that. As we journey, we will keep informing each other.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Health: Is it a fact that reports from Australia's northern areas indicate that malaria is once again on the increase and that there is a risk of it becoming endemic in Australia again after many years? Is it correctly reported that the incidence of falciparum malaria which is potentially a lethal disease is apparently becoming increasingly resistant to chloroquine? If the situation is as stated, is the Minister in a position to advise why there is an increase in malaria cases? Because malaria is a potential health problem of some considerable magnitude, what action is being taken to control such an outbreak?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Malaria is really endemic in Australia to some extent most of the time; that is to say, occasional cases of it are found. In northern areas of Australia where the appropriate mosquito is to be found, malaria does occur occasionally. The honourable senator is correct in the question he asked in drawing to our attention the seriousness of falciparum malaria and the fact that this form of malaria is becoming more difficult to treat.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator asked why malaria is becoming more common. I think the quick answer to that is that travel by Australians is becoming more common and as the community becomes more mobile and as aeroplane travel gets people to and from malarial areas more rapidly, people can come back incubating the disease. I am not aware that there has been a recorded increase in northern areas of Australia, but I will undertake to see what information is available on this matter and related matters and bring back anything of interest to the Senate, I hope, before the Senate rises.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for National Development and Energy to the steady decline in the price of crude oil by some $3 or $4 a barrel since the beginning of the year and the dramatic reductions in prices sought by some Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries and non-OPEC members over the last couple of days. With the prospect that the average world price may fall below that of Saudi Arabian light over the winter recess, I ask: Is it a fact that Australian refiners are free to purchase crude oil on the world market-I do not simply mean the spot market-that is, they are not bound to purchase Saudi Arabian light, the price of which sets the world parity price payable by the Australian consumer for domestic crude? Will the Government set the world parity price at a level related to any lower average world price or at actual prices being paid for imported crude, whichever is the lower, so that Australian consumers can enjoy a decline in petrol prices as is the case in the United States of America? Finally, will the Minister give an assurance that revenue considerations for either the private sector or the national public sector will not influence such a decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this moment there is happening, happily, a phenomenon in world oil prices. That phenomenon is not accidental. It has happened for two main reasons. The first is the decision of the International Energy Agency and its members to reduce their imports by 5 per cent and not to operate on the spot markets, but to draw down on their stocks. The second is what I regard as a very courageous and very wise decision of Saudi Arabia, that against its own interests it would increase its output by more than a million barrels a day and keep its prices low. The effect has been to convert what had been a shortage of oil in world markets to a temporary glut. The Saudi Arabians are pursuing a situation in which they are trying to get stability in pricing by a formula which would allow for an inflation factor plus a small real growth factor. They understand fully that a very large amount of the recession which has crept over the world in the last five to six years has come from unduly high oil prices, and they are endeavouring to abate that. I will spend the latter part of this week and next week heavily involved in this matter.

ANSWER.PARA: No one can predict what will happen or whether it would be likely that the price of any oil would fall below the price of the Saudi light market crude which is our market price. It is true that our oil companies will be free to purchase oil on the world market, but they will be free only in the sense that there are no restrictions on their doing so except the availability. Since there is, with only relative flexibility, little availability for manoeuvre they would not be able to pursue that course too long. The Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries meeting decided to allow 10 per cent reductions in most countries but not Saudi, Iran and Iraq. Production from Iran and Iraq, if the war does not intensify, may increase. There will be some abatement of volume. I have to stress to Senator Tate that the best informed view is that we can guess that all we are looking at is a short Indian summer of glut, and that in fact the production of oil in the world is falling. We are using oil at twice the rate we are finding it. Indeed, the predictions by IEA in regard to production of oil five to ten years ahead are less than they were last year. There is a downwards modification on this. It is an Indian summer and therefore it is not likely to persist. I think it hypothetical that there would be available in the world any large quantities of oil at a price lower than the Saudi market price. We chose the Saudi market price basically because a significant amount of our crude comes from there but also because it happened to be one of the lowest prices in the world. I think the overall situation is that, sadly, it is an Indian summer and that the trends are not likely to persist unless there is a continued severe recession in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid I have to ask a supplementary question. Really, the Minister has not got to the nub of my question, which is: Why could not Australian consumers enjoy an Indian winter if in fact Australian refiners have available to them crude at a price lower than the Saudi light, or even refuse to take advantage of a lower priced crude available to them? Why should the Government, even for a matter of two or three months, not allow the Australian consumer to benefit from that?
—The aim of the import parity pricing is to price--
—To get revenue.
—To get more revenue-that is the whole purpose of it.

—The aim of the import parity pricing, as judged by the 21 countries, all members of the International Energy Agency, but not by the interjectors, is to ensure that oil shall have a world scarcity price. Because it has that price, conservation and conversion or substitution will take place, as well as encouragement of exploration and of synthetics. The fundamental principle is that world price should persist. I repeat: It is hypothetical. I cannot see how any considerable volumes of oil could be available to Australian refiners at below the light market price. There is not a flexibility of shopping around of any quantities at all. Indeed, one of our companies is endeavouring to find a relatively small amount of oil, and it cannot be done at this moment. Basically, the honourable senator's proposition is hypothetical. Secondly, import parity pricing is the nub of the four key thrusts of energy policy both here and in other countries.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Social Security, concerns the reciprocity of pensions overseas, to which I referred yesterday. Is the Minister able to say whether the average age of pensioners who live and are paid Australian pensions overseas is statistically the same as that of pensioners resident in this country? Have there been any cases of pensions being transmitted for deceased pensioners overseas for a considerable time after their death? Is there any mechanism by which such an overpayment can be recovered? How many investigators are stationed overseas to check that pensioners are in fact still alive, and how is such information ascertained? What penalties can be applied to people who rob the Australian Government while they are resident pensioners overseas? Finally, can a decision be made prior to the presentation of the Budget on whether to continue the payment of pensions overseas?

—To answer the last part of the honourable senator's question first, I think I can say with a fair amount of confidence that it can be anticipated that pensions will continue to be paid overseas to eligible pensioners. As I mentioned in the course of a previous answer in the Senate, pensioners who qualify for a pension while resident in Australia are thereafter entitled to take the pension with them overseas. That has been the position in Australia for many years now and I would not anticipate it changing. I will take on notice the honourable senator's questions regarding enforcement, investigation and so on, and give him a detailed reply.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Social Security, flows from that asked by Senator Townley. Can the Minister give the Senate a guarantee that the Government will maintain its policy of supporting the portability of pensions despite the xenophobic campaign being waged by Senator Townley and others against this policy?

—I believe that I have already given a clear answer to that part of the honourable senator's question which was based on Senator Townley's question. The only qualification that I would put on it is that, as would be well known to the Senate, there have been a number of complaints about different aspects of the pension as it is payable or not payable to migrants to this country and to people who have perhaps been in the country for a period and then left it. I would again indicate to the Senate that those matters are receiving consideration. I have received representations both from within and without Australia as to the adequacy and otherwise of the existing rules and am examining those matters, but there is no general threat to the principle of portability of pensions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, it is a matter of considerable regret to me that I will not be here tomorrow when the valedictory remarks are made concerning the retiring senators. I have taken the opportunity individually--
—When will we hear yours?
—Is this yours?

—There is a compulsion on the part of some to speak, and I recognise that, but I would have thought that on this occasion it might have been considered good manners and good taste for honourable senators opposite to contain themselves. May I simply say that tomorrow we shall witness a unique and sad event. Some 12 senators will retire from this chamber after having between them scored up some 170 years, or an average of 14 years each of service to the Senate. Also they include a very distinguished President-you, sir-a distinguished past President, a distinguished Deputy President, three former Ministers and people who all in their own right, whether as leaders of committees in this chamber or as people who have made a marked contribution to the chamber, have added, I think, great quality to the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I simply say on behalf of those senators who are not retiring that we recognise the contribution that all have made. We have valued the friendships and the associations. For my part, I have very much valued the quality of association and friendship that has been extended to me by both sides of the chamber. I acknowledge that. I believe that those who are going have added enormously over the years to the quality of the chamber. I will, for the moment, be specific about my Australian Labor Party colleagues because I will have other opportunities to speak in respect of my Liberal colleagues. Amongst those who are going are some of the most effective parliamentarians, in the sense of their respect for and understanding of, the execution of parliamentary practice, I have seen in my time. I say that without singling out any of them. Therefore, they have brought to this place a standard and a quality that ought to be acknowledged and we will be the poorer for their going.

I wish them well and thank them for their company, their association, their friendship and their contribution. Above all else I wish them long life and full health for both themselves and their families. I give them an assurance that at any time they should return to this place or travel to the various States while we are here, they will find a warmth of friendship and understanding in what is a unique society-the Senate. I wish them well. Mr President, I can say only that you have brought a quality of dignity, fairness and impartiality to this chamber that has set standards which few chambers, if any, in the world can equal or emulate. I thank you.
Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a personal explanation. On 14 May I made a speech to the Senate outlining the problems facing the Commonwealth Grants Commission in trying to determine the relative shares of tax money to be paid to State governments so that, with equivalent local tax raising efforts, they can provide equivalent State government services. I also pointed out the way in which Victoria and New South Wales are seriously disadvantaged by the present formula. In a speech to the Senate yesterday, Senator Martin criticised my speech in a farrago of distortions, misrepresentations and quotations out of context which reflect little credit on the Queensland Treasury.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall deal with three areas in which I was accused, totally inaccurately, of misleading the Senate. I was accused of failing to deal with benefits to the Victorian State Government of having company headquarters located in Melbourne, although the main activities of those companies are in other States. In fact, as I said in my speech, these headquarters are in Melbourne because of the financial infrastructure there. They are of negligible benefit to State Government revenue. Company tax is paid to the Federal Government, not the State Government. I was also accused of failing to deal with the benefits of protection. In fact, as I pointed out, tariff protection is decided by the Federal Government on national interest grounds. None of it goes to State governments. The only significant benefit to State government revenue is through payroll tax. Victoria receives about $12 per capita annually from payroll tax on protected industries. This is trivial compared with the $70 per capita less than the national average Victoria receives in tax reimbursements. Many believe that excessive tariffs harm economic activity and that Victorian industry, far from being helped by tariffs imposed by the Federal Government, is seriously harmed by them. But that is a different issue which has nothing to do with State Government revenue.

Finally, Senator Martin challenged the accuracy of two tables I used showing the benefits to State governments of payroll tax and mining royalties. I have had these tables checked and they are correctly quoted and sourced. They are a true and fair representation of the situation. In any case the alternative figures cited by Senator Martin strengthen rather than weaken my argument. There are many more mistakes and misrepresentations in Senator Martin's speech, but it is all rather academic since the Grants Commission has already made its decision, which I do not think will disadvantage Queensland and which I am sure will result in a fairer deal for Victoria and New South Wales.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented and wish to make a personal explanation on a quite different subject.
—Are you speaking on behalf of Victoria too?

—It is well known that my view is that this place is not and never has been a States House. I would never do anything so absurd as to compete with Senator Hamer in that respect. The particular matter to which I wish to refer is an article which appeared in last weekend's National Times,the date of which is 7 to 13 June 1981, dealing with the architect Romaldo Giurgola and the design for the new Parliament House. The article, written by John Sandeman, appeared on pages 16 and 17 of the newspaper under the heading: 'One man's house on the hill'. It was indeed a very prominently advertised article because the front page of the National Times for last weekend billed it as the lead article under the heading: 'The real designer of Parliament House: Aldo Giurgola'. Whilst that article was generally very informative, perceptive and interesting, it did contain one passage which it is necessary for me to correct on the public record. I refer to the passage which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Gareth Evans, an assessor in the competition, says bluntly 'Giurgola is the architect, not Thorp.'

While I am certainly delighted to see Aldo Giurgola getting the public recognition he undoubtedly deserves for the Parliament House design, it was more than a little mischievous and certainly more than a little unfair to Richard Thorp and myself for the writer to purport to quote me in those terms. What I did say to Sandeman in a telephone conversation-it was simply by way of an aside during a conversation about something else, namely, the cost of the building-was that I though the basic design concept, and indeed such element of genius as that concept might be thought to possess, was clearly Giurgola's. But I was not then making, nor have I ever made, any big dramatic point about it, not least because Rick Thorp himself has always acknowledged-as he does again in the course of this article when quoted-the central role of Giurgola in generating the basic form and design approach of the winning scheme. Thorp is quoted as saying:
Obviously Aldo is the central figure in the form of the Parliament House, and in particular the design approach the firm takes.

The point I make very clearly is that the reality is that this design project was so huge and complex that its realisation must necessarily have been a team effort, involving not only the collaboration of Giurgola and Thorp but also the work of a host of other architects and specialist consultants. 'The' architect was not so much either Thorp or Giurgola as the firm of Mitchell-Giurgola and Thorp, of which they are both principals. I have no doubt whatsoever that Richard Thorp's personal contribution to the evolution of the winning design was, and remains, indispensable, both in the overall co-ordination of the design project and in the bringing to it of a distinctively Australian feel for landscape, location and function. I find it regrettable that the National Times found it necessary to downgrade Thorp's role at the price of boosting Giurgola's. Certainly I do not want to be thought of as in any way contributing to or associating myself with that enterprise. I have written to the National Times in similar terms to those I have just used. Given the importance of this matter for the reputation and the future of Mr Thorp, and indeed the interest of honourable senators and members of the House of Representatives in the matter, given that it is after all the new Parliament House that is in issue, I thought that it would be appropriate for me also to make that statement on the parliamentary record. I appreciate the Senate granting leave to enable me to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a personal explanation. Last week, on 5 June, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) in the course of a personal explanation said:

SPEECH.PARA: On 16 May 1980 in the Senate Senator Robertson referred to the Kimberley election and stated:

It is understandable that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Chaney) is sensitive about this area. He is sensitive because he is a member of the Liberal Party of Australia and because the Western Australian Liberal Party took the shameful action against the people of the north-west. He is sensitive because his own brother was involved in this matter. I do not like to raise these personal matters but . . .
Senator Chaney then went on to say:
Once again, I made no reply at the time but I think honourable senators would know that I would have found that reference objectionable.

Senator Chaney in the course of his speech went on to say that it was a pity that the people who spoke on this matter did not check their facts. He indicated that the facts related to the Kimberley by-election are recorded in the record of the Court of Disputed Returns, No. 1 of 1977. Then he read an apology from Nationwide. I wish to make a very brief personal explanation about my involvement. I have checked the facts, as Senator Chaney suggested. I have done this as he suggested, by reference to the findings of His Honour Mr Justice Smith. I have the documents. The facts are as I stated them when I spoke on 16 May 1980. I believe that the Minister would be sensitive, as I said in my statement, because of the actions of his party, the Western Australian branch of the Liberal Party, which set out to deprive Aboriginal voters of the vote, particularly at the time when he was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Members of his party set out to do this in two ways, as indicated in the findings of the Court of Disputed Returns. I will not go into those in any great detail. Certainly the Minister and most others would be aware of them. The first way was through the plan referred to as G16 in the proceedings, and the other was through improper directions to polling staff. The plan basically was that five Liberal laywers were to act as scrutineers and 'use of technicalities of the law to the fullest extent' to deprive Aboriginal people of their franchise. These are the people to whom the person involved, Mr Ridge, referred in a letter to J. P. Quilty of Hall's Creek, which was quoted in the Nation Review in September 1977. Speaking of Aboriginal people he said:

It was a degrading experience to have to campaign amongst the Aborigines to the extent I did and it offended me to know that whilst I was concentrating my efforts on these simple people over the last couple of weeks, I was neglecting a more informed and intelligent section of the community . . . It is indeed a travesty of justice that a comparative handfull of such ill-informed people . . . should have the right or the power to determine the future of our state.
A little further on he said:
. . . by the next election there could be in the order of 3,000 to 4,000 Aborigines on the roll and under such circumstances the Liberal Party would be doomed to failure . . .
Mr Justice Smith in the Court said of the plan:
. . . it seems to me that the only inference open on the evidence is that the intention was to stultify the use by illiterate voters of How to Vote Cards as a medium of instruction.
I repeat that phrase. He said:
. . . to stulify the use of How to Vote Cards . . .

The second matter to which I referred was the improper directions given to staff at polling booths. Mr Neil McNeill, the Minister for Justice-there is a strange contradiction-who is, of course, a member of the Liberal Party, directed the Chief Electoral Officer to send telegrams to all the presiding officers on illiterate voting procedures. The purpose of this, quite clearly, in the words of the Court was 'to stultify the use of How to Vote Cards' and to deny the people their right to vote. The telegrams referred to this purpose. The Chief Electoral Officer himself and his Returning Officer believed that the how to vote card:
. . . was an adequate and proper mode as to the marking of his (illiterates) ballot paper.

Of course it is. This is accepted by anyone with experience of illiterate voters-anyone, that is, except those who were trying to deprive the Aboriginal people of their franchise. In the Court Mr Justice Smith made it clear that he agreed. He said:

The majority of the electors were elderly people and many of them were frail, but nevertheless they crossed the (flooded) creek carrying their 'How to Vote' cards aloft so that the cards would not get wet.
Then he commented:
Each had a card, kept and shown to the Judge at the field sitting.
Mr Justice Smith then said:
The impression I gained of their evidence was of a simple, but sensible and sincere people who were anxious to exercise the franchise . . .

The Liberals, of course, were trying to deprive them of that very thing. Since the Minister has mentioned his brother, I state that specific mention was made of Mr John Chaney in the Court proceedings. He was indicated as one of the lawyers selected to act as scrutineers. It was indicated in the proceedings that he went to Turkey Creek by helicopter but arrived there too late. The work that he was to do had already been done. He went on to Kununurra where he acted as a scrutineer. Professor Tatz in his book Race Politics in Australia referring to the activities of Mr Chaney in Kununurra, stated:

The atmosphere at Kununurra was tense-but the Court found one single difference from Hall's Creek: 'Mr J. M. Chaney, the respondent's admitted . . . agent at this polling place, found that aspect of his instructions, he said, to be distasteful--
He was referring to the putting of the questions-
and he did not request that the questions be put.' However the Court found constant interjections from scrutineers . . .

Therefore, I do not deviate from my original statement. I was disgusted by what the Liberal Party did. I was in the electorate shortly after the election, after the plan was put into effect. I am pleased to say that the Liberal supporters to whom I spoke in that area were also disgusted. I would have thought that the Minister would have been embarrassed. He has made some fine speeches in this place and outside it-I will not bother to quote them-and these would suggest that he would be embarrassed about the matter. I would have thought that he would have been sensitive about the issue. If he is not, I am surprised and, frankly, disappointed. If he is not sensitive, than I am in error on that point but I am in no other error in respect of the issue I raised. It was a shameful action, it was carried out by the Western Australian Liberal Party of which the Minister is a member, his brother was involved and his brother indicated his own shame in the record of proceedings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, one is entitled to be regarded as an honourable senator in this place and one is required to regard one's Opposition in the same terms. I therefore simply direct the attention of the Senate to a significant difference between what was said by Senator Robertson today and what was said by him on 16 May. I referred to what he said on 16 May because he said on that date:

SPEECH.PARA: He--
Meaning me-
is sensitive because his own brother was involved in this matter.

Today when he started his explanation he referred to his words as being: 'Sensitive because of the actions of his party'. There is a significant distinction between the two phrases. My personal explanation related to the role of my brother. My brother, who was referred to in an Australian Broadcasting Commission report, sought and recovered damages and received an apology. I put that matter on the public record. I ask Senator Robertson to look at the difference between the words he used on 16 May and the word he used today. I suggest that he ought to be a little more careful in composing such an explanation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, if the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) wants to have a debate on this matter we will be very happy to give him a debate. I seek leave to make a further personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I resent the implication of what Senator Chaney has said. I thought I had been very kind to the Minister. Perhaps if Senator Walsh had dealt with the matter it would have been dealt with more appropriately, given the answer that we have received. The words which I used on 16 May are the words which I quoted today in their entirety. The Minister may check them from the record. I quoted from his speech.

—by leave-To respond briefly, I simply invited the honourable senator to examine the difference between the words he used on 16 May as recorded on page 2391 of Hansard and the words he used in opening his personal explanation in the Senate today. There is a significant difference.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melzer Sen J.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, I present the report relating to the following proposed work:

SPEECH.PARA: Redevelopment of Australian Antarctic Bases.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Leader of the Government in the Senate requesting that Senator Sim be discharged from further attendance on the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence and nominating Senator Lewis to be a member of the Committee.

INTERJECT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle)-by leave-agreed to:

That Senator Sim be discharged from further attendance on the Standing Committee of Foreign Affairs and Defence and that Senator Lewis, having been duly nominated in accordance with Standing Order 36AA, be appointed a member of the Committee.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle for Senator Carrick) proposed:
That, unless otherwise ordered, the Senate on Thursday, 11 June 1981, meet at 9 a.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to oppose this motion because I realise the futility of doing that. But I want to use this motion to make some reference to the sitting hours that we have been subjected to over the last couple of weeks. Last week, we met until 3 a.m. and this morning we rose at almost 3 o'clock. I think that business was concluded at about 2.45 a.m. when there were a couple of short adjournment speeches. Last night I demonstrated a lack of finesse, I suppose, by saying that the person responsible for us sitting at that hour of the night should have his head read. That is not the sort of language that I normally use but I think that it probably expressed precisely my feelings.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate simply cannnot function properly if we sit until 3 o'clock in the morning, and follow that up with sittings to 2 a.m. Continual late sittings do not assist us. We are sent here to represent the people of our States and to watch over the legislation that passes through this chamber. We cannot do that properly if we sit these hours. In addition, one must remember that not only are senators affected but also are all sorts of people affected. Staff of the Parliamentary Library must stay back to unearthly hours simply because we are here. Attendants in this place have families waiting for them and they are deprived of their family contact and of the sleep that they need because they are here until 3 o'clock in the morning and thereafter. Transport officers get away after the last of us leaves and they are here before most of us arrive. They get very little time for rest or recreation. All of these people should be considered. Just think what it must be doing to their health. We have a few medical practitioners in this place and I am sure that they will tell us that continued late sittings, such as we have had, are no good for the health of the people who are affected by them.

What about the health of honourable senators? We seem to forget that in this very parliament two members passed away this year through heart ailments-one in the House of Representatives, the Honourable Eric Robinson, and the other in this chamber, a young person whose death shocked us all. Yet what are we doing? We are placing strains on the health of all members in this Parliament by making them sit here until 3 o'clock in the morning when they have been here from about 8.30 the previous morning. Not only are we sitting until 3 o'clock in the morning but also we are having to front up for committee meetings and for early morning sittings the same day.

I do not know what the plan is for tonight. I am not sure whether there was a plan for last night, but, even if the plan for tonight is that we finish at 11 o'clock, we must be back here at 9 a.m., after having sat until nearly 3 o'clock this morning. This is not good enough. People in the community cannot believe that we have the stupidity to sit these hours, or that we have the crush of legislation to get through that we have at the moment. I believe that we are tempting fate with respect to the health of every person in this chamber.

When we come back after the winter recess, I hope that we will bring a bit more sanity into the sitting hours than we have had this session. Recently we all voted on what we think the sitting hours should be, but it is not much use sitting those hours if at 10.30 or 11 o'clock at night it is decided that, instead of adjourning, as the Standing Orders provide, we go on and on until the business is finished. As I have said, I will not oppose this motion of sitting at 9 o'clock tomorrow morning because I see the futility of opposing it. But I point out that the community expects a lot better from us, the people who work for us deserve a lot better from us and honourable senators in this chamber should look at their health and performance and start sitting proper hours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take advantage of this motion not only to echo and to endorse the sentiments just expressed by Senator Colston but also to express my protest, which I believe is shared by a great majority of senators in this chamber on both sides, about the whole way in which Government business is being managed this session and, in particular, in the last few weeks. It has become an absolute travesty of disgrace. I am not simply making a ritual protest about the consequences of the necessary log jam of business which always occurs at the end of every session but which has been particularly acute on this occasion; nor am I making my other personal ritual protest about the contemptible way in which important pieces of legislation such as the Freedom of Information Bill have been treated in the Government's programming.
