I am making a more general point about the extraordinary incapacity that this Government seems to have to be able to predict from day to day or even some times from hour to hour what business will come on and as the result the incapacity for senators to give even a semblance of organised attention to the Bills with which they have to deal.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality is that Bills and motions have come and gone from the Notice Paper like the Scarlet Pimpernel over the last few weeks. Honourable senators see them here and see them there but we do not see them when we expect to find them when they are initially scheduled to come up. It has happened again this morning. The appearance of the red business paper on our desks indicated that a number of major Bills, which are not expected to come on until tomorrow-including the income taxation tax law amendments to section 260 which were not completed in the House of Representatives until late yesterday-are, in fact, coming on today. That change was made, I understand, without any consultation with the Whips on our side or indeed with anyone on our side of the chamber to indicate that this was happening. As a matter of courtesy I will make the point and then sit down. The conduct of business has been a disgrace to everyone--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is unfair to blame the Whips.

—I blame everyone on the Government side starting, of course, with the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) and those honourable senators immediately responsible at the ministerial executive level for the conduct of Government business. That extends across to the Cabinet which, on occasions, has made life very difficult for them. But the reality of the matter is also that the Whip's Office, whether through its incapacity, inattention or inability simply to keep up with the pace of things, has undoubtedly contributed to, as I read the situation, the all-pervading sense of confusion that has prevailed over the last few weeks. It is an impossible situation to deal with. I hope it will not be repeated when we resume in the Budget session.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to this motion in support of what my colleagues Senator Colston and Senator Evans have already said. I have raised objections on many occasions to the manner in which Bills come from the other place when we get to the end of a session. A very important Bill-the Health Acts Amendment Bill-is due to come into this place today and we are to debate that Bill today. The Senate is supposed to be a House of review. The motion provides that we will resume at 9 o'clock tomorrow morning. I have previously expressed in this chamber my concern for the health of the attendants, particularly those who serve this chamber. When we sit to 3 o'clock in the morning and they have to be back here, as they had to do last week, at 9 o'clock they are out on their feet, and when certain things take place here they are the ones who get the blame. It is happening all because the Government cannot manage its business. That has been most evident this session because of the disarray in the Government's ranks over certain Bills. Paper tigers have been making statements that they will oppose Bills and the Government has had to take the Bills back to the Cabinet, only to find that these people are still not satisfied. They make outlandish statements about the things they will do, but when the chips are down they knuckle under to their party and act in here at the behest of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). As a matter of fact, they are nothing but damp squibs. We on this side of the Parliament know that the staff that service this place-the staff in the dining rooms, the transport drivers, the Hansard staff in particular, some of whom do not get away until daylight-have to suffer because of the enormous rows and disunity in the Fraser Government at this time. I say that it is absolute madness, as my colleague Senator Colston said, to be sitting here till 3 o'clock in the morning and them coming back at 9 o'clock.

SPEECH.PARA: Last week I asked Senator Durack, I think it was, whether he could give us an undertaking that we would sit reasonable hours if leave were given to incorporate second reading speeches in Hansard and he said that he would look at it. But he did not have much of a look at it, or if he did he just turned a blind eye, because the same thing has happened this week. Having sat till 3 o'clock this morning, we are now being asked to come back here at 9 o'clock tomorrow morning, Thursday, without any indication being given to the Senate as to what time we will get up tonight. Are we to get up according to the time laid down by the Standing Orders, that is, 11 p.m. or are we to negate the adjournment question?

TALK.START.PARA: —We will get up when the business sheet is finished.

—I want an undertaking from the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) about that. Are we to go through until the whole of the business is finished, whether it be 5 or 6 o'clock, and be back here at 9 o'clock? I say to members of the Government that they are nothing but heartless, cruel people. I am not worried so much about those of us who have been elected to this place, but I am very concerned about the paid staff of the Parliament.
—You are the one who is wasting time. You are wasting time now.

—The few minutes I am wasting will not make one iota of difference. If Senator Thomas keeps interjecting he might find that I will waste a lot more time because this morning I gave notice of a motion, which I hope will come on for debate when we resume, expressing the disgust of the Senate at the way in which we are being treated. If there is no proper understanding about sitting reasonable hours, I for one will refuse leave to incorporate all second reading speeches in Hansard. A new Bill is to come into this place today. Unless the Minister can say that we will adjourn at a reasonable hour tonight, the Minister might well have to read that second reading speech because, having got to this stage, I could not care less about her having to read it. The Government has got us all to the point of frustration. I say again, in speaking to this motion, that I am most disappointed, as are my two colleagues who have spoken to this motion, with the way in which the Government is treating this Parliament. I say again to the people who are listening to this debate that the Government is in complete disarray. The sooner it goes to the people and a sensible government is elected the better off the people of Australia will be. They will then get a fairer go and we will have no more things such as the razor gang being set up to cut away at the necessities of the people in this community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: -I think we all agree that it is a matter of concern that the Senate should sit till the early hours of the morning and, in particular, that those who do not have a vote on this matter, namely, the staff of the Senate, are kept here until we go home and in some cases for an hour or so afterwards. Nevertheless, I do not think that the sin can be visited entirely upon the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) or the Whips. Senator McLaren, Senator Evans and Senator Colston have indicated where the blame lies. It really lies in the Cabinet room or with the Government. I must say that I have received courteous attention from both the Government Whip and the Opposition Whip, and I acknowledge that.

SPEECH.PARA: Looking to the long term, I consider that the sort of exercise that has been undertaken recently-that is to say, the distribution of a voting paper upon which we have three options as to future Senate sitting times-was inadequate in that no opportunity was given, as I understand it, for these options to be debated in the Senate. In particular, I would regard anyone opting for the first option to be laying the foundation for a decline in the role of the Senate. It might do something for the night life in Canberra but it certainly will not do any good for the Senate or honourable senators. I would have liked to see, before this paper was distributed to honourable senators for a vote, a proper debate on this subject and a committee established to look at the question of options to see whether a compromise could be reached between the various viewpoints of honourable senators on this very important question of sitting hours. Frankly, before the matter is determined, I will be seeking the co-operation of other senators to establish such a committee because there are further options that I have considered.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another form is going around at the moment.

—Senator Townley informs me that there is another form; so it is not concluded. I know that our worthy President, Senator Sir Condor Laucke, if he were in the Chair, would ensure that the rights of the Senate and individual senators were preserved. I hope that his successor will also do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I will clarify for the Senate the program for today. A number of senators have requested information in regard to the Government's program and the expected time for the rising of the Senate tonight. The last item on the order of business is the Health Acts Amendment Bill 1981. That message has not yet been received. It is expected that the Bill will come into this place today, but it will not be part of the program of the Government to debate it today. That Bill was listed in the expectation that that message would be received and we would be in a position, if time permitted, to debate it. But it is the expectation of the Government that the other matters, with the exception of that last item, will comprise the program for today. I draw attention to the fact that there are to be cognate debates on those Bills which relate to the work of the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee and there is to be a cognate debate on the income tax legislation. It would seem that the program is one that should be completed in a reasonable time if honourable senators do not debate whether we are busy but actually debate the Bills that are before the Senate.
—If it is not, what time do we get up?
— That would depend on the flow of business through the Senate today. It would be expected to be within a reasonable time-somewhere around the adjournment time that is listed on the business sheet.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
(Quorum formed).

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 June, on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, may I propose a cognate debate on this Bill, the Income Tax (Assessment and Rates) Amendment Bill 1981, the Petroleum Products Pricing Bill 1981 and the Australian Capital Territory Gaming and Liquor Authority Bill 1981 as they all relate to the report on the Review of Commonwealth Functions.

—Mr Deputy President, there is an agreement that we will deal with the Commonwealth Functions (Statutes Review) Bill and the Income Tax (Assessment and Rates) Amendment Bill in one cognate debate and with the Petroleum Products Pricing Bill and the Australian Capital Territory Gaming and Liquor Authority Bill as another cognate debate.
—Is it the wish of the Senate to have a cognate debate on the first two Bills?
—Mr Deputy President, if that is the agreement which has been reached between the Whips, that is acceptable. I understood that we were to debate the four Bills together.

—Mr Deputy President, in point of explanation, I just make the comment that such a debate was requested, and we indicated that that course was not appropriate for the way in which we had to handle the Bills.

—Is it the wish of the Senate to have a cognate debate on the Commonwealth Functions (Statutes Review) Bill and the Income Tax (Assessment and Rates) Amendment Bill? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I made the mistake of taking seriously the business paper that the Government issued about two hours ago and I thought that some legislation would be introduced-that there would be a first reading before this second reading debate took place. However, I am speaking on the second reading of the Commonwealth Functions (Statutes Review) Bill and the Income Tax (Assessment and Rates) Amendment Bill. The first Bill is comprised almost entirely of decisions made by the razor gang which require legislative backing. I must protest at the method which the Government has chosen because of its past ineptitude in dealing with these legislative changes. It has shown its contempt for Parliament in lumping a whole range of disparate legislation into one Bill. It makes one wonder whether in the next session the Government will decide to simplify its procedures even more and tack all legislation on to the Budget and put it in one Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Before moving on to the substance of the Bills, I will quote some extracts from a speech made in February 1976 by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcom Fraser). He said:
In the past two weeks, the Government has undertaken a searching review of all its spending programs.
The Government is determined to manage Australia's fiscal affairs properly. It is determined to tackle inflation and unemployment firmly.
. . . we aim to cut back the unnecessary growth in government and the excessive deficit which has accompanied it.

The Prime Minister referred to 'ways of achieving maximum administrative efficiency and of eliminating waste and duplication within and between government departments, and between Commonwealth and State departments'. He continued:
There has been a rationalisation of commissions, boards of inquiry, and other advisory bodies as announced yesterday.
. . . A total of no less than 230 expenditure items was individually examined. Decisions were made to end, reduce or defer spending on most of these items.

If that language sounds familiar, if it sounds very similar to the language we heard on 30 April this year-just five years later than the extracts I have quoted-it is no accident, because in February 1976 the Fraser Government was conducting a political stunt and in April 1981 and in the months which preceded April 1981 it was engaged on another political stunt, the legislative consequence of which is before us now. Let there be no mistake about this: The razor gang exercise was a political stunt by Australia's greatest ever political stuntman-the Prime Minister. It has been misrepresented as a watershed, to use the Prime Minister's words. In fact, it is not just rhetoric; it is recycled rhetoric. It is the rhetoric of 1976 recycled in 1981.

According to the Government's own estimates, the ultimate-I stress the word 'ultimate'-gross savings of the razor gang's decisions will be $560m. The Government claims that 360 decisions were made. I could not find quite that many. The net result, however, the net savings, are not estimated by the Government but they will certainly be considerably less than $560m, for a variety of reasons, chief among them probably being that there are 32 decisions to transfer functions currently performed by the Commonwealth Public Service, by salaried public servants-engineering, architectural and other professional services-to the private sector. There is little doubt that as a result of those activities being transferred to the private sector, costs to the public purse will increase. There are a handful of very highly paid public servants. There are some who receive just over $1,000 a week but the private consultants hired by this Government frequently receive $1,000 a day.

No one should be more conscious of this, of the enormous cost of hiring private consultants on a part time basis, than a Minister of the razor gang, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, because it was she who a few years ago initiated the social security conspiracy case which has so far cost the taxpayer between about $6m and $7m. I repeat that the action initiated by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle as Minister for Social Security has cost the taxpayer between $6m and $7m. Mr Rofe, Q.C., the senior counsel hired by the Government, hired by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, received over $1,000 a day. His assistant receives just under $1,000 a day. In calendar year 1980, both Mr Rofe and his assistant who, I believe, is Mr Arden, received from the Commonwealth in fees something over $140,000. We have a decision in the name of cost paring to dispense with public servants who, at the very top of the range-at permanent head status-will be paid over $1,000 a week. We know that there are only a handful of them and, I might add, they pay tax on that $1,000 a week. But the decision has been made to replace them with private consultants costing anything between $500 and $1,000 a day. In many cases, there is little doubt that tax on that money would be avoided in one way or another. There have been 32 of those decisions. It may well be that the additional costs incurred by the Commonwealth in transferring those functions to the private sector will cancel out the gross savings.

Eighteen functions are to be transferred to the States. Some of those functions-for example, women's refuges which required in the context of a Commonwealth Budget a very small allocation of $3m, which is about 0.01 per cent of total Commonwealth outlays-are to be transferred to the States. There is little doubt that some of the States will decline to fund those women's refuges-the consequence of that contemptible decision we have witnessed around Parliament House in the last couple of weeks. Those functions transferred compulsorily to the States and which the States do not decide to drop, will be financed by State taxes and charges which are inequitable, insofar as they are regressive, and will be inflationary. The functions transferred to the States include nuclear supervisory activities. Leaving aside the fact that this is in breach of several international treaties to which Australia is a party, the Commonwealth is proposing to transfer activities to eccentric Premiers, one of whom takes his medical advice from Milan Brych and his nuclear advice from Stephen Hogarth who says that he has a fusion reactor in the boot of a motor car producing hydrogen. The Commonwealth actually proposes to transfer nuclear supervisory activities to that government headed by a man who takes his medical advice from Milan Brych and his nuclear advice from Stephen Hogarth. That not only is irresponsibility but also verges on criminal irresponsibility. Although I suppose, given that the Prime Minister takes his economic and taxation advice from the make-up girl at a television studio, at enormous cost to the taxpayer, it is not inconsistent that he should decide to transfer nuclear supervisory obligations to the Premier of Queensland.

There were 39 decisions to amalgamate pre-existing boards and 81 decisions to terminate or reduce authorities and programs. Some of those decisions, of course, were eminently sensible, such as the decision to abolish the post of rabbit scalp or fox scalp collector in the Australian Capital Territory, especially since none have been presented to be examined for a couple of decades, or the decision to abolish the Balloon Launching Co-ordinating Committee. Not all of those decisions were irresponsible or unjustified. But as the honourable member for Canning, one of the Government's own back benchers, Mr Bungey, pointed out on 1 May on the radio program AM, to the extent that those 120 decisions, amalgamations, terminations, reductions and so on, were justified, they reflect upon pre-existing ministerial negligence. Why have the Ministers responsible for the Balloon Launching Co-ordinating Committee and the rabbit scalp collector position not abolished those sorts of positions in the past? If they were properly discharging their ministerial duties they would not have to be prodded into doing them by the political stunt people of the razor gang.

There were 15 decisions to sell assets, some of them Commonwealth assets. Some of them, although apparently unbeknown to Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) and other members of the razor gang, such as the Australian Wool Testing Authority are not Commonwealth assets in the true sense of the word. I will say more about that decision and will move an amendment in the Committee stages. There were 36 decisions to review functions. What that means is that they were the matters that were too hard. They were the matters on which the desires of the Liberal Party conflicted with those of the National Country Party whose Ministers were on the Committee, and those functions of which the Country Party was conscious. It is quite clear that the Minister for Primary Industry was so culpably negligent and so culpably fundamentally incompetent, that he did not grasp the implications of the sale of the Australian Wool Testing Authority. When it came to selling airports and flogging off some of the functions of Telecom Australia the Government was impinging on what the Country Party regards as heartland territory. There were 36 decisions to review and 13 decisions to allow the functions to remain as they are.

I remember the then Prime Minister being rightly ridiculed in 1971 or 1972 for saying: 'The Government has made a decision. The Government has decided to make no decision'. Prime Minister McMahon was ridiculed for that, but the present razor gang in effect said that 13 times. There are some truly absurd decisions in this list of 338 or 360 decisions-whatever the number is. There is the abolition of the Australian Plague Locust Commission. Unfortunately, locusts do not recognise the territorial imperatives of State governments and they do not stop at State borders. If ever there was an interstate problem requiring Commonwealth action it must be the problem of locust plague control. The Commonwealth has abolished the Australian Plague Locust Commission. The Australian Government Publishing Service is to have some of its activities transferred to the private sector, says one decision. Another decision says that the publishing activities of the Department of Defence will be transferred to the Australian Government Publishing Service. Did Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle ever actually look at those decisions in total? If she did, how does she explain such contradictory decisions being contained in the same report? The Curriculum Development Centre, which only six weeks before the Minister for Education, Mr Fife, was eulogising, is to be abolished. The Australia Post Courier service was to be abolished, so the report said. But if one scratches a little deeper one finds that it is to be replaced by the Australia Post parcel service which, so far as anyone could tell, affected only parcels that weighed more than about half a tonne and the colour of the vans. It was decided to keep the Australian Information Service in New Delhi, Mexico City and Vienna while shutting it down at such major overseas posts as London and Washington. The Commonwealth Council for Rural Research and Extension, set up only two years ago by the Government, is also to be abolished by the Government.

The report signalled the third change in eight months in depreciation rates applicable for investment by reducing the loading on depreciation rates from 20 per cent to 18 per cent. What that in fact means, and it is worth explaining just to demonstrate how trivial the decision was, is that last year a 20 per cent loading on depreciation rates was introduced pursuant to the Budget. An item of plant or equipment previously depreciable at 15 per cent per annum would be depreciable at 18 per cent per annum. As a result of the razor gang decision, that 3 per cent increase in annual depreciation rates is to be reduced by one-tenth, in other words by 0.3 recurring per cent. So instead of having a depreciation rate of 18 per cent for those items of equipment, the new depreciation rate will be 17.6 recurring per cent. That surely must be regarded not as fine tuning of the economy but as super-fine tuning. It ought to be regarded far more accurately as yet another political stunt.

We have already seen several backdowns arising mostly from the fundamental initial incompetence of the Minister for Primary Industry but also delving into other areas such as a modification of the decision to impose fees for second degrees, colleges of advanced education amalgamations and the Glebe housing estate in Sydney. The report was supported by reams of rhetoric about the Fraser Government's commitment to small government. The next day we received a very telling demonstration of how strong that commitment is when the Fraser Government, moved by ministerial fiat, decided to limit the trivial imports of canned ham into Australia because it was pressurised by a vocal but minuscule vested interest group. That is how the Fraser Government's real commitment to small government is. Never mind what the consequences of that decision might be for Australia's international trade in general. Whenever a minority makes a lot of noise and is in a position to apply pressure to the Country Party especially, the Fraser Government caves in and misuses its legislative and regulatory administrative powers to protect any noisy vested interest, providing that vested interest has some leverage on those two parties. Women's refuges do not come into that category.

Later in the last week or so we saw further evidence of the Fraser Government's phoney commitment to small government. We saw the twentieth century version of the old Tudor mercantilist chartered monopoly when chartered duopolies or oligopolies, reinforced by legislation, were handed out by this Government to pay off its political obligations to Rupert Murdoch with the two airlines agreement and the Broadcasting and Television Act amendments.

Again on the subject of small government, I mention that the major gross saving claimed by the Government will come from the projected reduction in the Public Service. I am not and have never been, nor has my party even been, an advocate of a bloated and superfluous Public Service; but, given the Government's decision to reduce the Public Service on cost saving grounds, it is ironic that simultaneously it should maintain trade and protectionist policies with a view to maintaining employment. The marginal cost of maintaining employment in the public sector is certainly lower than that of maintaining employment in the most highly protected industries.

One decision of the razor gang, which is partially related to that aspect and is incorporated in the legislation before us, is that of halving export incentive payments after mid-1982. One of the objectives of the generally protectionist policy of the Fraser Government is to discourage imports. Whether this Government is conscious of it or not, at least one of the effects of that policy is to provide a disincentive for exports. One wonders why a government would simultaneously provide, at the very great cost-if the Government were to be honest-of around $300m a year, a system of export incentives. One might wonder why a government which ostensibly is committed to small government should on the one hand apply a protectionist policy which provides disincentives for exports and on the other simultaneously apply a policy which provides incentives for exports-with two regiments of bureaucrats simultaneously administering schemes which have contradictory consequences, all in the name of small government. Of course, the Prime Minister is notorious for his penchant for assorted tax dodges for business investment, the underlying assumption of which is that governments are better able to judge than is private management the areas into which business investment should be directed and encouraged. That also is a repudiation of the fundamental tenet of small government.

The Prime Minister is no disciple of Adam Smith, let alone of Ayn Rand or Friedrich von Hayek. His economic philosophy, if it could be dignified by such a name, is a crazy and innumerate mixture of physiocracy and mercantilism, of which the chartered duopolies and oligopolies which we have seen passing through this House are prime examples. They are straight from Tudor mercantilism and probably have similar sordid motives.

From this so called cost-cutting exercise there are many notable omissions. In fact, there is sacred territory on which the so called razor gang committee was instructed not to intrude. The one thing that those omissions have in common is that some of them, which I am about to enumerate, were the Prime Minister's pet projects and others were 1980 electoral bribes. I refer first to the proposed Northern Territory railway. A cost-benefit analysis shows that there will be no return for the capital outlay on the railway of $430m. In the meantime, foreign corporations are encouraged to come to Australia and take up equity in our profitable investment projects, on the ground that we have a shortage of domestic capital. If we recklessly fritter away domestic capital on such projects, we are likely to have a shortage of it forever.

Assorted pork barrelling commitments on airports, are to cost another $400m. The new Parliament House, the grand Fraser monument, is to cost, as was admitted just last week, in 1981 dollars $295m. The Commonwealth's commitment for the Burdekin Dam is to cost in 1981 dollars $121m. The Casey University, which was opposed by the parliamentary committee which studied it-the Joint Committee on Public Works-and almost certainly by a majority of Liberal Party members of parliament, is to cost $90m. The fuel storage rort, legislation for which I believe is to be introduced in the Senate tomorrow, if it achieves its objectives of inducing farmers, only, to store an emergency fuel reserve equivalent to six months consumption, will cost the country $70m.

The notorious film tax rort-the television make-up girl's economic policy which was taken over by the Prime Minister-is to impose a cost on revenue in the next financial year that is now admitted to be $30m. I hasten to add that initially the cost was given as $2m. We are told that that was the costing given by the industry. Does the Fraser Government propose to adopt the practice of accepting as the costing for any program that given by the industry which has a vested interest in it? Is the Treasury to be abolished? Is it a new government policy to cost programs on the basis of figures worked out by those who have a vested interest in them? If so, the razor gang should have sliced into the Treasury and removed about half of it. But of course that is not the policy of the Government. The fraudulent costing figure of $2m was adopted for purely political purposes before the last election so that the Prime Minister could prop up his sagging image of economic responsibility. In fact, he was committing the taxpayers to what was in its original form-I will be saying more about this subject tomorrow-an open-ended commitment for tax deferral by people who would never even had made a movie.

I refer next to the proposed $20m cost of the Boeing 707s, which represent the Prime Minister's greatest self-indulgence. The Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, the Prime Minister's ego trip, will cost $12m, not counting the postman missions on one of which Senator Carrick has left today to race around the world and try to con everybody into coming to the meeting in Melbourne. It is to be the Prime Minister's ego trip for 1981. According to recent Press reports, it will result in an additional cost of $90m in the form of foreign aid which will be the subject of a dramatic announcement by the Prime Minister at the conference. The Canberra motor race track, which hardly anyone even in Canberra wants, is to cost $2m, merely because the Prime Minister, along with other things, is a motor racing freak.

Finally, though not quantitatively important, the Liberal Party propaganda unit which operates out of Senator Carrick's office in Sydney, among other places, and is called the Government Imformation Unit, is to be expanded at a cost of half a million dollars. I have not the time to mention some 50 other pre-electoral bribes.

The second Bill before us is the Income Tax (Assessment and Rates) Amendment Bill. Its principal purpose is to complete the Government's sell-out of personal tax indexation, which the Prime Minister in 1975 and beyond had promised would end the great tax revolt. The Prime Minister then referred to unindexed tax schedules as vast, unlegislated increases in taxation, as taxation by stealth, and so on.
Sitting suspended from 1 to 2.15 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I have a table from the Sydney Morning Herald of last Thursday which I will seek leave shortly to incorporate in Hansard. Prior to the suspension of the sitting I had just moved on to the Income Tax (Assessment and Rates) Amendment Bill, the major feature of which is the final repudiation of the Prime Minister's and the Government's solemn pledges of 1975 and beyond on personal income tax indexation. Of course, we have never had indexation. Despite the promises, we have had a shonky, corrupt and perverted form of indexation manipulated by the Government to impose secret increases in taxation but to a lesser extent than it will be imposing in the future following its final repudiation of indexation.

SPEECH.PARA: One point ought to be established very clearly and that is that anything less than 100 per cent indexation-and, strictly speaking, indexation tied to wages and not the consumer price index-is, in fact, a real increase in tax. An increase in the proportion of income which will be paid in tax. The second effect of not indexing the taxation schedule is that it makes the schedule more regressive. At this stage, I seek leave to incorporate into Hansard a table prepared by Mr Collins of Macquarie University and published by the Sydney Morning Herald last week which shows that, in fact, for constant real incomes equivalent to $50,000 five years ago there has been a 3 per cent real reduction in taxation and an increase in real taxation of about one-third for the lowest income bracket. I foreshadow that I will move an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Income Tax (Assessment and Rates) Amendment Bill. I seek leave to incorporate the table in Hansard.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to some of the matters reviewed by the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee. It seems to me that Senator Walsh has, to a large extent, missed the point of this review. He may have established today that he can count, but even that is open to some doubt. As I understand it, the main purpose of the Review of Commonwealth Functions was to get a direction of government activity more consistent with Liberal Party philosophy and, as the Minister for Finance, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, said in her second reading speech, to have more room for people to make their own choices. It also sought to eliminate unnecessary costs but financial purposes were not the main function of the review.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of the decisions that have been made do, in fact, have a particular impact on the Australian Capital Territory because of the extent to which government is so involved with the Australian Capital Territory. Perhaps the real answer to some of these problems is for the economy of the Territory to seek to diversify much further so that we can establish a broader commercial base and, to as great an extent as is possible, become freed from the effect of government decisions, become insulated more from government decisions. The government in Canberra has several roles. Of course, it is a federal government. It plays the role of State government and, in many of its functions, it is also local government. The Minister, in her second reading speech, dealt with the philosophy and details of the review. I will refer to just a few of the aspects.

The Government proposes to wind up the activities of the Canberra Commercial Development Authority and to direct the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) to take such steps as are necessary to do this-in effect, to sell the Belconnen shopping mall. Much taxpayers' money is tied up in this enterprise and, in my view, it is quite inappropriate for taxpayers' money to be tied up in this way. It is not a proper function of the Commonwealth Government to be involved as a landlord in such a retail enterprise. Certainly, the position of the tenants must be taken into account, but the Minister is authorised to set the terms and conditions of the sale. I have no doubt that he will have the interests of the tenants in mind when he sets the terms and conditions upon which the mall will be sold. Money will then be released which, as I have said, is taxpayers' money and which should be more properly used by government in other ways.

The Minister for the Capital Territory will also play a role in relation to the Canberra Retail Market Trust. He may direct the Trust to enter into an agreement for sale on such terms and conditions as he specifies. These markets have grown to have a very special place in the life of Canberra. The stall holders are independent traders who have added much colour and interest to the city as well as provided a service in selling their goods. I believe it would be a great pity if this were to change. In my view the markets, ideally, should be owned by a co-operative of the stall holders at the markets, should be free and independent as a co-operative and should not be owned by one person or company. I think a co-operative should be so structured that it cannot be taken over or dominated by one person or company. I would want the integrity, individuality and character of these markets to be maintained. They can be under the terms of this Bill and in a way that the Minister can stipulate.

A part of the Government's decision in this review is to reduce the size of the Public Service. This would need to be done in a way that is not, in my view, just a flat two per cent cut. I think there needs to be a review of the staffing formulas so that both in Canberra and in places where the Commonwealth has a presence in the States the greatest efficiency can be achieved and the greatest service to those who in fact fund the Commonwealth can be obtained. It may be that in many places the staff cuts will be greatly in excess of 2 per cent. As a result of this review, there may be some areas in which the staff cuts will be extremely high. Also, there may be other places where additional staff is needed. I would urge those in the Public Service responsible for reviewing this matter to see that this is done in a way that achieves the best possible result.

From the Australian Capital Territory's point of view, perhaps the most controversial area of the Review of Commonwealth Functions which relates to the Australian Capital Territory is contained in clause 90-a perhaps deceptively short clause which deregulates shopping hours; that is, allows shopping hours to respond to the needs of shoppers. No Liberal can really make out a case for the Commonwealth Government being for regulating shopping hours. As one telephone caller said to me, the Commonwealth Government should not interfere with shopping. Many issues have been raised by those involved and not all the reasons advanced for opposing the deregulation could possibly turn out to be correct. If the unions are correct in suggesting that the prices in the big stores will rise, surely the small traders would benefit and there would also be more flexibility for consumers. Whilst, in principle, I support the Government's decision, I am mindful of the concerns of the many small traders who have contacted me and of the problems that they perceive will flow as a result of the deregulation of shopping hours. I believe that small traders provide a friendly service which most shoppers appreciate and which cannot be matched by the type of trading of the big stores these days.

Shops, of course, have several purposes. The first is to provide an income for the owner. Secondly, shops provide employment and, also, they provide a service for customers. These three aspects must be kept in mind. It is my view that a deregulation of trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory would in fact attract shoppers to Canberra from surrounding districts. It may be that with deregulation there will be a few changes. The big stores may stay open a little longer, but there will be a continuing demand for the service and convenience that a small local store can offer.

There is no doubt that for Canberra to have shops open and people about will help to make it a more interesting city and a more interesting place for tourists to be. Tourists in those circumstances would spend more money in Canberra. However, in many respects Canberra is not a normal market place. It has large shopping centres. It has been structured under a philosophy that the National Capital Development Commission has introduced of large shopping areas and small neighbourhood areas. It is not the same as the major cities where, mostly, shops are established along roads, among houses and all over the place, and are not congregated as they are in Canberra. The geography of shopping centres here is quite different. I am very concerned about some of the worries which the small business community has expressed to me over these last few days. Equally, I have had callers urging that I support the earliest possible introduction of the deregulation of trading hours. These calls have come from some small traders and consumers.

The Minister for the Capital Territory said last week that he would set up a committee to monitor the effects of deregulation. I urge him to go a little further than this and request the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory to inquire into and report on the matters relevant to the implementation of that decision. There are many other decisions throughout the Bill, all I believe consistent with the Government's philosophy of being less involved in decision making. The ones I have referred to are a few of those that are particularly relevant to the electorate which I represent. I repeat my request to the Minister for the Capital Territory that he pursue that one matter in the way I have suggested.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats have grave misgivings about not only the effects of this Bill but also the form it takes. I support the comments made by Senator Walsh when he expressed concern about the new format of introducing bulk legislation in one Bill. I say for the benefit of those people listening to the broadcast that the Senate is debating legislation which is essentially implementing some of the decisions of the so-called razor gang, but in government parlance we are debating the Commonwealth Functions (Statutes Review) Bill. The Bill which I hold in my hand contains some 18 matters relevant to the Australian Capital Territory. It covers a whole range of things from agents and architects through co-operative societies, life insurance holding companies, the Landlord and Tenant Ordinance, rabbit destruction, sewerage rates to trading hours and whatever. In addition to matters affecting the Australian Capital Territory, the Bill contains 22 other headings, among which are the Australian Postal Commission, the Australian Wool Corporation, bankruptcy, the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act, the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation and so on. The Bill enables a beleaguered government in the dying hours of a session when its own back bench supporters are desperate to get home-I do not blame them for that--
—I am not desperate. I take exception to that. I will stay as long as you like.

—If Senator Townley interjects in that way much more often we will accommodate him. We would have enjoyed his contributions late last night when we were trying to prevent the passage of one of the most awful pieces of legislation to be brought into the Senate this session. I refer to the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill. I point out, with the greatest respect to the honourable senator for whom I do have a regard, that he was conspicuous by his absence from the chamber, particularly at 10 minutes to two this morning when we were debating the final stages of the Bill. The honourable senator did not make a contribution to the debate. I repeat that this mechanism of joining the functions of 22 or 23 departments under the one Bill is a dangerous precedent. I warn the Government -I am sure I have the support of the Australian Labor Party-that such a thing will not happen after 30 June. The Government will not be able to get away with doing such a thing in this place after 30 June.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a rag bag Bill. God knows what is hidden in it that cannot be flushed out in the short time we have. If people listening to this broadcast conclude that senators are less articulate and less scintillatingly witty than usual, let me explain that the Senate sat until about 3 o'clock this morning and sat again at 10.30 a.m., 7 1/2 hours later. That seems to have been the pattern in the last several weeks. Why is this legislation being rushed through at this stage?

TALK.START.PARA: —Why indeed.
—I thank Senator Townley for his interjection. He asks why indeed. Let me give listeners to this broadcast a clue. On 12 September 1978 a well-known Australian, a leading politician, said:

SPEECH.PARA: We have said that we wanted to end for all time the deceit of a tax system which, through the process of inflation, brought larger and larger funds to the coffers of government. We said that if governments wanted more funds they should tax for them openly and plainly. I would not want to be taking more and more from the people of Australia by the hidden process of inflation, and trying to pretend that taxes had not in fact been increased.

One might wonder who made that remarkably generous and statesmanlike statement. Of course it was Malcolm Fraser who did so, on 12 September 1978. He virtually said that the abolition of tax indexation was a deceit. He said anybody who did this would be a deceitful person. The following words were spoken by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in the second reading speech on the Income Tax (Assessment and Rates) Amendment Bill:

Also dealt with is the announcement . . . that there is to be half-indexation of personal income tax for 1981-82, and that that year is to be the last year in which the system of tax indexation will apply.

That is spoken with the authority of the Prime Minister of Australia in June 1981. So in June 1981 we can afford to be deceitful. I do not think I transgress Standing Orders when I say that putting those two statements side by side proves beyond any shadow of doubt that the Prime Minister of this country is a deceitful man.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order.

—Senator, I suggest that perhaps you have transgressed Standing Orders by your last statement. Prior to that the Chair took no exception to the language. I do not think the printed words would convey the meaning you intend.
—Can I speak to the point of order?
— Certainly.

—I prefaced my remarks by saying that I did not want to transgress. I speak to the point of order. I know the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs is itching to get on his feet to speak to it too. I am not using my words. 'Deceit' is not my word. The word 'deceit' is the word of the Prime Minister of this country, Malcolm Fraser. On 12 September 1978 he said:

SPEECH.PARA: We have said that we wanted to end for all time the deceit of a tax system which, through the process of inflation, brought larger and larger funds to the coffers of government.

Then in June 1981 he said that that year, namely 1981-82, would be the last year in which the system of tax indexation would apply. The point I am making, Mr Acting Deputy President, is that in September 1978 the Prime Minister said that the abolition of tax indexation is a deceitful thing to do. Those were his words, not mine. In 1981, he does it. I think sheer logic would force one to conclude that the person who made that statement or who authorised it is a deceitful man, but I would bow to your ruling in a flash, as you know, Mr Acting Deputy President.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Chipp. I accept what he says. He is a hard debater but has always shown respect in the chamber. I am pleased that he has seen fit to follow my suggestion. I call Senator Chipp.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I leave that subject to move on to other matters. I shall deal with why this legislation is being introduced now. Again, listeners to this broadcast might wonder: Why introduce, on the second last day of the sitting, a Bill covering 23 or 24 matters that affect different departments? Why bring it on when we met until 3 o'clock this morning and when, without a shadow of a doubt, we will meet until 3 o'clock or 4 o'clock tomorrow morning? Again, I hope I do not transgress the Standing Orders, Mr Acting Deputy President, but there was a party which did extraordinarily well at the last election on the slogan 'keep the bastards honest'. This legislation is an example of absolute deception and dishonesty. Mr Fraser knows that if this Bill, which breaks the promise made in regard to tax indexation, were to be introduced on 18 August or thereafter when the Government will not have control of the Senate, there is no way in the world that it would pass this Senate. That is the reason for its being before the Senate today. It affects 24 or 25 departments. That is why the galleries are jampacked with public servants advising the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume), who is at the table, on the 24 or 25 components of this Bill. I look forward with great anticipation to sitting in this place knowing that the Government cannot ram legislation connected with broken promises through the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Without making a great point of it, one might well ask in passing: Why do all senators on the Government back benches sit by and allow a promise made so overtly and in unmistakable language to maintain tax indexation to be broken? Why do they sit there now and allow this Bill to be passed without raising a voice in anger or in protest? It is not a small matter. Every person in Australia who earns income will be affected by this broken promise. The Labor Party and the Australian Democrats at this stage can do absolutely nothing about the situation. We will be swamped by the sheer weight of voting numbers. Government back bench senators have been told how to vote and to support this particular broken promise. One hopes that they can live happily with that situation.
In relation to the razor gang itself, I point to the blatant incongruity in the Prime Minister's opening remarks when he introduced the razor gang functions. He said:
The Review's starting point is that Australia's greatest asset is the Australian people . . . exercising their abilities, their skills, their imagination and their enterprise.

One of the things that leap out of the recommendations of the razor gang is the attempt to reintroduce fees for university courses for second degrees. The razor gang seemed to have inordinate pleasure in disadvantaging students and making life harder for them. Yet that situation sits rather unhappily with the Prime Minister's opening statement that our greatest asset is the Australian people, with their abilities and skills. On the question of education, which is not subject to this Bill, I mention in passing what the Government has done to the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme. It will make it even more difficult for tertiary students to undertake their education by reintroducing tertiary tuition fees. Whilst the Democrats do not encourage the concept of lifetime professional students, we disagree with a reintroduction of fees for second degree and post-graduate students. The rationalisation of councils of adult education is something that the Democrats would support, but not with the incredibly stupid haste with which the razor gang has recommended that it proceed.

In talking about incongruities, I would have thought that the thoughts of Senator Reid, who spoke before me and who represents the Australian Capital Territory, and my thoughts about the deregulation of trading hours would not be terribly different. I am unhappy to say that she will vote for the deregulation of shop trading hours. I, as a Democrat, will vote against deregulation. Like her, I share the concern of small shopkeepers. I share the worry of the consumers of Canberra. The prices they have to pay will undoubtedly increase as a result of this move. Like her I share the concern of shop employees who, if experience elsewhere proves correct here, will face casualisation of their industry and unemployment. But I, unlike Senator Reid, will vote against deregulation of shopping hours, not only for the reasons pertinent to Canberra but also because I believe that it will be the thin end of the wedge of something that will spread to other capital cities and other States. Make no mistake; the kind of lobby that is pushing for unlimited trading hours is that of big business and the American-owned retailers which can afford to operate for long hours, in the process driving the smaller traders out of business.

In conclusion, I ask: Why on earth is the Australian Wool Testing Authority, an independent, impartial, highly efficient body, being sold to the private sector? I even listened to Senator Walsh, who normally emits a great deal of wisdom about these things, to find a reason. I have not been given a good reason by the Government. I do not think that Senator Walsh has found a good reason for the Government's action or can even imagine one. It is the most stupid decision. I think I have received more correspondence and protests about this decision than I have received about any other decision for some time. I notice at least a habit that I am happy to see is growing in the House of Representatives. Two more members of the Liberal Party-Messrs Bungey and Burr-crossed the floor to vote against the measure. This is one of a number of cases in which the Government is pursuing a wrong-headed and counter-productive approach. I wish to quote from a telegram received from the Livestock and Grain Producers Association of New South Wales. I would have thought that it was hardly a rampant group of socialists.

TALK.START.PARA: —Probably Democrats, Senator.

—They are quite possibly Democrats. However, I would have thought from my past experience that there would be a fair smattering of hard-nosed tories among the members of that organisation. However, let us settle on the fact that they are not rampant communists or socialists.
—They are not even pink, Senator.
—A good colour; I read the letter:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's justification for the 'razor gang' cuts appears to be based on the premise that the user must pay. In the case of AWTA this premise is not valid as the user does pay.

In fact, the Government does not provide one cent in direct cash handouts to AWTA. At the same time, AWTA has been able to make profits over the last five years of about $1m per annum and hold its charges at about the 1970 level.
The reason for disposing of AWTA had to change and Mr Nixon has said that 'there is no longer a requirement for the Authority to have a link with the Government'.
It goes on:

This 'link' provides the very basis of the wool industry's marketing system. All sectors of the industry have very strongly opposed the Government's present proposal. These objections are best summarised by the International Wool Textile Organisation.
Members of IWTO are strongly of the view that in its unique function between sellers and buyers, AWTA must be, and be seen to be, an official, independent and impartial body.

Mr Nixon has further stated 'that the fundamental aim is to ensure that AWTA continues in precisely the same way as it does already'. 'We will establish a foundation' says Mr Nixon 'which will be designed by the industry itself.'
One thinks that the industry has already designed its own 'foundation' and that it already exists-namely AWTA.

No real argument has been put up by the Government as to why it is necessary to dispose of AWTA. This is particularly disturbing when there is the slightest possibility of doing damage to Australia's wool marketing system.

As woolgrowers, we are extremely concerned with the Government's proposal to dispose of AWTA. This concern has been conveyed to the Prime Minister by a large number of our members, apparently to no avail.

I ask the question once more: Why is it necessary to sell this independent and efficient enterprise to the private sector? I know that the Senate is pushed for time, hence I am about to conclude my remarks 11 minutes earlier than I need. Notwithstanding that, I appeal to one Government senator to get up here for five minutes or three minutes and explain why he will put his bottom on a seat on that side of the chamber when the division bells ring and honourable senators will be asked to support the Government on this measure. I do not think that that is an unreasonable request for a senator to make of a colleague. I ask one Liberal senator: Why is he supporting the Government in the selling of the Australian Wool Testing Authority?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over a period of weeks now we have been through the saga-if I could call it that-of the razor gang report but the Commonwealth Functions (Statutes Review) Bill 1981 gives legislative effect to some of the decisions of that body. I refer to one or two matters arising from the legislation and from questions which I would like to raise in the Senate today and which I have pursued since the report of the razor gang. Any honourable senator speaking in this place can set out a list, as Senator Chipp did, of extraordinarily bizarre decisions which were made by that group referring to measures which will, in fact, cost more than they will save, measures which will reduce the amount of information available to the Australian community and measures which will obstruct the machinery of government. Of course the worst thing about the razor gang report is that it is not what it purports to be. It is not an examination of the functions of government. It is an examination conducted on the basis of a cost cutting exercise irrespective of the functions of government and the functions of particular government departments. In that sense it is something of a travesty of government accountability because nowhere are we given any detailed reasons for the decisions which have been made.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chipp referred to bodies such as the Curriculum Development Centre and the decisions in relation to student fees and so on. Many more examples of that kind have been given in the Senate. We are handed a total figure which we are told is the saving from the razor gang report. There are no sums in terms of arithmetic and no balance sheet in terms of the functions of government. It is a very marked contrast to the extensive volumes of the Coombs report which one suspects has not been dipped into by this government since then. Since the review was handed down I have tried to find the answer to a number of questions, apart from the ones that we have asked in the chamber, which ought to have been supplied when this statement was first made. Some answers have been informative. They have revealed serious doubts about the Government's fitness to run a corner shop in relation to some of these matters, let alone the affairs of the country. For example, I asked: How would the abolition of the Nature Conservation Advisory Committee save money? The answer I received from the Minister was:
There are no significant savings as fees were not paid to committee members.

That body was abolished as part of a cost saving exercise. It was a committee which gave its services free to the Government. This is all done in the name of cost cutting. Other answers which I received reveal the poverty of the Government's decision making and the fact that it has nothing whatsoever to do with efficiency. For example, I will quote a further answer which states:

The Commonwealth Council for Rural Research and Extension in its annual report for 1979-80 says that: 'In principle, public resources should be devoted to research and extension to a level where the expected benefit of the last project funded is equal to the opportunity cost, that is the return if used in alternative investment.'

Since we are talking about competing philosophies that is the sort of principle upon which we argue a government should base its decisions. A very pertinent question to ask rhetorically is whether the Minister who gave that answer has considered whether that principle has been applied in abolishing that body, the Council for Rural Research and Extension. The answer is clearly no. It was not acting on that principle of government. The most disgraceful answer that I have received, in answer to questions, comes from the Treasurer (Mr Howard) regarding the abolition of various statistical collections. What I wanted to be convinced about, as a member of this Parliament, was the reasons and evidence given for each of those decisions being correct, namely that they were responsible Government conduct. I did not receive any argument, any evidence or anything for which I had specifically asked in the question relating to the figures compiled by the Australian Bureau of Statistics and the discontinuance of those functions as a result of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, the so-called razor gang. What I sought was information about why a number of sets of statistics were being abolished and what assurances could be given that none of the groups which were affected by the abolition of those statistics would be disadvantaged by the lack of information. The question went to one and a half pages and the answer given by the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) was as follows:
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(1) to (10) The collections referred to are considered to be of low priority and are being discontinued in order to reduce the costs incurred by the Australian Bureau of Statistics and by those who supply the information to the Bureau.

I hazard a guess that it is only the Fraser Government, which purports to govern in what might euphemistically be called a modern democracy, which can arrive at decisions of importance relating to government without the benefit of statistics. I mention one case. One of the so-called big issues in this Parliament-insofar as there are big issues in this Parliament-is the question of how to handle the resources boom which was part of the pre-election advertising, if I can call it that, of the Government parties and which has since become a matter of relatively serious discussion in the Parliament. One of the essential tools, one would have thought, for handling the resources boom in the context of the current problems of Australian manufacturing industry and unemployment would be information about unemployment in regional areas of Australia. That information will no longer be available. I raise the matter again today because as a Victorian senator the fact that that information will no longer be available is of the utmost concern to people in the provincial cities of Victoria at Ballarat, Bendigo and Geelong. Those three cities can be duplicated across Australia in terms of the importance of the information on regional employment figures in those areas.

But one would have thought that any government, even the Fraser Government with the touch of magic which it seems to have of 'now you see it, now you don't' in terms of its stated philosophies and its actions, would have needed this sort of information and material if it intended to do anything about handling this matter in an appropriate way in terms of distribution of resources and job opportunities throughout Australia. The unemployment statistics for provincial regions in this country will simply no longer be available. From the answer which I received I would single out that matter as being of the utmost concern. I inform the Minister that I have a commitment to pursue this matter on behalf of the people in those provincial country towns who are represented through their councils and I will continue to do so because it is an absurd neglect of their long term interest that those figures will no longer be available.

The other matter with which I want to deal relates to Part III of the legislation which deals with Australia Post. In the original razor gang report, there appeared this sentence: 'Australia Post Courier service to be abolished'. After a while it was clear from public pronouncements by Australia Post and by the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) that the announcement should have read 'Australia Post Courier vans to be repainted and to be forbidden to carry double beds, elephants and things of that kind'-large items of cargo, for want of a better word. That was the position as at a fortnight ago. Australia Post effectively was to be renamed and to be forbidden to carry large items of furniture and so on. That was done, let me hazard a calculated guess, at the instigation of companies like Thomas Nationwide Transport Ltd which have been diligent in their pursuit of government work. The whole of the TNT complex has been diligent in the pursuit of government work whether it be in relation to Telecom, the airlines, film production or whatever. But, in relation to the Australia Post Courier service, there is no doubt that heavy representations were made by companies such as that in connection with the work done by that service.

I just want to make the point that it now appears that a large number of drivers employed by this service are likely to lose their jobs. What happened was that the razor gang made that benign sort of statement which was interpreted as meaning that the name of the service was to be changed and there was to be a slight alteration to its functions. Australia Post then put out a circular stating that the courier services would be operating as usual subject to these slight changes. That seems to have annoyed the Government. It now appears that many more major changes will be made. I just remind the Senate that about one-quarter of the business of the Australia Post Courier service is for the Commonwealth Employment Service. The Courier service takes notices to the doors of unemployed persons-various documents for the CES such as claim forms and so on. All these tasks have upgraded the CES work. It is very interesting to note that it has been demonstrated by the CES as a result of seeking quotations from rivals that the Australia Post Courier service has been able to provide these services more efficiently and more cheaply than private enterprise would have been able to do.

The Australia Post Courier service operates profitably. Its sin is not one of loss making. It is an efficient organisation. Its offence is to have competed efficiently and successfully with private operators. I make the point again, again and again and I will continue to make it as other honourable senators on this side of the Parliament will continue to make it also that the Australia Post Courier service provides a provincial service, a country service, as well as an intra-city service. Very few private operators are interested in taking on country services or provincial services of one kind or another which have been handled by Australia Post. Australia Post provides a service to rural areas, combining mail deliveries with other courier services. The result of cutting Australia Post out of that courier market will inevitably be that those services will decline in quality. The private operators do not make profits out of country runs.

I again come to the question which we have debated here on several occasions in the last few weeks, that is, the simple question of what is the function of a public service. Let us look at instrumentalities such as Australia Post, Telecom, Trans-Australia Airlines and so on. Trans-Australia Airlines runs services to the north of Tasmania and the outback areas of Queensland which no private operator would take on. The first reaction of the chairman of TAA when he heard the airline was going to be sold was: 'Good, we will not have to run those unprofitable Fokker services to outback Queensland any more'. That remark drew a slow roar of pain from the members of the National Country Party who have all the qualities of the dinosaur; that is, if one sticks a pin in the tail the message takes a week to reach the brain. When this information in relation to TAA reached the brain of the National Country Party, there was a slow roar of pain and some of its members expressed concern about it.

The same thing happened in respect of Telecom. The proprietors of a number of large companies in Australia have been looking at the work of Telecom with greedy eyes. Why? The reason is that Telecom is a profitable government instrumentality and a very successful government instrumentality. It is the only organisation in Australia which, if I might say so, has not increased its prices since 1975. No corner-store or emporium in the private sector can make that claim.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has in fact reduced them in some areas.

—In country areas, that is right. The only organisation which has not increased its prices since 1975 is attracting the attention of entrepeneurs who want to take over its most profitable work. They are not concerned about taking over the $214m, I think it was, which Telcom appropriated last year to subsidise the country telephone network. Exactly the same sort of remark can be made about many public instrumentalities which have received the benefits of the so-called razor gang attention-this committee of hard-headed businessmen, I do not think-which looked at these matters. The same, of course, can be said, as I mentioned, about the Australia Post Courier service. Precisely the same sort of argument applies.

SPEECH.PARA: I just touch on those two matters which again are examples of the stupidity of this committee in terms of not looking at government functions from the point of view of efficiency, not looking at government functions from the point of view of the function of government in relation to the delivery of services to the Australian people, but looking at it in a totally ideological way as part of a political stunt which the razor gang is. For those reasons, the Opposition opposes this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this matter basically, I suggest, for one reason. My opinion is that the results of the efforts of the razor gang will hit hardest of all the third largest provincial city in Victoria, namely, Bendigo which has a population of some 64,000. Bendigo will possibly lose its ordnance factory and it will definitely lose its engineering faculty at the Bendigo College of Advanced Education. I believe that the Fraser Government will rue the day when it introduced that aspect of the report that relates to Bendigo because the Liberal Party--
—Bourchier certainly will.

—Particularly Mr Bourchier. Certainly the Labor Party is very much aware that Mr Bourchier holds the seat of Bendigo by a very slender thread-some 1 1/2 per cent. As a result of the report, some 650 jobs are in jeopardy at the ordnance factory. If one multiplies that by whatever the factor might be to estimate the voting strength of those people, I suggest that the Liberal Party can forget Bendigo as a winnable seat at the next election. This action is a shameful display of blatant politics by a Government that for years has pretended that it cares about country people, that it knows what goes on in the countryside, that it cares about students and is hell bent, in talk anyhow, on a resources boom.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer firstly to the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. Last week in this Parliament we were visited by a delegation of some 15 or 16 citizens from Bendigo and its environs. The delegation comprised representatives of the City Council itself and adjacent shire councils, people from the college and workers at the Bendigo Ordnance Factory-a variety of people who were concerned about their future and the future of the city of Bendigo. I have some sort of personal relationship with that city. It is 39 years since I formed that relationship with the city of Bendigo. It is an ongoing relationship and to me Bendigo is, I suppose, a second home. I know what makes the heart of Bendigo tick and one of those ticks is the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. It seems that the decision by the Government to do away with the Bendigo Ordnance Factory came about as a result of the Eltringham report. Yet when the delegates from Bendigo spoke to Sir Phillip Lynch some time back and sought a copy of the Eltringham report, they were told that it was confidential. So much for open government, Fraser style! To my mind, there is no reason why the Government should not have been prepared to produce the Eltringham report to show the people of Bendigo why the Government had made this decision; but the Government has not been prepared to do that.
We all realise that we are in the straight of this session and, as a result, the whips are out. I have been told that if I speak for more than 10 minutes some people will not buy me a beer tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or ever.

—Someone said 'or ever'. That may be a godsend. I think it is pertinent to note some of the factors concerning the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. The factory was established in 1941 as a manufacturing support for the Armed Services during World War II. During that period it was engaged in the manufacture and reconditioning of six-inch and eight-inch naval guns, the manufacture of four-inch gun mountings for merchant ships, torpedo air vessels and a wide variety of equipment for the Army. In the post-war reconstruction period, the factory played a major role in the building of weapons such as propulsion machinery for the Australian built Battle and Daring class destroyers and Type 12 frigates. The manufacture of 4.5 twin RP.41 Mark 6 gun mountings and propulsion gearboxes for the vessels was a major contribution to the Royal Australian Navy's modernisation program. There is a list of the achievements of that establishment set out in this paper which I will seek leave to incorporate later.

SPEECH.PARA: In order to get the message across without taking up too much time I will just say that, aside from the defence work this establishment has conducted since 1941, it has also been responsible for a large amount of work in private enterprise. Anybody who was privileged to go through that establishment can only be proud of the establishment itself and of the management, the workers and the staff generally. One should also point out that one of its other great contributions to engineering in Australia is the fact that at present the establishment has on staff some 120 apprentices. I suggest that if this establishment is passed over to private enterprise, many of those apprentices can forget that they ever belonged to the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. The ratio of apprentices to tradesmen will drop rather alarmingly. One is also concerned, if the establishment is passed over to private enterprise, about what will happen to some of the equipment in the factory. Only in recent years has there been installed in that factory one of the most modern lathes in Australia, perhaps in the southern hemisphere. What will happen if the private entrepreneur who purchases the place strips that away from the plant and takes it elsewhere? It must surely detract from the employment opportunities and the capabilities of that establishment.

Just to show the sorts of double standards of this Government and, in particular, one of its members that we are all immune to by now-but it does rankle some of us-I quote from the Bendigo Advertiser of 25 September 1980, which, one will recall, was just prior to the last federal election. An article in that newspaper states:
About $9 million was likely to be spent at the Bendigo Ordnance Factory between 1981 and 1985, according to the Federal Member for Bendigo, Mr John Bourchier.
Planning within the Department of Productivity would ensure that the Ordnance Factory would have an increasing role in Australia's overall defence preparedness, he said.

I will not go on to quote the rest of the article but, as I said, it just goes to show the double standards of this Government and at least one of its members-promising the world to the Ordnance Factory and to the citizens of Bendigo. They did so just two or three weeks prior to the last federal election, yet within six months, the same member, Mr Bourchier, was prepared to allow that establishment in Bendigo to be taken apart by private enterprise and any work that the Government may like to do will have to be sent to another defence establishment at Maribyrnong. That is another matter concerning which I would like to incorporate information later in my speech.

It is interesting to note, while this Government is doing this, the words of Sir Laurence Hartnett, one of the great Australians. I suppose there are a lot of great Australians but surely one of them would be Sir Laurence Hartnett. He is one of those men who were thrown into the breach in the dark days of the late 1930s and the early 1940s when this country was threatened. In the June 1981 edition of the Pacific Defence Reporter, Sir Laurence Hartnett makes one or two very pertinent points. Again, in the interests of time, I will not read the whole article, but he said:
Apparently we in Australia cannot learn a lesson-to which I refer our experience in the last war when our ability to produce a wide range of armaments and military equipment saved the day for us.
He goes on to point out:

Prior to Pearl Harbor, Australia had been at war for two years. The United States vigorous neutrality even prevented transmission of mail through the States if such mail dealt with armaments and, in particular, drawings of such armaments.
Ball and roller bearings nearly brought us to a halt, but we quietly set up manufacturers.

So he goes on. The portent of his letter is that we were caught once with our pants down and that as a result we established a perfectly viable defence establishment in a provincial city in Victoria. This Government is now prepared to do away with it. I note also that in this letter Sir Laurence Hartnett said:
I fully concur and fully support Sir Keith Shann in his article, 'Build Our Defences and Hang the Cost' in the April issue of Pacific Defence Reporter.

We have a Prime Minister who has talked continually about the threat to this country, about the alleged presence of Soviet vessels in the Indian Ocean and about the downward thrust of Chinese communism or some other form of communism.
