That man has preached that dogma ever since I have known him; yet he is prepared to get rid of one of the finest defence establishments in this country. It does not ring true. Like so much else of Malcolm Fraser's character, there is a hollow ring somewhere. He says one thing but he does another.

I now refer rather briefly to the loss in the same city of the engineering faculty at the Bendigo College of Advanced Education. Whilst the Government was doing this, I was very interested to read in the Melbourne Age of last Monday, under the heading 'Monday Job Market', an article entitled 'Plenty of jobs for graduates in engineering'. The article, which quotes the Dean of Engineering at Monash University, states:
More than 10,000 well paid positions will go to overseas job seekers unless Australians come forward, according to the Dean of Engineering at Monash University, Professor Lance Endersbee.

Professor Endersbee said there would be a great demand for engineers in Australia during the next few years, and if young people continued to ignore the profession local and overseas companies would recruit elsewhere for jobs that often started a graduate on about $25,000 a year.

That is another article that I will seek leave later to have incorporated in Hansard. This Government has always loudly proclaimed, particularly around election time, its great support for people in rural areas. I fail to understand why such a government, making that sort of proclamation, would want to do away with a perfectly viable engineering institute in a provincial city, an institute which is available to students of engineering from the whole of the north and the north-west of Victoria-from Shepparton, Echuca, Swan Hill, Mildura-all the Mallee. This faculty provides an opening for those students. What are Mr Lloyd and Mr Fisher thinking at the moment? By supporting this sort of legislation, they are denying the sons and I suggest one or two daughters in their own electorates-I do not know whether the female gender is involved in engineering these days; there is no reason why it could not be, in my view-engineering educational opportunities. They, being representatives of country areas, would well know the cost in fares and accommodation to which they would put the parents of any future engineering students in that region of Victoria. It seems to me that future students who might once have gone to the Bendigo institute will have to go to Melbourne. One can only hope that the supporters of the National Country Party and the Liberal Party in that region will do a little deep thinking about this and realise that by the deletion of these establishments in Bendigo the Government has done a great deal of harm not only to the present generation of workers and citizens in that fair city but also to future generations.

I have spoken longer than my Whip suggested I should. Finally, I shall quote a letter which I received from a man who served for many years as a faithful member of the National Country Party in western Victoria and who, because of some double dealing and chicanery in that party three or four years ago, opted out and is probably now voting Labor or, if not, is politically neutral. It is a letter dated 31 May that he wrote to the Prime Minister. Of course, living in that part of Victoria he knows the Prime Minister fairly well; so he addressed the letter 'Dear Malcolm'. It states:

As our Member for Wannon, your Government's decision to practise economies deserves some commendation, although its belated implementation and your Cabinet's confusion of priorities do not, when applied to the wool industry.

With other woolgrowers in your electorate, I object strongly to the proposed sale of the Australian Wool Testing Authority to private interests. Such a decision is stupid and foolish and is contrary to all sections of the wool industry and trade. e.g.
(1) It runs at a profit.
(2) Two commercial firms at wooltesting have failed during the past 15 years.
(3) At present, the AWTA has served the wool industry faithfully and well, and is a key part of a reputable marketing system accepted by overseas trade.
(4) It is funded by Australian woolgrowers, is commercially viable, and costs the Government nothing.

In view of these facts, you would be well advised to reverse the decision of the proposed sale of A.W.T.A. Forget the cosmetic face saving antics of the Ministers concerned, and make a statesmanlike decision to leave it as it is. I trust and pray that commonsense will prevail.
I am, Yours sincerely, LIN CAMERON

Of course, anyone who trusts the present Prime Minister would pray forever and it would not matter a continental damn. I will leave the matter at that. I believe, as I said originally, that the Government will not hold the seat of Bendigo after the next Federal election. That is patently clear. These cuts are a very regrettable move. They will do a great deal of damage to hundreds and perhaps thousands of people in that central northern area of Victoria. They are a crying shame. I guess any Australian who, from this day on, falls for any of the propaganda that the Liberal Party puts out about decentralisation and caring for country people is nothing more than a fool. Mr President, I seek leave to have those documents that I mentioned incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
BRIEF HISTORY AND STATUS OF THE ORDNANCE FACTORY, BENDIGO

The Ordnance Factory, Bendigo, is part of the Commonwealth Department of Industry and Commerce, an Australian Government owned and operated manufacturing establishment, engaged in the manufacture of capital equipment for the Army, Navy, Air Force, and Commercial Industry, as and when required.
It may be regarded as a well equipped general engineering plant.

The Factory was established in 1941 as a manufacturing support for the Armed Services during World War II, and during that period was engaged in the manufacture and reconditioning of 6 inch and 8 inch Naval Guns, manufacture of 4 inch gun mountings for merchant ships, torpedo air vessels, and a wide variety of equipment for the Army.

In the post war reconstruction period, the Factory played a major role in the building of weapons and propulsion machinery for the Australian built Battle and Daring Class Destroyers and Type 12 Frigates.
The manufacture of 4.5 inch Twin RP.41 Mk 6 and 6* Gun Mountings and Propulsion Gearboxes for the vessels were major contributions to the Royal Australian Navy's modernisation program.

Other major service programs undertaken included the manufacture of 120mm Recoilless Anti-Tank Guns, overhaul of Tanks for the Army, refurbishment and modernisation of Anti-submarine Mortars, Torpedo Tube Mountings, Bofors Twin Gun Mountings, 4.5 inch Twin Gun Mountings, etc. for the Navy.
In-situ major overhaul of ships' propulsion machinery is also undertaken.
O.F.B. played a major role in the manufacture of the Ikara Missile Handling System.
Spares requirements for the Services are regularly produced, including the manufacture of a variety of medium calibre gun barrels.

In recent years, Service type work has included the manufacture of ships' propeller shafting, controllable pitch propeller hubs, 500 lb Bombs, 7.62mm Ammunition Links and Charger Clips, F.111 Aircraft Tooling, Trailers, etc.
Since 1946, a large variety of Commercial and Government Instrumentality work has been undertaken covering the light, medium and heavy engineering fields.

Typical major achievements include: 500 ton Steelworks Ladle Cranes, Gearboxes for a variety of applications, Valves, Hoists and Gates for hydro-electrical schemes; Cement Kilns; Ball, Rod, and Autogenous Mills, Mine Winders; Bridge Girders; Pressure Vessels; Steel Tubes for Off-shore Oil Drilling Rigs; Carpet Making Machinery, equipments for the Oil Refining and Aluminium Industries, Motor Car Body Framing Gates for the Automobile Industry, Ships' Propeller Shafting, Marine Diesel Engine Components, Steel Rolling Mill Tables, Conveyors, Freight Containers, Hammer Mills, Tractor Components, Presses, Bucket Wheel Dredger Crawlers and Components, and a host of other things too numerous to mention.

O.F.B. has a separately managed Quality Assurance Department, independent of manufacturing, which is approved to Level 2, equivalent to Australian Standards 1821-1823-1975, Department of Defence (US) Mil Standard 1-45208A, and Ministry of Defence (U.K.) DEF-STAN-05-24.
Delegation of Inspection is granted to O.F. Bendigo by Defence (Army) and Defence (Navy).
Surveillance inspection is performed by resident Service Inspectorates.
The Quality Assurance Department offers excellent protection to non-service customers.
The integrity of measuring equipment is assured by the NATA approved Metrology Department.

Material control and welding process control is assured by a NATA approved Metallurgical and Chemical Laboratory, which is staffed by qualified professional officers. All methods on non-destructive testing are available.
General
Bendigo is a provincial city located approximately 100 miles from Melbourne in the State of Victoria.
The present population of Bendigo is 64,560.

During the historical days of the Bendigo Gold Rush, the place where the Factory now stands was the site of a Chinese community camp which in the late 1930s was substantially levelled off for the construction of a proposed aerodrome. The sole relic of the past is a Chinese Joss House near the main entrance to the Factory-the Joss House has been restored to much of its former splendour by the National Trust and now attracts a large number of tourists.
The Factory has a total area of 91 acres (30.4 Hectares) of land and, in all, the buildings which provide work-shop, store, and office space cover 12 acres (39,722 square metres).
The employment level is generally around the 650 mark. It will be appreciated that the Factory makes a substantial contribution towards the stability of the economy of the Bendigo District.
The workforce is particularly stable.

The Factory employs people in a wide variety of categories such as professional engineers, industrial chemists, metallurgists, draftsmen, technical officers and assistants, accountants, clerks, typists, accounting machinists, data processing operators, foremen, tradesmen, riggers, cooks, storemen, boiler attendants, gardeners, cleaners, crane drivers, truckdrivers and labourers.

The Factory has a continuing need for highly skilled tradesmen, and to satisfy this need relies mainly on training its own apprentices to the high standard of workmanship required. We take 20 to 30 apprentices each year, the majority of whom enter the trade of Fitting and Machining.

The trades of Fitting and Machining, Toolmaking, Boilermaking-Welding, Electrical Fitting, Electrical Mechanic, Carpentry and Joining, Signwriting, Heat Treatment, Patternmaking, and Sheet Metal Working are taught by experienced instructors under ideal workshop conditions. Initially, the training begins in the Apprentice Training Section and there lads are taught the basics of their trade, as well as safe working habits. As their training advances, the apprentices gain experience in each section of the production shops associated with their trade.

Opportunities exist for tradesmen with skill and ambition to progress to higher trade positions, such as inspectors who check the work of other tradesmen, and also to foremen and technical staff positions. Exceptional tradesmen can even advance to professional engineering positions by undertaking and completing diploma courses at the Bendigo Institute of Technology or other Institutes.

Whatever spare manufacturing capacity is available is devoted to making all kinds of products for commercial enterprises, and it is a matter of record that major equipments made at Ordnance Factory, Bendigo, are operating large industrial installations in nearly every state in Australia and overseas.

The principal material used in fabrication and machining work here is steel, almost all of which is Australian made, although in recent years more and more specialised non-ferrous materials are being used. Only minor quantities of special materials for which no Australian capacity exists are imported from overseas.
We consider that the Factory as equipped today is among the most modern engineering factories in Australia.
ASSESSMENT OF THE ECONOMIC CONTRIBUTION OF THE BENDIGO ORDNANCE FACTORY TO THE BENDIGO COMMUNITY
The Present Status of the Factory

The factory, a part of the Commonwealth Department of Industry and Commerce, manufactures a wide range of capital equipment for Australia's defence forces whilst also providing a number of services to the private enterprise industrial sector. The plant is the largest individual engineering works in the region and plays a vital role in maintaining the economic well-being of the Bendigo community. The following analysis attempts to summarise the influence of the factory upon the local economy.
(i) Relative importance
Population of BendigoOrdnance factory employment64,560650

In a country community the continued well-being of an installation of this size represents a crucial factor in community confidence as applied to the economic future. Since the Ordnance workforce represents 2.8 per cent of the total district workforce of 23,144 persons, the maintenance of productive activity at the current level has a variety of implications upon the local economy.
(ii) Employment/the work force

The work force at the plant has, over a long period, gradually been forged into a large pool of skilled personnel, a situation which the present crisis threatens. Should the Federal Government proceed with its stated policy of selling the factory to private enterprise the interim period of negotiation has the potential to exert a detrimental influence upon the factory.

One reason why skilled personnel are attracted to an organisation like the Ordnance applies to the 'attractive' working conditions (especially in terms of continuity of employment) usually associated with government employment. Questions which require answers in this regard include:

(a) If the sale goes ahead now can the Government guarantee to a prospective purchaser(s) that one of the major resources, the skilled work force, will still be there when the takeover is complete? Surely the highly skilled, the experienced, the qualified staff members, in a period of uncertainty will react by seeking out, and moving into, employment opportunities elsewhere?

(b) What provision is to be made for accrued benefits relating to the existing work force? Will a private enterprise employer be allowed to register his employees with the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme? If not, do all employees, regardless of age, stage of health, have to buy their way into some new scheme, if available?
(c) Will existing accrued long service leave, sick pay be transferrable into the private enterprise situations?
(iii) Wages and salaries

Currently, the wage and salary bill paid to Ordnance employees amounts to $8.9m per annum. On the basis of our own analysis and Victorian government research on this topic we believe that the net impact of such a wage bill is best explained by multiplier analysis.

Economic multipliers provide an approximate indication of the ultimate increase (or decrease) in income (or whatever is being analysed) as a result of a given input. In this instance we estimate that a multiplier of 1.5 is reasonable, that an extra 50c income is generated through the community as a result of the expenditure of $1 in income in wages paid to Ordnance workers. After deducting 20 per cent of the wage bill in taxes paid by Ordnance personnel the 1.5 multiplier would indicate that the factory creates an income flow within the region of at least $13.4m per year.
(iv) Supplies

Although accurate data is not available it is worth mentioning that an additional income flow arises out of the value of supplies purchased within the region by the Ordnance. It is estimated that $150,000 is spent annually in the local economy. To this extent every dollar spent on supplies should also be multiplied by 1.5 and added to the aforementioned estimate of the income flow representing $225,000 annually.
(v) Employment

Bendigo region is currently one of Australia's higher unemployment areas-any downturn in activity at the Ordnance has the potential to accentuate the problem (or alternatively, any increase, which is not an impossibility) will alleviate it.
Using multiplier analysis again, every job lost will have the influence, within the region, of reducing employment opportunities by an additional .5 of a job.
(vi) Population

Based upon a population multiplier of 3.2 times employment (i.e. if one worker is influenced by this decision, an additional 2.2 people, his dependants, will also be involved) the closure of a factory of this size has the potential to influence 2,080 people. Since the Ordnance Factory work force tends to be a relatively young one this multiplier figure (since it relates to the entire State) probably represents an understatement.
Other influences upon the surrounding community which relate to Ordnance Factory activity but which we have not been able to quantify relate to:
1. The effect upon those firms which have work done there if the service was not available-their costs would increase.
2. If a large number of people were forced out of employment this would reduce government tax revenues while increasing welfare payments-an increase in government expenditures?

3. Defence related work, if continued at the Ordnance Factory under private enterprise, would cost the taxpayer more than is currently charged and so would result in an increase in Australia's defence expenditures.
4. The Ordnance Factory plays a decisive role in apprenticeship programs-would a private employer be as co-operative? A major point in a city with a severe youth unemployment problem.

5. The factory also does work for State government instrumentalities-would private enterprise be prepared to do such work at similar costs? If not, would it increase State Government expenditures if the Ordnance Factory's current facilities were unavailable?
BRIEF HISTORY AND STATUS OF THE ENGINEERING FACULTY AT THE BENDIGO COLLEGE OF ADVANCED EDUCATION

1. Engineering courses in Bendigo date back to the early days of the Bendigo School of Mines & Industries, which was founded in 1873 and was one of the first institutions in Victoria to produce professional engineers.

2. Professional engineering courses developed rapidly after the School of Mines and Industries became the Bendigo Institute of Technology in the late 60's and early 70's, reaching a peak of 174 students in 1973 with a first year intake of 69 students. Engineering was the strongest school in the Bendigo Institute of Technology and was the first to be accommodated in new buildings on the Edwards Road campus. There were absolutely no doubts about its economic viability at that time.

3. Following the upsurge of unemployment in 1974-75, which had a significant effect on employment opportunities for engineers, there was a drop in engineering enrolments throughout Victoria in 1976. This drop was especially marked in Bendigo where it seemed to be combined with a statistical fluctuation to give a new intake of only 23 students.

4. In 1977 the Victorian Government set up a Committee of Enquiry into Post-Secondary Education under the Chairmanship of Professor Partridge. The Partridge Committee in turn appointed a sub-committee to look specifically at engineering, under the Chairmanship of Mr S. F. Newman. This sub-committee became responsible for the production of Chapter 5 of the Partridge Committee's Report on Engineering Education and Training. Although the Engineering Sub-committee of the Partridge Committee claims in an appendix to Chapter 5 of the Report that 'the Chairman and other members' visited the Bendigo 'Institute' of Advanced Education, amongst other institutions, in carrying out its investigations, this claim is, to say the least, misleading. The only member of the Engineering Sub-committee to visit Bendigo was the Chairman, Mr S. F. Newman, who was a member of the main Committee proper, and who came to Bendigo in company with some other members of that Committee on 19 July 1977. This group spent no more than 2 1/2 hours in the Conference Room on the Osborne Street Campus, during which time they conducted five interview sessions with members of the College Council, senior academic and administrative staff, academic staff, teaching staff from the TAFE Division of the College (Bendigo Technical College) and students. The group declined an invitation to visit the Edwards Road campus (where the engineering facilities are established) and raised no questions about engineering, except concerning the interface between courses offered in the TAFE Division and those offered in the Advanced Education Division.

5. The Partridge Committee's report was produced early in 1978 and Chapter 5 recommended the phasing out of professional engineering courses from the Bendigo College of Advanced Education from the beginning of 1979. This recommendation appeared to be based on three factors-

(i) an alleged surplus of engineering graduates-concluded from a survey of the employment records of Monash University graduates, but taking no account of the almost 100 per cent employment record of Bendigo graduates.

(ii) the small intake into Bendigo courses-based on the extremely low 1976 intake, but ignoring the recovery to 44 in 1977 and 49 in 1978. Incorrect figures were used in referring to the number of final year students at Bendigo between 1972 and 1977.
(iii) the low graduation rates at Bendigo-based on completely incorrect figures, e.g. 24 instead of 32 in 1975 and 20 instead of 45 in 1976.

6. Inaccuracies and illogicalities in the Partridge Committee recommendations on engineering were pointed out to Education Minister Thompson and the Government agreed not to accept these recommendations, but asked the proposed Victorian Post-Secondary Education Commission to carry out a further study on engineering education in Victoria.

7. As a result of the publicity generated by the recommendations of the Partridge Committee, there was a loss of public confidence in the stability of engineering courses at Bendigo and the intake in 1979 dropped to 27.

8. During 1979 the Academic Committee on Engineering of the Victorian Institute of Colleges carried out the regular quinquennial review of our engineering courses and agreed to extend their accreditation only until the end of 1980 in view of the investigation then being undertaken by a working party set up by the Victorian Post-Secondary Education Commission. This did nothing to restore public confidence in engineering at Bendigo and the new intake for 1980 was only 26.

9. Towards the end of 1980 the Victorian Post-Secondary Education Commission Working Party on Engineering Education produced its report, in which it noted that there had been a resurgence in employment opportunities for engineers and there was a prospective shortage of engineering graduates unless more were produced in the next few years. It expressed the view, however, that there was sufficient capacity in the large metropolitan institutions comprising Melbourne and Monash Universities, Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology, Swinburne Institute of Technology and Footscray Institute of Technology to meet these needs. It stated that spare capacity was available at the Caulfield Institute of Technology, the Ballarat College of Advanced Education, the Gippsland Institute of Advanced Education, Deakin University and Bendigo College of Advanced Education. It recommended that the Preston Institute of Technology should continue to phase out engineering courses as had already been planned. It also recommended that some attention should be given to engineering courses at Bendigo College of Advanced Education, Deakin University and Caulfield Institute of Technology.

10. So far as Bendigo was concerned the Victorian Post-Secondary Education Commission Working Party noted that the facilities and staff were of high quality, but recent intakes had been too small for economic viability and it recommended that the College Council should give careful consideration to moving out of engineering into other course areas. This report again did nothing to restore confidence in engineering at Bendigo and, although there was a general upsurge in enrolments in engineering in 1981, new enrolments at Bendigo rose only to 29 students.

11. It is acknowledged that present intakes are too small for economic viability, but it is clear that the reason for these small intakes can be traced back to the engineering recommendations of the Partridge Committee, based on inaccurate information, ignorance of the local situation, a distinct tendency to favour centralism in education and illogical conclusions on employment opportunities on the basis of a sample from Monash University without taking sufficient account of the employment records of graduates from other institutions.
ASSESSMENT OF THE ECONOMIC CONTRIBUTION OF THE ENGINEERING FACULTY OF THE BENDIGO COLLEGE OF ADVANCED EDUCATION TO THE BENDIGO COMMUNITY
Social benefits/costs

The closure of the three engineering departments within the Engineering School would result in the loss of at least eighteen jobs directly within the Bendigo community. Fourteen of these would be full-time academic positions and four would be support/technical positions. Also lost would be a significant number of the ninety-three students currently enrolled in the Engineering School. The average length of service of the non-fixed term staff (teaching and non-teaching) is well over ten years. It is a relatively stable staff with little turnover in recent years which itself is of importance when one considers that only one of the teaching staff originally came from Bendigo. As with any relatively insular community it is often the injection of new blood that contributes to shaping the direction and attitudes of the community as well as adding stimulus to its cultural affairs. This is aptly demonstrated by the variety of local community affairs actively participated in by a majority of staff members. Such activities include service clubs, scouting, education, local council affairs and professional organisations such as the Bendigo and Northern Group of the Institution of Engineers, Australia. It is perhaps not going too far to suggest that many of these people are even more involved in community affairs than the average citizen.
Economic benefits/costs

1. The monetary contribution of the Engineering School to the local community is of particular significance. The current income generated into the district by the School in terms of spending power (comparing payments to wages, ancillary payments and materials expenditure) runs to the tune of approximately half a million dollars. The bulk of this spending would be withdrawn from the region, the result being lower retail sales, lower expenditure on insurance, less expenditure on entertainment, housing, debt charges, health and medical services and so on.

Even here the effect is not simply half a million dollars withdrawn but perhaps closer to three-quarters of a million when multiplier effects of the spending flow are taken into account. The effects don't stop there either, the withdrawal of spending from the community will also result in the loss of other jobs dependent upon the spending and impede the prospects of future job opportunities. Although it is difficult to predict where this job loss will occur, we might expect at the very least that other staff members of the College would be directly affected since service work provided by other departments to the School of Engineering occupies the time of approximately three other full-time staff members. Once again, the subsequent across the board multiplier effects need to be taken into account by the community. Should these people be forced to leave Bendigo in search of employment and consequently place their houses on the market, the effect could be quite serious upon a somewhat already depressed real-estate market. The prospects of recovery in this market in the near future would be postponed in the very least. Viewed as a transaction cost to the staff seeking alternative employment, the amount involved could be considerable, as an externality to the community the real cost would be even greater.

2. A current service provided in association with the Engineering School involves industrial testing facilities, mostly in the area of concrete testing with however, some provision for soil testing. The facility is registered by the National Association of Testing Authorities (NATA) for concrete testing as such, provides the only facility for concrete testing in Bendigo. Some materials come from as far away as Swan Hill and Deniliquin and without the Bendigo service these and local materials would have to be sent to Melbourne. The fees for testing are slightly less than those charged by private operators in Melbourne and Bendigo firms using the facility to enjoy an additional advantage in that there is less time and lower transport costs involved. The actual gross income to the College in 1980 from industrial testing amounted to some $31,700. It would be difficult to imagine the industrial testing service continuing without the existence of the Engineering School, as without the backing of the engineering staff, testing couldn't continue with NATA recognition. The prospects of the testing service being taken up by a local private engineering consultant wouldn't be bright when one considers the capital investment required ($50,000), the fluctuating demand for materials to be tested (this reflects cyclical fluctuation in the building industry) and the rate of return on investment. At present the facility employs three staff on limited term contract and the closing of the School of Engineering would place their futures in grave doubt. Just a short time ago this area was seen to have ample scope for expansion and development in light of the proposed establishment of a Professional Community Services Body within the College. The closure of Engineering would provide a body blow to such developments and further reduce future potential income sources for the College as a whole.

3. A further contribution by the School of Engineering to the local community is made via professional advice and assistance to local community groups, public authorities and councils. Both staff and students are involved in this area. Staff from the electrical, mechanical, and civil engineering departments frequently provide advice and consulting services to local industry. Where possible, staff may involve themselves and their students in practical applications of their subjects which is of assistance to local groups, for example, surveying the playing areas of school grounds where improvements and landscaping are proposed,or surveying the rinks of a local bowling club. About a dozen or so major projects are undertaken by students (mostly civil engineering students) each year in conjunction with local government bodies. The project might involve designing a water supply scheme, a drainage system or even a caravan park. Whilst only some of these projects are actually adopted and put into effect by local authorities, those that are provide an extremely valuable and very cheap service.Even if the projects are not directly used the authority may often be able to make use of a good deal of ancillary information and specifications. Since this contribution is provided free of charge, its value is difficult to estimate but clearly the community derives major benefits in the form of positive externalities.

4. It is interesting to note that with only a couple of exceptions, local municipal councils employ engineers who have completed all, or at least part, of their academic qualifications with the Engineering School of the Bendigo College of Advanced Education. Not only is this the case in the immediate Bendigo region, but there are also numerous examples of Councils throughout Victoria and NSW who employ engineering graduates from Bendigo. Closure of the Engineering School would deprive the region of a service of technological skill and expertise at a time when a shortage of engineers is becoming apparent and when the projected shortage over the next decade will become acute.

5. At the present time and using the best available estimates of revenue and costs, in terms of direct teaching expenditure, engineering students on average bring into the College approximately the same amount of revenue from funding sources as it costs to teach each student. In this sense, (i.e. the direct teaching costs) engineering is cost efficient with the present number of students and costs per head could be reduced with a greater intake of students. Without engineering the other Schools and Departments within the College would find indirect costs higher per student (computing services, library, Media services, administrative, buildings, etc.). Many of the services would not be reduced in size if engineering were to close, therefore raising costs per head in the remainder of the College. Thus we might view direct teaching costs as the pertinent figure in terms of efficiency.

Using January 1980 base figures updated for estimated cost increases to the present time, and incorporating a proportion of total College costs based on actual EFTS figures, engineering students cost the College approximately 39 per cent more in total per head than they bring in revenue. In terms of total costs it is estimated that the Engineering School would need to have an EFTS of 150 students to balance costs with revenue. Positive steps could be taken to ensure this increase in numbers. (The total cost figures probably represent an understatement if previous funding arrangements per department are taken into account).
RETAIN ORDNANCE FACTORY BENDIGO
26 May 1981 Sir Phillip Lynch MP,
Minister for Industry and Commerce,
Parliament House,
Canberra, ACT 2600
Dear Sir Phillip,

This letter is intended as a follow-up to your meeting with a deputation of OFB employees on the 15/5/81. The purpose of this letter is to both gain written verification of statements you made during this meeting and to receive clarification in several areas related to the proposed OFB sale to private enterprise.

At the meeting you stated that if no satisfactory buyer could be found for the OFB, then it would continue as a government concern in its present form. Will you please verify this statement in your reply?

During the meeting you stated that the sale of the OFB was recommended in the Eltringham Report. When asked to make this report public, you stated it was 'Confidential'. This committee finds this viewpoint unacceptable and therefore calls for the release of the Eltringham Report and its terms of reference. The proposed sale of the OFB has very grave implications for the jobs of its 650 workers, the economic stability of the Bendigo area and the defence preparedness of the nation. With this in mind the Government needs to show on what basis it made the decision to sell the OFB. Clearly, if the Government believes its reasons for selling the OFB are sound and well founded, then it has nothing to fear. At the meeting with our deputation you spoke of the need for consultation and discussion. The release of the Eltringham Report and the terms of reference it was based upon, would be a very real way of showing the sincerity in your calls for consultation and discussion.

At the May 15 meeting you rejected the deputation's request for an open public inquiry into the OFB similar to that at the Williamstown Dockyard. You spoke of the fact that the proposed sale of the OFB had been thoroughly investigated by your department. Our committee, at this time, does not intend to question this statement but clearly justice not only needs to be done, it needs to be seen to be done. Therefore this committee reiterates its request for an open public inquiry into the OFB. If, as you say, the matter has been thoroughly investigated by your department, an open public inquiry could only help to justify and explain what is seen by the Bendigo community as a secretive, unjustifiable decision.

The question of what plant transfers the Government plans to undertake with the proposed sale of the OFB, is an area where urgent clarification is needed. Mr H. Ryan and you stated at the deputation's meeting that minimal plant transfers were envisaged. It was also stated by Mr Ryan and you that details of plant transfers had not been finalized. The Government stated, when it announced the sale decision, that it planned to sell the OFB as a ''Going Concern''. These three statements are contradictory. A factory such as the OFB is based upon several key pieces of machinery. The removal of any of these machines would leave a body without a heart and not a 'Going Concern'. With these facts in mind, this committee calls on the government to inform it immediately, of the specific items of plant it plans to transfer with the proposed OFB sale.

In the past the question of the rationalisation of Ordnance Factories has often been raised. Up until 30 April it had been stated Departmental policy that any such rationalisation would favour Bendigo. This policy had been reinforced by a statement made in 1978 by the minister then in charge of the OFB, Mr Ian McPhee. He stated that any rationalisation would favour Bendigo. At the deputation's meeting you stated that a Government has the right to change its mind. Our committee does not question this right but we do request further clarification. Since you acknowledged at our meeting that the Ordnance Factory is an important part of the Bendigo economy, upon what basis did your Government change its mind on the issue and decide to sell the OFB?

During the 15 May meeting you stated that the Government envisaged a private enterprise OFB having a continuing involvement in defence work. Does this mean that the Government would guarantee defence work at least at present levels, to a private enterprise owned OFB?

The government has stated that with the proposed sale it plans to transfer part of OFB's defence capabilities to Ordnance Factory, Maribynong. It is a well known fact that the OFB has a great deal of difficulty attracting tradesmen. In view of this, how does the Government plan to attract the skilled tradesmen necessary for such work?

The OFB is a strategically decentralised defence manufacturing facility. The Government cannot guarantee it will continue as a defence manufacturing facility under private enterprise. With these two facts in mind, how does the Government justify centralising its own defence manufacturing capabilities?

The OFB is currently training 102 of its own apprentices. Additionally, the OFB is currently training 24 first year apprentices on behalf of private employers in Northern and Central Victoria. Virtually all these apprentices are being trained in trades which are suffering from a shortage of skilled labour. Can the Government guarantee that this very high level of apprentice training would continue at the OFB, if the OFB was sold to private enterprise?

As has been previously stated, this letter is designed to gain written verification of statements you made during the 15 May meeting and to receive clarification concerning areas of doubt and importance in relation to your Government's proposal to sell the OFB to private enterprise. You have stated that consultation and discussion should occur between all parties involved in the proposed OFB sale. This committee also recognises the need for consultation and discussion. A comprehensive reply to all queries raised in this letter would be a very real way of illustrating the sincerity of your calls for consultation and discussion.
We look forward to an early reply.
Yours faithfully, G. W. WILD Committee President
EXTRACT FROM THE 'BENDIGO ADVERTISER' OF 25 SEPTEMBER 1980
Ordnance's $9m?
About $9m was likely to be spent at the Bendigo Ordnance Factory between 1981 and 1985, according to the Federal Member for Bendigo, Mr John Bourchier.
Planning within the Department of Productivity would ensure that the Ordnance Factory would have an increasing role in Australia's overall defence preparedness, he said.
The Government was considering a five-year capital works plan at Government factories.
This was in keeping with its policy of maintaining a viable defence industry within Australia, Mr Bourchier said.
This financial year's capital works program for the Ordnance Factory provided for tenders to be called next March for the construction of a new electroplating building at a cost of about $440,000.
Tenders would also be called that month for the construction of concrete foundations for lathes and other equipment at an estimated cost of $55,000.
The proposed program for the factory in 1981-82 would cost close to $2m, he said.

Work to be done would include the renovation of transporter crane tracks ($100,000), a new quality assurance building comprising a number of equipment testing laboratories ($1.5m) and additional air-conditioning in the metrology (measuring) section ($40,000).
The metrology section would be extended at a cost of $200,000 and a pit furnace restored at a cost of $100,000 in 1981-82, he said.
In the 1982-83 financial year work would be done to strengthen steelwork for new cranes at a cost of $200,000.
A new administration building would be built at a cost of $1.5m and the gear shop would be extended at a cost of $80,000 in 1983-84.
In 1984-85, the final year of the program, a new toolroom-machine shop costing $5m would be built.
Mr Bourchier said the program was designed to ensure that the Bendigo Ordnance Factory achieved its full capacity.
MAKE OUR MUNITIONS OR PERISH
Apparently we in Australia cannot learn a lesson-to which I refer our experience in the last war when our ability to produce a wide range of armaments and military equipment saved the day for us.

In the period of 22 months between Dunkirk and Pearl Harbor we had no outside source of supply for any defence requirements. Yet when our troops came from North Africa into New Guinea they lacked for nothing be it guns, mortars, Bren gun carriers, searchlights, refrigeration vehicles, hand grenades, rifles, Bren guns, engineering equipment and so on. There was virtually something of everything and enough. Three thousand field guns of four different calibres were delivered to the Army by the Australian motor industry. It was the engineering ability of the motor industry that proved so valuable. We had several shortages that nearly put us over the gun barrel. There was no nickel, the experts emphatically stating that there was no nickel in Australia.

The major shortage that could have left us virtually unarmed was the inability of the United Kingdom to send up optical munitions, in particular gun sights. We actually had some 150 guns made in Australia, but with no sights they were useless. Then virtually by a miracle, Australia produced four varieties of top grade and very special optical glass and made a full range of optics for cameras, tank sights, binoculars, range finders etc. and all in seven months at a cost of about 60 million pounds, and this despite a cable from the Australian High Commissioner in London to the Prime Minister advising that UK top authorities, including the Admiralty and manufacturers, that such optical work would take us four years and cost over 1 million pounds. Prior to Pearl Harbor, Australia had been at war for two years. The United States' vigorous neutrality even prevented transmission of mail through the States if such mail dealt with armaments and, in particular, drawings of such armaments.
Ball and roller bearings nearly brought us to a halt, but we quietly set up manufacturers.

The critical defence establishments that we set up have been allowed to close down and disappear. Imported defence equipment is at best a short term deterrent. It might hold off the enemy for a few weeks, but no country can depend on an ally in time of war. This especially applies to equipment and to essential spare parts, because the same requirement is needed for the ally, and quite naturally its needs come first. What is the use of a motor car if you have a broken crankshaft and cannot get a replacement? This applies equally to a gun, an aeroplane, or a tank.

The requirements for spare parts in time of war can never be adequately forecast, and the vulnerability of transport, both by air and sea, could cut us off from all imported supplies. This was well illustrated when much of the Israeli Air Force was grounded during the last Arab-Israeli War, and they could not get spare parts for their Mirage aircraft from France for several months. As a result, Israel now designs and makes much of its military aircraft and tanks.

I have been through two major wars both in the services and in munitions. I have no financial or other interest in war production. I fully concur and fully support Sir Keith Shann in his article, 'Build Our Defences and Hang the Cost' in the April issue of Pacific Defence Reporter. How can survival be measured in cost?

If economics can determine such an equation, then perhaps mundane money can be viewed through the words of a former president of the United States who, when much debate was current over the building of the Brooklyn Bridge, remarked:
'Make it in the United States regardless of cost, so we will still have the dollars!'
Making of armaments in its many forms is a No. 1 industry in several countries, providing enormous employment, which is fairly viewed in such countries as better than payment for the dole.

Very fortunately, new high technology is available and makes manufacture much easier and quicker than it used to be. I refer to computer tape control of all machine tools. This almost eliminates the costly long time to making tooling and gauges. The process goes straight from the drawing into the automatic tape controlled machine tool and out comes the finished product.

We have a wide awake Ministry of Science and Technology. We should ensure that the Ministry comes to the fore. It is struggling hard to create improved awareness of the new high technology and can make a great contribution to our defence.

The government as a defence measure must release funds, and provide defence subsidies so that we can produce the required modern machine tools. Right now under defence we can create and put into use a wide range of new high technology that would be of immense value to the nation.

We must with urgency bring to the fore the valuable lessons of the last war in the making of munitions. We must bring back into production the items we had to produce to survive, such as the manufacture of ball and roller bearings, optical glass and optical munitions and to hell with the cost and the economists.
Yours faithfully, Sir LAURENCE HARTNETT

(As Director of Ordinance Production in the Munitions Department from 1940 to 1945, and chairman of the Army Inventions Directorate, Sir Laurence Hartnett performed the extraordinary task of building a defence industry from nothing in 1940 to the point two years later when the Australian Army was self-sufficient. He is the only Australian alive today who knows from first hand experience the dangers of dependence on others for critical equipment in time of war, and the problems of creating a defence industry. He was born in England in 1898, served his mechanical engineering apprenticeship with Vickers Ltd, was commissioned in the Royal Navy Air Service in 1917, and also served with the RAF. Still intensively active, he established Singapore's armament factory, the first ever built in the tropics. Editor.)
MONDAY JOB MARKET
Plenty of jobs for graduates in engineering
More than 10,000 well paid positions will go to overseas job seekers unless young Australians come forward, according to the Dean of Engineering at Monash University Professor Lance Endersbee.

Professor Endersbee said there would be a great demand for engineers in Australia during the next few years, and if young people continued to ignore the profession local and overseas companies would recruit elsewhere for jobs that often started a graduate on about $25,000 a year.

'The number of Australian students doing engineering is declining and the demand for engineers is increasing. It's a terrible problem. We are not inspiring our young people to come forward. More than 40 per cent of my students are Asian, and 80 per cent of those doing their doctorates are Asian', he said.
He said not only large Australian development companies like BHP wanted engineers, many international companies, especially from Britain, recruited in Australia.

'Every year French oil exploration companies come to the university and interview graduates. Many are prepared to start the graduate on $25,000 a year. It's rather tough work out there but the graduates they take come back as fairly rich young people.
'We also have a great demand for chemical engineers and our graduates usually start on about $18,000 a year.
'Sometimes a firm will send the youngster abroad to work with the parent company. Often after about four or five years the engineer can come back and buy a house'.

He said that in the past Australian firms combatted the shortage by bringing in large numbers of workers from other countries. By doing this they were leaving all the senior positions open to overseas people.

He said the last thing Australia needed was for large slabs of its industry to be controlled by overseas interests and for Australian companies to resort to foreign manpower and technical facilities because they could not cope on their own. 'It's far better to develop our own capability to deal with this and just get on with the job, otherwise Australians will be standing by the fence watching others do the work for them'.
He said it was also preferable for Australian companies to train their own graduates rather than recruit from overseas because then they knew exactly what they were getting.

There were many opportunities for Australian engineers because the demand was also increasing all over the world. 'It is an international profession and there are prizes going to people who are highly developed in the field', he said.
Why are so few people training for such a rewarding profession? Professor Endersbee blames the education system in part.
'School students are often not encouraged to study maths and science with the view of doing engineering, and as a result many students just don't have the qualifications needed to do the courses'.

There was another main reason, he said. 'In Australia we haven't developed a sophisticated modern technological society. We have been getting by on the export of coal or on primary produce while our industrial and manufacturing base is not highly developed.

'Therefore for a generation we have not been attracting our brightest, most talented people to the profession. But that must change now, and schools must start encouraging students to do engineering as a career. We must take advantage of the possible shortfall in engineers'.

The chairman of the Institution of Engineers Australia, Victoria division, Mr Brian Lloyd agreed that while the present supply of graduates in Victoria balanced with demand, there probably would be a shortage of labor within the next few years.
He said about 800 graduates a year entered the Victorian workforce, but to meet future demand this number would have to be raised to about 1000.

There would probably be a high level of demand for engineers in the areas of electronics, computer and control systems and mining. Demand would strengthen in areas related to private investment such as chemical, mechanical, industrial and production engineering. The growth in electric power engineering would not be as great.
He said demand for civil engineers in the public sector might not grow but there could be an upturn in the private sector.
The number of graduates in Victoria had dropped 23 qualified engineers per 100,000 people compared with 34 engineers in 1975.

There were many opportunities for young engineers, he said, firstly because the Victorian Government was planning a thrust towards new development projects and secondly because companies had no choice but to take on graduates now.

Because large companies stopped taking on graduates in the late seventies there was a shortage of experienced engineers in the workforce. As there were shortages in many other countries it was unlikely that firms would continue to bring in a large number of workers. Therefore graduates would be employed.
'I think every graduate would be able to get a job in engineering', he said.

The institution thought the Government could help combat the shortages by providing more funds for engineering colleges around Australia. First priority in Victoria had to be given to 'the big four'-Melbourne and Monash universities, RMIT and Swinburne Institute of Technology.

He said one major problem that was being overlooked was the great shortage of people who serviced or supported engineers such as draftsmen and technical officers. 'If there were more people skilled in these areas we would be able to use the engineers we do have more effectively'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the Commonwealth Functions (Statutes Review) Bill 1981. This is a very strange sort of Bill covering many things by stealth. When we were in government we brought in a medical scheme whereby doctors could bulk bill patients. That was a great boon to the doctors and of great assistance to people in need of medical attention. This Government abolished Medibank and bulk billing and today we see before us in this legislation another form of bulk billing. A whole series of alterations has been brought into the Parliament. Every one of them should be debated independently. Because of the way in which the Government has introduced this Bill, known as an omnibus Bill, honourable senators on this side of the chamber do not have an opportunity to debate its contents. We would be the only people here who want to debate it. There has been only one Government speaker in the debate, Senator Reid who represents the Australian Capital Territory. Of course, her contribution was to the effect that she did not believe the Government should own any enterprise which shows a profit. It should all be handed over to private enterprise. That was all she spoke about-that one part of the Bill which deals with the disposal of places such as the Belconnen Mall, which is a great credit to the Australian Capital Territory, and handing it over to private enterprise. That was all she was concerned about.
—She had no sympathy for members of the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Union.

—That is right, no sympathy at all. At least she spoke to the Bill. No other Government senator has been prepared to speak to it and to back the Government in the measures that have been put forward to the Parliament in this Bill which no doubt will be passed. For the information of people who are listening, so that they will have some understanding of what is embodied in this Bill, we find that the Australian Capital Territory is mentioned. Even rabbit destruction and sewerage rates are mentioned in the part of the Bill that deals with the Australian Capital Territory. Then we have the Australian Postal Commission; the Australian Wool Corporation; bankruptcy; Commonwealth Employees (Compensation); Commonwealth Employees (Payments of Remuneration and Allowances); Commonwealth Teaching Service; Director-General of Health; export expansion grants; export market development grants; foreign takeovers; Housing Loans Insurance Corporation; Industries Assistance Commission; lands acquisition; Legislative Drafting Institute and navigation. Then we have the Prices Justification Tribunal; the procurement of goods, works and services; remuneration in respect of dual appointments; transport planning and research; urban and public transport, miscellaneous items and three Schedules to the Bill. All that is included in one nicely wrapped up package-bulk billing as we call it. As Senator Chipp pointed out, this is the last time at least for the next three years that this type of thing will be allowed to happen in this chamber because the numbers will be against the Government. If the Government is foolish enough to bring in a measure like this, it just will not get it through the Senate because the numbers will be here to stop it. Government senators will then have to cast their minds back to 1972 to 1975 when they took certain measures to block certain legislation which was introduced by the properly elected Government of the day.

SPEECH.PARA: All the measures that I have mentioned are deserving of a full-scale debate but we are restricted to speaking to very few of them. I repeat, this provides conclusive proof that the Senate is not a House of review but rather a rubber stamp for the Liberal Party when it is in government and a House of frustration for the Labor Party when it happens to be in government. That is the way in which the Senate is used. It is not a States' House or a House of review. We found that out, to the chagrin of many people in Queensland and Western Australia just the other day when the airlines legislation was discussed. We then witnessed the paper tigers of whom I spoke this morning saying all sorts of things to the Press and making themselves out as little heroes for what they were going to do to force the Government to amend the legislation. But when the pressure came on too few of them were prepared to cross the floor and bring the Government to its senses. Certainly some Government supporters crossed the floor on some provisions and others on other provisions, so they got some publicity in that senator so-and-so crossed the floor and opposed the Government. But on the next piece of legislation such senators voted in support of the Government and someone else crossed the floor.

TALK.START.PARA: —In August they will be the ones who will be frustrated, not us.

—That is so. I am reminded of the activities of members of the Australian Democratic Labor Party in this place. They had all sorts of airy-fairy ideas about what they were going to do, but whenever the Government was in jeopardy they sat tight and supported the Liberal Government. They are only paper tigers. Government supporters will be judged on their merits when we come back for the Budget session. Time will permit me to refer to two matters only. Senator Primmer mentioned his opposition to the sale of the Australian Wool Testing Authority. My colleague, Senator Walsh, referred to it also. I spoke at some length on it when we were debating the Wool Industry Amendment Bill in this chamber last week. I made reference then to the fact that we had received a great deal of representation from people in primary industry, in South Australia especially, asking not only members of the Opposition but also members of the Government to oppose the sale of that authority. Once again we saw the wrath of those so-called champions of democracy who go out on the hustings at election time and tell people whose support they want: 'You can vote for members of the Liberal Party; we are free agents and will look after your interests in the Parliament; we are not bound by Party policy.' Of course they are. If anyone wanted proof of that he has only to see the legislation that has been rail-roaded through this House in the last couple of weeks.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members are often chided as being bound by Party policy, but we make no secret of that fact. Our policy is arrived at by a majority decision. Every member of the Labor Party who seeks endorsement for election to a State or Federal Parliament signs a pledge to be bound by Party policy. We do not go out and fool people, when we are seeking election, that we will do certain things, that we are free agents. We are proud that we abide by Party policy. Not so the Liberal Party supporters or, to a lesser degree, Country Party supporters. They promise: 'When measures come before the House we will judge them on their merits and will vote according to our conscience'. They do not do so. They vote according to the way that Mal Fraser tells them to vote. That has been borne out all too often.

Another matter of great concern to Senator Primmer and to myself is the proposed sale of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. I agree with the honourable senator when he says that after the next elections the present honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Bourchier) will no longer be a member of this Parliament. Whether or not the Government changes its mind about selling the Bendigo Ordnance Factory, the people of that area have got the message that if Mr Bourchier is re-elected, and Fraser is returned, the factory will go; that the only thing that can save it is the return of a Labor Government and, once more, the election of a Labor member for Bendigo. The electorate was represented many years ago by a very good Labor member. That is what the people of Bendigo must consider. No doubt as Senator Primmer has said-he has a very close association with Bendigo-he will do his best to remind the people of that. I doubt whether they will need reminding. The writing is on the wall, that if the Fraser Government is returned to office 600 or 700 employees will be looking for jobs and small businesses will go to the wall because of loss of income generally. Also, as a result of recurring losses, service industries no longer will be able to remain in Bendigo.

I have mentioned the Australian Wool Testing Authority. Mr Kerin, when speaking on the matter in the other place, said that the Opposition opposed Part IV of the Bill, comprising clauses 114 to 121. Part IV relates to the Government's decision with respect to changing the status of the Wool Testing Authority and the necessary changes to the Wool Industry Act. As I said earlier, we have had reams of correspondence, telegrams and telexes from people in primary industry. Very few of the writers would come out and say publicly that they were members of the Labor Party or supported it. In the main, they are supporters of the Liberal Party or the National Country Party. They are pleading with members of the Opposition as well as Government supporters to oppose this measure, but not one member of the Liberal Party or the National Country Party has been prepared to stand up for those whom he represents. Not one is prepared to stand up in the Parliament and speak in support of what the Government is doing. They will vote for the legislation but are afraid to get up and criticise it. I wonder what they will say when they go back to the country areas that they represent and meet some of the people who have asked them to oppose this legislation in the full belief that they are free agents. What will they say? If they are honest they will say, 'Mal put the pressure on us and we have to do his bidding; it is his idea. He set up the razor gang and he is the person who has dictated to us that we must support its proposals, as incorporated in the omnibus Bill, and all of their ramifications! The wording of the measure is such that we see only the tip of the iceberg. One cannot get to the crux of it. We will not know, until it begins to operate what its ill-effects will be, especially on the rural areas of this great country. I repeat, Government supporters have claimed that they are free agents. That they are not has been proved and we will see a lot of new faces in this place when we come back.

When I spoke on the Wool Industry Amendment Bill, I referred at length to representations that had been made to me by Mr Bill Murdoch of Karoonda. I have sent him the record of what I said in his support in this Parliament and have mentioned that only the members of the Opposition have been prepared to put a case on behalf of the woolgrowers that he represents. I know that he approached Government members in Adelaide a few weeks ago because I happened to be in the Commonwealth office building when I ran into him. He told me that he was on his way to see certain members of the Liberal Party. They are not interested in the case that he put to them, and they have been very conspicuous by their absence in commenting on either that Bill or the legislation before us today. They have not said a word. To save the time of the Senate I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the first three pages of the Rural Digest, which is published by Mr John Kerin, the shadow Minister for Primary Industry. It deals at length with what the razor gang cuts mean to primary industry, especially woolgrowers. If I am refused leave I will have to read it, but otherwise I do not intend to quote from it. I seek leave to have those pages incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
THE RAZOR GANG

My first reading of the Ministerial Review Statement (MRS) suggested that the rural sector would pay a reasonably high price as a result of the recommendations of the Razor Gang. But obviously I don't have Mr Nixon's capacity to read between the lines. This remarkable talent of Mr Nixon's has become apparent in his responses to the presumably unexpectedly hostile producer reaction to some of the recommendations. (A cynic might even suggest that Mr Nixon has backtracked on some of the recommendations).
Let's have a look at two of Mr Nixon's interpretations:

(1) The MRS announced that the Australian Wool Testing Authority would be 'sold to (the) private sector'. Mr Nixon's interpretation of this is that the AWTA will be sold to a 'special foundation . . . set up by the wool industry-not what most people would call private enterprise! What would the difference be between this arrangement and the existing situation?

(2) Mr Nixon has interpreted a recommendation that the Wheat Board interest subsidy 'be reduced by one percentage point' as referring to a change in Reserve Bank interest rates announced in March. This change in fact increased the gap on which the subsidy is calculated by 0.55 percentage points!

Might I suggest that it would be a worthwhile exercise for Mr Nixon to apply his talent to some of the other Razor Gang recommendations which are also going to have an adverse impact on the rural sector. Perhaps he could interpret the 'abolition of the PJT'-an organisation which has saved primary producers some hundreds of millions of dollars-as referring merely to the abolition of changes in the legislation which have progressively weakened the PJT since 1975. What the recommendation could really mean is that a PJT in the form originally intended, is to be re-established. The savings to individual primary producers will amount to thousands of dollars each year. Hurrah for Mr Nixon!

We need similarly imaginative interpretations of other recommendations for example, those relating to quarantine, soil conservation and extension research. Without an effective quarantine policy, Australia should start now to prepare for the day when our livestock industries cease to be a major export earner. Without adequate attention to soil conservation, the future profitability of both our livestock and cropping industries could be in jeopardy.

It is a pity that Mr Nixon's capacity to read between the lines has not also been extended to some of the other recommendations which are just as important to rural people. For example, the recommendations relating to education. In particular, the reintroduction for university fees for second and higher degrees places a disproportionate burden on country people who must also find money for accommodation.
Who is Confused?-A Tale about Interest Rates

Let's examine the Razor Gang's recommendations to reduce the gap between the interest rate on commercial borrowings undertaken by the Australian Wheat Board and the cost of borrowing from the Reserve Bank by 1 percentage point for purposes of subsidy calculation, a little more closely.

The reaction of the wheat industry to this announcement was understandably hostile. The statement appeared to be a blatant breach of the 1979 Wheat Marketing Agreement. When the AWB was forced to start borrowing on the commercial market a few years ago to help the Government overcome some of its money supply problems, the growers received a guarantee that the Treasury would pick up the difference between the commercial rate of interest and the rate of interest charged by the Rural Credits Department.
The statement in the Razor Gang report appears to clearly indicate that the subsidy would be reduced by 1 percentage point.
Not so, the Minister for Primary Industry, and member of the Razor Gang, Mr Nixon, is reported as claiming.

According to Mr Nixon, the statement in the report merely refers to a natural fall in the interest rate subsidy occurring as a result of the general increase in RCD interest rates announced by the Government in March.

However, prior to the March increase in RCD interest rates, the gap was 3.85 percentage points. Taking increases in equivalent commercial rates into account, the March increase in the RCD rate increased the gap to 4.40 percentage points, an increase in the gap of .55 percentage points. Mr Nixon is claiming that the gap was reduced by 1 percentage point by the increase in the RCD rate.

Mr Nixon's department-apparently working on the same interpretation of the Razor Gang recommendation as everyone except Mr Nixon himself-is currently preparing legislation to allow the commercial rate to be reduced by 1 percentage point for the purposes of the subsidy calculations.

Reducing the notional commercial rate would reduce the gap to 3.4 percentage points. On this basis, the change in the interest rate gap since the beginning of the year would be a decrease of 0.45 percentage points.
If Mr Nixon can convince the Treasurer that his is the correct interpretation, then the gap would have increased by .55 percentage points.
Now what was the original recommendation?-A reduction in the gap by 1 percentage point.
Who is confused?

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The other matter to which I wish to address my remarks is one that has caused great concern to educationists in this country. At page 11 of the ministerial statement on the Review of Commonwealth Functions we have the beginning of the section on education. At page 13, under the heading 'Function', we have the heading 'Tertiary Tuition Fees' and the following comments:

SPEECH.PARA: Tuition fees to be introduced in universities and CAE's for students undertaking degrees and diplomas subject to an initial tertiary qualification . . .

The description goes on and on but I have found it impossible to see that spelt out in the legislation. That makes me suspicious. It must be spelt out in detail somewhere, but when it comes into effect it will have a great effect on the top educationists of this country. I have received reams of correspondence from people in South Australia. No doubt every South Australian member of this Parliament has received correspondence including, no doubt, you, Mr President. I will not read all the letters. I will just read the names of the people and some of their comments. I have received a letter dated 11 May from Professor J. R. Prescott, who is the Professor of Physics at the University of Adelaide. He enclosed a copy of a letter he has recently sent to the Federal Minister for Education (Mr Fife). The letter reads:
I trust that the argument will appeal to you too, and that you will lend what support you can to initiatives to reverse the decision.
In the opening stanza of his letter to Mr Fife, he stated:

I write on the matter of fees for postgraduate degrees. If implemented, the recent proposal to impose such fees would cripple my department within eighteen months, by removing from it all postgraduate students except those on CPRA's.
The letter is signed by J. R. Prescott, Professor of Physics at the University of Adelaide.

I have received another letter from the University of Adelaide written by Professor Bowie who is the Dean of the Faculty of Science. He also pointed out to me-and enclosed a copy of a letter sent to Mr Fife-all the problems that his Faculty will suffer if these razor gang recommendations are put into effect. In his letter to Mr Fife, under the heading 'Fees for Postgraduate Students' he says:

I wish to inform you that on 12 May 1981 the Faculty of Science of the University of Adelaide, passed the following motion unanimously. 'The Faculty of Science opposes the introduction of fees for students undertaking Degree and Diploma courses'.
Under the heading of 'The Financial Effect on Postgraduate Students' the letter reads:
The imposition of fees will cause many talented graduates not to undertake valuable postgraduate studies.

The 1981 statistics are as follows. There are 1,101 postgraduate students currently enrolled in the University, of whom only 324 are in receipt of Commonwealth or University awards. There are 235 postgraduate students in the Faculty of Science of whom 117 receive support. Over half of postgraduate students in the Faculty are thus not funded, and we must assume a high proportion of these would have been unable to continue their studies had fees been imposed at the time they commenced their courses.
The imposition of fees and the subsequent loss of postgraduate students will severely restrict the research output from Departments in the Faculty of Science.
If Australia is to continue to develop its technology it needs more skilled scientists. The Government's decision on fees will inevitably result in a reduced production of scientists.
Under another heading 'The Effect on Undergraduate Teaching in the Faculty of Science' the letter reads:

Departments in the Faculty of Science often have large first and second year undergraduate classes. Some Departments teach up to 600 first year students. These students all undertake laboratory classes and although University staff supervise these classes, it is the postgraduate students who act as tutors and demonstrators to the undergraduates. It would be impossible to provide laboratory and tutorial instruction to undergraduates without the teaching contribution of postgraduate students.
The letter is signed by J. H. Bowie, Dean of the Faculty of Science of the University of Adelaide.

I have received further correspondence from the Australian Federation of University Women-South Australia, signed by Dr Jennifer M. Barker. She points out the same fears about what will happen. I will read only the last part of her letter which she sent to Mr Fife. Obviously no attention has been paid to all of this correspondence. Dr Barker states:

There is a fear that introduction of fees at the postgraduate level may be a preliminary to introduction of fees at the undergraduate level, to which we would be totally opposed, for reasons similar to those given above. Similarly, we are opposed to any reduction in TEAS allowances.

We believe strongly that it is in the national interest to have a populace which is as highly educated as possible and which has a respect for learning. The further development, rather than restriction, of that situation would be an act of enlightened government. We therefore request that you reconsider the proposals referred to and endeavour, in consultation with the appropriate bodies, to find more acceptable solutions to the problems of support of this important section of education in our country.

The letter is signed by Dr Jennifer M. Barker. Most of these letters point out to us that there has been no consultation at all with the deans and the professors in the universities by the razor gang. These people are completely in the dark. They are very worried, otherwise they would not be writing to members of parliament.

I have also received a copy of a letter sent to Mr Fife from the Roseworthy Agricultural College which is signed by M. B. Spurling who is the Acting Director. Under the heading 'Proposed Introduction of Student Fees for Post Graduate Courses', the letter reads:

Because of the possible ambiguity in interpretation of what postgraduate courses may or may not be considered for attracting fees, I would want to clarify the nature of the graduate diploma courses at Roseworthy Agricultural College and put on record our strong objection to the introduction of fees for such courses.

Mr President, you and I know that most of the students who go to Roseworthy are children of people who would normally vote for the Liberal Party and not for the Labor Party. I venture to say that 90 per cent of the students who go to Roseworthy would be the sons-I do not know whether there are any girls there-or the daughters of supporters of the Liberal Party. They would have been supporters in the past but will probably not be in the future because of this action of the Government.

I have received a letter from the Adelaide University Graduates' Union which is signed by Dr R. C. Heddle. Dr Heddle points out the same problems that the union will experience if students are to be called upon to pay fees. I have received another letter from the Flinders University of South Australia which is signed by G. J. Fraenkel, the Chairman and Dean of the School of Medicine. His opening paragraph in his letter to me states:

I believe that the Australian Government has made a very unfortunate error in planning to introduce fees for second or higher qualifications in universities and that this plan should not be put into effect.

I have received another letter, again from the Flinders University, which is signed by Keith Hancock, the Vice-Chancellor. He used similar phrases to tell of the problems that will beset the Flinders University if these recommendations of the razor gang are put into effect. I have received another letter from the University of Adelaide which is signed by Graham Nerlich who is the Professor of Philosophy. He states:
I view with alarm the recent decision of Federal Cabinet to impose fees on higher degree students and those undertaking second degrees in our Universities.
I urge you to seek urgent reversal of this decision. I should be grateful for an indication of what position you will adopt towards it.
I can assure all of those people who have written to me of my position. I oppose most vigorously what the razor gang is doing.

I have received a letter from the University of Adelaide Staff Association signed by C. R. Lawton, who is the President and G. Dunstan, who is the Honorary Secretary. The first paragraph of their letter states:
The Federal Government's proposal to introduce fees for most students undertaking second degrees is hardly credible as an act of a cabinet which includes a good number of university or CAE graduates.

Of course, members of Cabinet have their diplomas or whatever they are. They are now in the Parliament and they have made a decision that no one else will come along with the same educational standards which they have been able to acquire. I have received a further letter from the University of Adelaide signed by Mr A. J. Butler. He writes:

I write as one of your constituents who is both a parent and a university staff-member, to express grave concern at certain decisions announced after the Review of Commonwealth Functions (the 'Razor Gang Report').
