I have received another letter from the University of Adelaide which is signed by R. F. Seamark who is a reader in endocrinology. He says:
As a University teacher involved with graduate students I wish to protest against the proposed budget cuts which would mean increased Fees for graduate students and 'tightening' of TEAS.
His letter went on.

Even people in Queensland have been writing to South Australian senators in the same vein. I have received a letter from the Chancellor of the Griffith University in Queensland, Theodor Bray, expressing the same concern. I have received a letter from the Association of Professional Engineers, Australia, stating:

The Review of Commonwealth Functions has recently recommended that a major review of the Defence Department organisation is to be conducted. You will be aware that two reviews have already been carried out early in 1980 into the Defence Science and Technology Organisation which were required to report to the Minister by June 1980. I understand these reviews are yet to be tabled in Parliament.

This Association has a number of members employed at the Defence Research Centre, Salisbury, who are anxious to know the outcome of these prior reviews. This is particularly so now as these reviews are no doubt of relevance in implementing the RCF decisions. These decisions could impact directly on a number of highly skilled, dedicated professional people in South Australia.
Would you enquire of the Minister of Defence when he intends to present these reports to Parliament and urge him to make them available to this Association at the earliest possible moment.

The letter is signed by J. R. Terry, the Honorary Vice President of the South Australian branch of the Association of Professional Engineers. Time does not permit me to read the full contents of those letters. I have read the pertinent parts. When honourable senators read those letters and when they have a think about them they will see that the old philosophy of Menzies has come back into this Government. The Government educates a few of the people who support it and it does all that it can to prevent the children of people from the working class of this country from getting any higher education. Immediately it educates the children of the working class of this country those children become a threat to the children of the wealthy section. Of course, as I and my colleagues have said on many occasions in this Parliament, this Government governs only for the benefit of those who have everything they require, and to give them more it takes away from those who have less. I have no hesitation in saying that I support the pleas made by all those people who wrote those letters to me. I have no hesitation in saying that I join my leader, Senator Button, in opposing this legislation. I express my disgust and regret that members of the Government who have also received copies of all the correspondence from the respective states do not have the intestinal fortitude to stand up in this chamber and put a case on behalf of those people who have written to them.

SPEECH.PARA: My second point concerns the complaints about demonstrators in the Parliament House galleries and outside. I refer honourable senators to a communication sent out by the Meat and Allied Trades Federation of Australia which states, among other things:
This Federation believes it is the responsibility of the Senate to ensure that important Bills of this nature are not rushed through the House-

Dear Senator,Re: Deregulation of Trading Hours in A.C.T.

This Association has been informed that the Fraser Government intends to push the deregulation of trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory through both Houses of Parliament before the end of the present period of sitting.
It is apparently being done as part of some omnibus legislation in a last-minute effort to avoid the proper consideration which such legislation would receive in the Senate after 1 July.
The drastic effect of such legislation on increasing unemployment cannot be under-estimated.
Already, the retail and wholesale industry has suffered a net loss of 39,400 full-time jobs in the period from 1972 to 1979.

Athough there was an increase in casual jobs in the industry over this period, a large proportion of these jobs went to full-time school-children. For example, in August, 1978, of 75,000 full-time school-children who held a job, 72 per cent were employed in the retail and wholesale industry and they averaged 7.2 hours of work each week. The participation rate of these school-children in the work force increased from 4 per cent in 1971, to 20 per cent in 1978.

These statistics clearly illustrate that massive numbers of school-students earning pocket money as casual employees are taking the jobs of full-time shop assistants who have a much greater economic need to work.
Because the retail and wholesale industry employs over 20 per cent of the workforce, these trends have undoubtedly swollen the ranks of persons registered as unemployed by a measurable degree.

Furthermore, the expansion of part-time and casual employment in retailing at the expense of full-time jobs is quite insane when one realises that 81.5 per cent of the unemployed are seeking full-time work (April, 1981 figures).

Moreover, an increasing proportion of employees with part-time jobs are seeking more hours of work. For example, in February, 1980, there were 142,900 part-time employees seeking more hours of work. Of these, 52,400 were seeking a full-time job.

If trading hours in the Capital Territory are deregulated, full-time employment in the retail industry will largely disappear-as has happened in the United States where no restrictions on retail trading exist.

It should also be remembered that if trading hours are deregulated in Canberra, it would be difficult to resist the flow-on pressure which the giant retail chains would exert in Victoria and New South Wales.

Two case studies have been done by the Union on retail stores to show the effect on employment when Saturday afternoon trading is introduced. In one of these stores, full-time employment fell by 25 per cent, in the other it fell by 18 per cent.
The consequent pattern of employment in these stores was as follows:
Number of employees
Full-time Casual Total
Store 1 25 75 100 Store 2 28 53 81
If such figures were repeated across the whole retail industry, the effect on employment would be disastrous.

After a full investigation on the effects of longer retail trading, the Standing Committee on Development of the A.C.T. House of Assembly recommended to the Minister 18 months ago that trading hours in the Capital Territory not be extended for at least five years.
We therefore urge that any legislation which is introduced in the Senate be amended so that trading hours in the Capital Territory remain unaltered.
Yours sincerely, J. de BRUYN, National Secretary-Treasurer

Dear Senator Mulvihill,
Repeal of Trading Hours Ordinances ACT

This Federation represents 6,000 retail butchers throughout the Commonwealth and members view with concern the current Bill introduced by the Government seeking to repeal the Trading Hours Ordinance for the ACT.

The purpose of the Bill is to completely abolish any regulated trading hours for the ACT and our concern is mainly directed to the repercussive effects of the introduction of unrestricted trading hours in the ACT and its consequential effects on other States with particular reference to New South Wales and Victoria. Already in the ACT, we have unrestricted trading hours for the sale of food and its effect on the Meat Industry in terms of small business has been of major concern to this organisation.

Small retail butchers are now required to trade at least 6 days per week and in some circumstances, on Sunday and the consequential labour cost has seen 20 retailers forced out of business in the past 3 years and other retailers are finding it difficult to continue trading with the employment of labour and competing with large supermarket chains who are not employing labour over the weekends or in the evenings and use only a checkout system.

This Federation believes it is the responsibility of the Senate to ensure that important Bills of this nature are not rushed through the House without proper consideration of the effects of such legislation. It is our belief that it is the responsibility of the Senate to be responsive to the interests of small independent business in Australia and we consider the Bill has been introduced with indecent haste and requires further consideration by those groups of businessmen affected by the Bill.

I would emphasise that there has been no consultation whatsoever with various Industry Groups in Canberra and it is important for the Senate to monitor the effects of any legislation before its adoption.

It is well-known that the Bill is supported by major retail groups who see the introduction of this Bill as an objective means of influencing State Governments, particularly in Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria, to extend trading hours to the detriment of small business. It is in this area that the Bill requires careful consideration by the Senate.

I would respectfully ask you, as a Senator, to seek the deferment of this Bill which would repeal the Trading Hours Ordinance for the ACT to enable further consultation and reports to be submitted on the overall effect of such repeal.

It is our belief that the repeal of this Ordinance has been linked with other Government expenditure and the monetary effect of this Ordinance cannot be measured against the economic effect it will have on consumers and the small business interest throughout Australia. For this reason, we seek the deferment of this Bill and ask your support in such action.
Yours faithfully, W. J. PATTERSON Secretary

TALK.START.PARA: —The crux of the matter is that there was a diminishment of 39,000 jobs in this industry between 1972 and 1979. Some people talk about feather bedding, but they must realise that for every redundancy created a taxpayer goes on to some form of unemployment benefit. I suppose the arch apostle of the economic theory that has been practised here has been the British Prime Minister. In January I was in Wales at the time that the British Prime Minister got the idea that the Welsh steel industry was overloaded. All she did by her actions was to boost up the number of unemployment benefit recipients. This is what will happen in the Capital Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: I say with all due respect to Senator Reid, the new senator for the Australian Capital Territory, that I was amazed and disgusted when I sat in my room and listened to her assessment. She had some sympathy for the small trader. I could tell by the verbiage she used that she had a little doubt about the matter, but she did not say one word about the rank and file members of the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Association who visited this House. I say to her respectfully: 'Senator, if you want to go places you will have to try to have some of the warmth and compassion that Senator Ryan has. I wonder what will happen when Senator Reid goes out on the soapboxes prior to the next election and meets some of the young men and women who at an early stage of their life have no income other than that obtained in their employment. They would not be like the honourable senator who is a member of a rich profession. Those young men and women are not in a rich profession.

The honourable senator had the temerity in the first question she asked in this chamber to defend a magistrate in a Canberra court. He came from a well-paid profession. But the honourable senator is not a bit interested in the rank and file members of the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Association. I hope that at the next election members of that association heckle the honourable senator wherever she goes. She shows no milk of human kindness about what will happen to these people. There is no question about that. Some 80 per cent of people unemployed want permanent work, not casual work. The honourable senator, by her indifference, has stamped herself as being like the Prime Minister who wants to grind these people into the humiliations that are part and parcel of unemployment.

It is all very well to talk about the Australian Capital Territory and people earning reasonable and high salaries. If the honourable senator were to mingle with the masses outside she would be a better senator. I hope she takes that advice. If I did not give her this advice now I know that Senator Ryan would. Senator Reid deserves all that I have said. I think it is an utter disgrace that she represents the Australian Capital Territory. She is a woman, yet she does not have an atom of kindness for these people who will be dispossessed. I note that the Minister for Social Security is looking at me, but this is the place to give people what they ask for. If Senator Reid wants equality of sex by becoming a member of this chamber she will get it. I know that if Senator Ryan were here she would endorse to the hilt all that I have said, as would Senator Melzer. If we are kept here to the early hours of the morning every Minister and senator opposite will cop all the spleen that I can dish out. What I have said is nothing compared with what they will get tomorrow.

I want honourable senators to know once and for all that a lot of tripe is spoken about democracy. We must look at what the Government has done in the last 48 hours and at the way it has put the boot in and rushed through legislation. There will be a multitude of disputes concerning the engagement of people and the conversion from permanent employment to casual employment. The Government will win this one, but nothing is contained in any parts of the legislation about the form of arbitration that will be adopted. Every master retailer will want to get even with somebody who spoke up for his fellow workers. The document that has been incorporated from the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Association refers to the large supermarket chains and what effect the changes will have on small businessmen. Senator Reid said that she had some sympathy for the small businessmen. Senator Chipp sounded the tocsin. It may be that Senator Reid believes in small businessmen, but she does not care about trade unionists. I suppose it is not in her makeup to do so. She does not believe in unions at all. I wonder whether Senator Reid, in her legal career, ever appeared for them.

In conclusion I say that the way Senator Reid has raised the matter is a disgrace. I will be very surprised if Senator Chaney or any other Minister who replies to this debate will show some courtesy and tell Brian O'Neal, the Secretary of the New South Wales branch, or Mr de Bruyn, the National Secretary of the union, how they should handle the dispute. The dispute will not be like those connected with shunters in marshalling yards or employees in coal mines. In a lot of these cases the employee will not win. Members of the Government are not offering me any advice on how jobs will be protected. I say to Senator Reid and to other honourable senators that the chamber is a place in which you express your feelings. I have never been one not to do so. That is why I have never had ulcers or a bad heart. I get what I have to say out of my system. I make this statement quite definitely: Honourable senators opposite should not talk to me any more about industrial relations. I have said before that there may be occasions when rank and file unionists take a lead from their paid officials and say that others are not battling hard enough. In this case I know of the courtesy in dialogue that Mr O'Neal and other people always extend to employers. But this issue is not one of fighting the employers; it is one that has been aided and abetted by that man Sir Phillip Lynch, a man who came out of the working class and sold his soul to become a Minister and get a knighthood. Thank goodness I do not want a knighthood; I am never likely to get one. I am still part of where I was born and grew up. Little can be said about him. He knows my view on him only too well because I have given him a few letters. I conclude on this note: This is one of the worst situations I have ever witnessed. I differ with Senator McLaren in that I reckon that the Prime Minister is loyal to his class because he came out of the squattocracy; but Sir Phillip Lynch came out of the working class and he has ratted on it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not intended to enter the debate on the Commonwealth Functions (Statutes Review) Bill at the second reading stage because I had understood that the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) had given some sort of an assurance that the clause to which Senator Mulvihill, who preceded me, addressed himself-namely, clause 90 of the Bill-would not be proclaimed until such time as the whole issue was referred to either a select committee or the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory for investigation and report, and subsequent legislative action by the Parliament. Senator Reid, in her remarks, stated that in principle she supported the decision on the deregulation of shop trading hours. She went on to make a number of other statements. Senator Reid is the Chairman of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory. She also suggested to the Minister that clause 90 of the Bill should not be proclaimed until such time as the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory was able to inquire into matters relevant to the implementation of the decision. That is not at all consistent with my understanding of the results of the discussions that have taken place over the last several days. I make it very clear to those honourable senators who are concerned about this matter that that sort of assurance is not worth the paper it is written on. The horse has bolted; the action has been taken. There is no remedy. The implementation will occur, but only after certain matters relevant to that implementation have proceeded. That is not good enough.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, in its November 1977 report, indicated its view on the question of legislation by Act or by ordinance. In Recommendation 116, which is to be found on pages 31 and 32 of the report, the Committee stated:

A review of events leading to the disallowance of the Evidence Ordinance 1971 and other Territory legislation indicates that neither the Legislature nor the Executive have formulated any clear guidelines for determing which Territory legislation ought to be made by Act and which ought to be made by Ordinance.
However, it went on to say:

Legislation for the Territories on matters of national importance, which, if enacted within geographical Australia, would be within the legislative powers of the Commonwealth Government, should be made by Act of Parliament. Legislation of this kind is of two classes:
It went into the first class. It defined the second class as:
. . . legislation on matters incidental to the exercise of the constitutional powers and which 'co-exists' with State legislation on similar matters.

The provision before us relating to the regulation of shop trading hours fits into that category. Therefore it ought to be the subject of a special Act of parliament, and certainly not part of an omnibus piece of legislation, such as the legislation which the Government has before the Senate today. Because of its nationwide ramifications, because a few Government Ministers want to lapse into Whitlamesque, make Canberra a social laboratory for the rest of Australia and deregulate shop trading hours at the behest of the giant interstate retailers, the Government is attempting to force this provision through as part of an omnibus piece of legislation and is not granting it the respect which it is due, namely, the introduction of a separate piece of legislation relating to this matter. In paragraph (d) of Recommendation 116 the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs stated:
Legislation which, in Australian States, would actually be made by an Act of State Parliament should normally be made by Ordinance.

It appears that there is a conflict between those two recommendations, but even if we accept the last recommendation, why did the Government not proceed by way of an ordinance to amend the trading hours ordinance so that the matter could come before the Parliament and be subject to the scrutiny of the Parliament. The only reason for the Government proceeding in this way, I suggest, is that it is not game enough to have the matter properly under the scrutiny of the Senate after 1 July. Of course, had it proceeded by ordinance, it would of necessity have had to have that ordinance placed on the table of the Senate and any senator would have been able to move for its disallowance.

The only other explanation is that the Government is committed to what it feels to be market forces. I regard this as a very serious matter. I hope that the Government understands that now and will understand it later. I regard this move as an attempt by at least one interstate retail chain to impose its will-this is one of the suggestions-upon the governments in Australia. The Managing Director of G. J. Coles and Co. Ltd stated in February of last year that he expected that Saturday afternoon trading, and possibly Sunday trading as well, would be a fact of life within the 1980s.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—He is on record as having said that. I heard one Government senator saying 'Hear, hear!' to that statement.
—That is quite correct. You should be able to trade at any time; not when the bully boys let you, but at any time.

—The senator from Queensland says that we should be able to trade at any time we like. The following question then arises: Does this mean that retailers can trade at any time that they like? Is that what the honourable senator is saying?
—Any business can operate at any time.

—Senator MacGibbon says that any business can operate at any time it likes. The facts of life are that if we deregulate shop trading hours we will not be consistent with market forces but will be throwing over to the interstate mainland retail giants and to the finance corporations which own or manage shopping complexes the authority to dictate trading hours.
—Rubbish!

—I will now prove to Senator MacGibbon that what I am saying is perfectly correct by pointing out that Lend Lease Corporation in this city manages a number of shopping complexes. As Senator Reid says, Canberra has a number of these shopping complexes. It manages the Boulevard, Cooleman Court, Monaro Mall and Woden Plaza. In 1980, when no shop trading legislation operated in Tasmania, Lend Lease also managed the Eastlands Shopping Centre. I have a letter addressed to Mr B. O'Connor, of O'Connor shoe stores, who leased a property in the Eastlands shopping complex which is managed by Lend Lease Corporation. Mr O'Connor did not wish to trade on Easter Saturday last year. I will quote to the Senate and for Senator MacGibbon's information what Lend Lease said to that retailer:

SPEECH.PARA: As an established tenant of this centre you are no doubt aware of the obligation to comply with trading hours as specified by the owners and managers and your failure to comply with those instructions is in effect a breach of that agreement.
The letter goes on to state:
Any future advices on trading hours which are ignored will be treated in a very serious nature. You must realise that your tenancy could be at risk in any similar situation.

If that is freedom of choice for retailers, I do not know what the meaning of freedom of choice is. What the Government is really doing is giving giant interstate retailers and finance companies such as Lend Lease Corporation an open slather to dictate its terms and to crush the small retailers. I will quote from another letter which I have received from a Mr G. Andre of Canberra. Presumably every other honourable senator has received the letter as well. He says:

As owners of retail businesses we are most concerned at the proposal of the Federal Government to deregulate shopping hours in the Australian Capital Territory. Particular concern is expressed at the following clause in our leases reading as follows 'the lessee will at all times during the term of the lease keep the demised premises open to trade during the usual business hours of the centre and conduct the lessee's business therein at all times in good faith and in accordance with the best method and in a reputable manner and will not permit or suffer to be committed any illegal or unlawful act on the demised premises.
The letter goes on to state:

This clause caused no concern whilst the hours of operation were subject to Government regulation as we were aware of our obligation. However, should your proposed legislation become law we would be at the mercy of the landlord who would dictate shopping hours.

I regard the action of the Government as a dereliction of duty. In fact, it is totally inconsistent with the attitude publicly expressed by the member for Denison in his capacity as Minister for the Australian Capital Territory. The shop assistants and small businesses in Tasmania tried to get the Government of that State to abandon the worst features of nineteenth century laissez-faire capitalism and to have regard to the wishes of others, not these sorts of companies I have mentioned-the Lend Lease Corporations of this world. Mr Hodgman said that his decisions were taken having regard to all aspects of the situation and that the principles of good government demanded that the interests of all sections of the community be taken into account-the employers that is, the retailers-shop assistants and the public. Deregulation denies and overrides the interests of the shopping public. It overrides the interests of the small lessee, the small businessman and certainly shop assistants. I would like Senator MacGibbon, if he is still of the same opinion, to deny what is here and now put in the record about the standover tactics that are being used by the firm which manages four of the shopping complexes in the Australian Capital Territory.

To save time, I will refer to the letter which deals with the opposition by small businessmen who are represented by the Meat and Allied Trades Federation of Australia. If any honourable senator has run a butcher shop-I have not, but I know a few people who have-he will know that it is hard yakka. These men have made a great contribution for many years. The Meat and Allied Trades Federation of Australia stated:
I would emphasise that there has been no consultation whatsoever with various industry groups in Canberra before this decision was taken.

Furthermore, the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Association said the same thing, that there was absolutely no consultation with it prior to this taking place. In fact it made submissions to the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly inquiry and had been given a firm undertaking by the Minister for the Capital Territory that the Government would do nothing about this, would not change the status quo until such time as there was proper consultation. The Government is changing the status quo now. It is no use having the consultations after the horse has bolted. That is not consultation about what ought or ought not occur. That is saying to the people concerned, to the small businessmen, to the shop assistants: 'There it is. It is going to come. How can you best cut your own throat?' That is what the Government is saying. 'You will have your throat cut. How best can we go about cutting it? Do you want it sliced quick smart or do you want a slow dying death?'

Lawyers draw up these leases which refer to 'demised premises'. I do not know what that means but certainly there will be a lot of demised premises around the place after deregulation occurs because, as every honourable senator ought to know, already there are too many shops in the Australian Capital Territory. When the giants take over and put on specials on Saturday afternoons, Sundays and whenever, what will occur? The shops will be empty. The Government will certainly have plenty of demised premises on its hands.

I am a supporter of the attitude of the Minister for the Capital Territory in respect of Anzac Day. I believe that Anzac Day is a day which should be properly observed. I understand that there might even be a move to disallow the Ordinance which the Minister for the Capital Territory proclaimed to ensure the proper observance of Anzac Day. However, what is the Government doing in respect of this matter? It is repealing the Trading Hours Ordinance which prevents shops being opened on Anzac Day because the Ordinance prevents shops being opened on any day specified in the Public Holidays Ordinance. On the one hand the Minister quite rightly is seeking the support of the people to ensure the observance of Anzac Day and on the other hand the Government is pressing through this legislation which will enable stores-big stores, small stores, any stores-to open all day every day, 365 days a year and 24 hours in each day if the shopkeepers so desire or if they are directed to open by the owners of the complex. It is in the interests of the owners of the complex if shops do open because, as Senator MacGibbon ought to know, if he saw Nationwide the other night in relation to the Indooroopilly shopping complex, the Westfield owned shopping complex-and I do not know whether this is a fact-some lessees appear to be frightened about their leases. The owners appear to be taking the cream off the top and, of course, for owners of a complex the longer a place is open the more hoot they get from the hardworking lessees. It is an extraordinary situation in which a government which calls itself a loyal Australian Government says to the shopkeepers, 'You can open on Anzac Day all day'. This Government which regards itself as being based on Christian principles is saying to the shopkeepers, 'You can open all day, Christmas Day, Easter Saturday, Good Friday and Easter Sunday'. This Government calls itself a loyal government of the Queen but shops can open on the Queen's Birthday, Canberra Day, Labour Day or any other day.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is shocking to open shops on the Labour Day holiday.

—That is right. This is one of the arguments that we put to the Labor Government in Tasmania. After a great deal of convincing it introduced the shop trading legislation and it abandoned its attitude, which did not fit very well, of market forces prevailing because it knew what that point meant. That Government was told. Let me tell the Senate that this is a matter which is regarded as very important not only by me but also by the small business associations. I have a telegram from the Retail Traders Association of New South Wales asking me to firmly oppose this provision. The Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Association, which has a large number of members, is also concerned about the effects which everyone knows will flow from this proposed change and that is the further casualisation of the retail trade, an increased rate of bankruptcies for small businessmen, the extra additional costs to the consumer but certainly not in the short term because the giants will see to that. When they have got a monopoly control of the market they will see that the costs will rise and then they will amortise the losses that they have made in the short term.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a government whose supporters talk about support for the family. What is this move going to do to those families of the workers involved in the retail trade, not only the families of the shop assistants but also the families of the small businessmen? Because of the restriction on the time for debate I will not canvass the other matters in this omnibus legislation with which I am concerned and not only things that are in it but also things that are not in it including some things that were mentioned such as the Bendigo Ordnance Factory and also the fact that the Government is not going to proceed with the operation of the Broadcasting Information Office. I refer honourable senators to the speech I made last night, at what time I know not, and in which I expressed my belief that successive governments have pushed into the background this whole question of the monitoring of the standards of quality and excellence and standards of common decency and good taste in broadcasting and television. They have done so by limiting the amount of money that is available to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in respect of research. Maybe that decision has been taken by the Tribunal, but the Government has not told me who has taken that decision. The Government has now stated that it is not going to proceed with the Broadcasting Information Office. The issue of the monitoring of the standards of excellence and the quality of broadcasting and television is uppermost in the minds of the Australian viewing and listening public. I believe the Government's intention to abolish the very office to which an ordinary person could have registered a complaint and which was designed to investigate that complaint is reprehensible in respect of this matter.

I am just sorry that the time of the Senate is so short that I am unable to expand on this issue. I believe the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), who is in the chamber, should not get up and in a platitudinous way say: 'Yes, we will agree with Senator Reid.' Senator Reid has asked that the proposed section not be proclaimed until the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory has had an opportunity to inquire into the matters relevant to the implementation of the decision. In other words, does the Government intend to cut its throat or is it going to drown the people in coldcream. This suggestion has come from the chairman of the Joint Committee of the Australian Capital Territory, who said when she started that in principle she supported deregulation. I hope that what the Minister might say in the Committee stage is that the Government intends not to have that part of the legislation proclaimed until such time as the whole issue has been referred for investigation and report and until a substantive piece of legislation can be submitted to the Parliament and determined in a positive manner and until such time as that takes place clause 90 of the legislation, when enacted, will not be proclaimed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine confessed that he had never run a butcher's shop, but he rather carefully butchered the logic of his argument with that rather distorted and convoluted exposition of the landlord and tenant agreement, relating that to the deregulation of trading hours. With the greatest of respect, I say to the honourable senator that that is a complete irrelevance. I do not doubt that there are some points that are grossly unfair in the relationship between some tenants and some landlords, but it is an absurd simplification of the situation to say that, because a tenant has to pay a percentage of his turnover to a landlord, the solution to that problem is to hold back the number of trading hours. That is a nonsense. With respect, that was what the honourable senator's argument was. I would have second thoughts about the commercial judgment of the tenant who entered into that agreement in the first place and I do not really believe that it is the business of the Government to come in and interfere with the market-place in that way, because one of the worst operators in the market-place, even worse than those tenants, is the Government itself. The Government simply does not have the discrimination and the judgment to get involved in those sorts of things. Surely the answer to Senator Harradine's problem is to build more shops and give an opportunity to those traders to hire other premises or to let them raise the money and build other premises themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite bluntly, what has been going on here is a defence for the union position once again on the monopoly of labour. That is all that this deregulation argument is about. If, in some way, through deregulation we can limit the control of the unions over what is going on in Australia, we will be doing a great service to the people of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Union bashing!

—It is not union bashing; it is community bashing by people like the honourable senator. Australia needs to develop and it will not develop while we have penalty rates. Today we see the problems which have arisen from short-sighted, selfish union policy. We see a lack of skilled tradesmen for the great developmental projects in Australia today. We see a shortage of those skilled tradesmen because the unions have pushed for rises and they have eliminated the relativities for skill which formerly existed in the Australian market. They have pushed for penalty rates for people working on Saturday nights, on Sundays and on public holidays. Until we get away from those penalty rates and get back to paying a differential for skill, the Australian economy will be in trouble and we will have to import people to do those skilled jobs. The argument we have heard in this chamber is just a perversion supporting the vested interests of the unions. They have a cosy arrangement whereby they want to monopolise the supply of all labour in the country. I support emphatically what the Government is doing here to free the market-place, to get government and union control out of it and let the water find its own level.

SPEECH.PARA: My final point for those honourable senators on the other side of the chamber who do not understand the simple facts of economic life is that it is a far easier business for an owner-entrepreneur to compete with a giant like Coles than the other way round because the overheads of the owner-entrepreneur are far lower and they always will survive against the giants.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented and I wish to make a personal explanation. Senator MacGibbon said that my argument against this deregulation proposal was that certain leases included provisions which required the lessee to pay certain amounts of money to the owner of the particular property as a percentage of the takings and that the best way to prevent that sort of exploitation was to have deregulation. I read from a letter from Lend Lease Corporation Pty Ltd, which manages five shopping centres in the Australian Capital Territory. I will table that letter if that is requested. The letter was sent by that Corporation to a lessee of one of its shopping complexes in Hobart, Tasmania, last year. In that letter, the Corporation threatened the lessee with a termination of his lease if the lessee did not obey the instructions of the owners and managers of the complex in regard to shop trading hours. The point simply is that deregulation means that the question of shop trading hours will be dictated, not by the retail industry, not by the consumer, not by the shop assistants union, not by the small businessman, but by people like these finance corporations who have control of these shopping complexes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it a Bill entitled Commonwealth Functions (Statutes Review) Bill 1981. That Bill incorporates a number of measures which are part of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, the results of which were announced in the Parliament on 30 April. The matters which are before the Senate in this Bill, together with the other matters dealt with in the Review of Commonwealth Functions, have been a matter of public knowledge now for some six weeks and have been the subject of considerable discussion. As was said in the second reading speech to this Bill, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) announced some 350 decisions aimed at transferring to the private sector and to the States functions more appropriately performed by them and rationalising functions which properly belong to the Commonwealth. The overall objective of the review is to establish conditions under which there can be increased opportunities for all and better care for those in need. As the Prime Minister said in his statement, the immediate aim of the review was to streamline and to fine down Commonwealth operations.

SPEECH.PARA: The review was announced immediately after the Government was re-elected last year and it commenced in a environment in which it was quite clear that the great bulk of Australians is favourably inclined to having a leaner government, one which is less wasteful, not one which is less generous to the individual Australian but one which is less involved in regulation and less involved in spending money on the business of government administration. With that end in view, the Government set out to reduce duplication to ensure that the functions which were properly performed by the States and by the private sector were performed by them. We believe that is in accord with the wishes of the people of this country.

The debate has been fairly wide-ranging and it would be a matter of regret to Government senators that, because of the pressure of the program, not many have been able to take part in the debate. The debate has, of course, ranged well beyond the measures which are provided for in this Bill. For example, one honourable senator referred to the arrangements for education, with the proposal that there should be the reintroduction of tuition fees for students undertaking second degrees and diplomas. I mention to the Senate and to those people who may be listening to the broadcast of this debate that in fact that particular measure is one of many which are not the subject of this legislation. Those who were listening to that part of the debate would be hard-pressed to realise that what we were discussing was not a proposal to introduce universal fees, but to introduce fees only for those students who are undertaking a second degree.

I would think that many Australians would feel that, if those other Australians who have had the good fortune to obtain a degree or some form of tertiary or other qualification at public expense decided to pursue a change of career or to pursue studies of a different sort, they might be entitled to make some contribution towards the cost of that education. There is a limit to the extent to which any of us as individuals are entitled to demand from our fellow Australians perpetual subsidies. In that sort of area I think it is important that the line be drawn somewhere, and the Government has drawn it with respect to one's obtaining an initial degree qualification. I think that is a good example of how the debate on all these measures can get out of kilter. The fact is that, if 350 decisions are made aimed at reducing the scope of government, it is inevitable that some people will object. They will object in terms which are often strenuous and in terms which ignore the broader realities with which the Government has to deal. I believe that the legislation, which has its place as part of the Government's move to reduce the size of government in Australia, is legislation which will have the general approval of the Australian people.

A great deal of the debate has focused on one relatively small aspect of the legislation, and that is the question of trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory. I suppose that to many people around Australia a good deal of that debate might have been regarded as being focused on something which is of bare relevance to them because it affects only the Australian Capital Territory. Of course, it is a matter which is seen to be of great importance here. I stress that the decision with respect to shopping hours is one which was taken within a range of decisions which looked at the question of government regulation generally. It is not a matter of that area of regulation being singled out solely as being something warranting government attention. In fact, a good number of the Government's regulatory activities came under examination during the Review of Commonwealth Functions. We have endeavoured to reduce the degree of Commonwealth involvement as far as possible. The abolition of the Prices Justification Tribunal was one significant step. The rationalisation of industry assistance advisory functions in and between departments was another. The Government measures which have been signficantly debated in the Parliament and outside to move towards less regulation of the airline industry and to an exposing of the instruments of regulation of the airline industry to the public gaze are another very important step.

The Industries Assistance Commission is to investigate modifications and improvements to the customs by-law system. Those who have sought to examine that area of government activity and control might well say that that is an area which badly requires modification and improvement because of the complexity which has developed over the many years of its operation. It is in that sort of context that the decision was taken to abolish rent control in the Australian Capital Territory and to deregulate shopping hours. Nobody on this side of the chamber will be at all apologetic about the general principle of reducing the amount of government regulation with which we are faced in this country.

A good deal of representation has been made since that decision was announced. The Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Hodgman, has received deputations from groups representing traders at two of the major shopping centres in Canberra, the Belconnen Mall and the Woden Plaza. In addition, he has spoken to groups from all areas of the retail industry and has asked his Department to consult with these and other groups on the implementation of the decision which was announced on 30 April. The groups which have been involved in discussions with the Minister or his Department or with both include the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Association, the Australian Association of Independent Businesses, the Canberra Chamber of Commerce, the Confederation of ACT Industry, and the Trades and Labour Council of the Australian Capital Territory. It is true that these groups, in the main, have opposed the decision, although the Chamber of Commerce and the Confederation of Industry support the philosophy behind the decision taken by the Government. Following those consultations, the Minister has agreed to recommend that proclamation of the commencement of the relevant provisions of the Bill should be scheduled for three to four months' time to allow a smooth transition to deregulation. All groups certainly have supported the idea that there should be a delay in the implementation to permit that smooth transition.

The Minister has also agreed to establish a monitoring committee, which will be a widely representative committee that will monitor the effects of deregulation. That is important, I think, in the context of the sort of matters raised by Senator Harradine in the debate in which he expressed concern about the effects of deregulation. In fact, the monitoring committee will be a body which will be able to keep an eye on the possibility of the sort of developments suggested by Senator Harradine as certain to occur. What might follow from that is a matter for government decision at the time, but Senator Harradine has flagged certain fears and the Minister has put in place a committee which can monitor the effects of deregulation and report to him if the dangers of which Senator Harradine is concerned develop.

There has been support of deregulation, principally from large retailers. A degree of horror was expressed in this place at the prospect of Canberra shoppers being faced with the dreadful possibility of there being specials available to them on Saturday afternoons and Sundays. I suggest that plenty of shoppers in Canberra would quite welcome the idea that they will have shops available to them on the weekends and that those shops might be seeking to obtain their custom by offering specials. I think the shock and horror suggested in the debate in this place will not be very representative of the consumers of Canberra, who would like to have the benefit of that sort of activity on the part of retailers. The other matter raised was that of the position of families. I would have thought that many families would welcome the availability of shopping hours at different times of the day, on different days of the week and at hours which they can take advantage of as a family group, whether it is husband and wife or parent and children. The support, as I understand it, for late night shopping in Canberra and in other parts of Australia is evidence of the public demand for greater access to retail trade.

There is evidence from a recent Bureau of Industry Economics report that in fact flexible trading hours would increase total demand for retail services. This will have the effect of decreasing the increased costs which might be involved in having labour available at different times of the day. All in all, the Government is of the view that it is highly desirable that this sort of deregulation should occur. It is in the public interest. In the end it is the public interest which must determine these matters, not sectional interest. The public interest in this matter is principally the interest of those consumers who are entitled to access to a variety of stores at a variety of times that suit their convenience and not the convenience of proprietors or unionists. Rather, it is the convenience of those who wish to shop that ought to be the major determinant of when shops are open. One could not hope to get the sort of cosy agreement which sometimes occurs in this place in regard to legislation. Indeed, most members of the public are suprised to find that there is little or no disagreement on the great bulk of legislation that goes through the Parliament. But this Bill and many elements of its represent a difference in attitude between the Government and the Opposition. The Government is opting for less regulation and less interference. That is something which many honourable senators opposite find disagreeable.

Senator Reid has been mentioned in dispatches during the course of the debate as well as making a contribution to the debate herself. She raised the question of the role of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory. Mr Hodgman has agreed that there should be a reference to the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory with respect to this matter. The Joint Committee would be required to report on the process of deregulation of trading hours and the steps for the implementation of the decision. That process is one which I think Senator Harradine indicated he would not find satisfactory; it did not go to the point he raised. But the important thing about that proposal which was put forward by Senator Reid and which has been accepted by the Minister is that it provides another avenue in addition to the monitoring committee established by the Minister to ensure that if there were to develop the sort of problems and abuses which some of those who are opposed to the legislation suggested would develop, they would be immediately brought to the attention of the Minister and the Government which could then consider what action was appropriate in the light of those abuses.

I make that statement not believing that abuses will occur but simply to calm the fears of those who with equal certainly believe that they will. I say to them that this legislation in no way puts it beyond the power of the Government to intervene in any situation in which it appears that intervention is required in the public interest. I commend this legislation to the Senate. I believe that in those areas where there is a common cause in this chamber on the need for government interevention, not least in many of the areas which are the concern of my own portfolio responsibilities in social security, we do in fact have a common interest in reducing the amount of government which is devoted to non-essential items.

If we are to make a better effort in areas of concern to senators such as Senator Cavanagh and Senator Peter Baume, in building more houses for Aboriginals and spending more on Aboriginal health services; if we are to be concerned about the situation of pensioners who require supplementary assistance to perhaps a greater extent than they receive it now-whatever our concerns in making a greater contribution to the public good-it is important that we minimise the Government's contribution in those areas where it is not necessary. It goes without saying that with 350 decisions being taken, there will be differences of opinion. There would not be one decision which would not be opposed somewhere in the Australian community but I believe that the broad line followed by the decisions is right in the national interest and will equip us as a government to do better those things which only we as a government can do.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of the Senate, I explain what the Opposition intends to do. In addition to voting against the Bill in its entirety, the Opposition will be calling a number of divisions-sometimes on sections of the Bill and in one instance on a specific clause-in order to give those Government senators who have the wit to see the foolishness of some of the proposals, and the courage to cross the floor and vote against specific provisions, the opportunity to do so. I am less confident that any of them will have both of those attributes.

SPEECH.PARA: If it is satisfactory to the Committee, the Opposition will oppose clauses 3 to 89, taken together, and divide on them. It will oppose and divide on clause 90. It will oppose Part IV in its entirety and divide on it. It will move together a number of amendments to Part VI. A division will be called for on Part VI. There will be a division on Part XVIII, which proposes the abolition of the Prices Justification Tribunal.

With respect to clauses 3 to 89, it appears that a defensible case can be mounted in respect of some of the individual 87 propositions, but given the time constraints which the Government has imposed upon the Parliament, the very limited time which the Opposition has had to consider these propositions and, most importantly, the fact that the overwhelming majority of the proposals in the 86 clauses are not by any reasonable standard defensible, the Opposition intends to oppose clauses 3 to 89 collectively and will seek a division on the issue.
Clauses 1 and 2-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clauses 3 to 89-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I explained earlier, although the Opposition is opposing, in fact, all the clauses in the Bill, it will explicitly oppose clauses 3 to 89 and will push its opposition to the point of division.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the clauses be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 90 (Repeal).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this Committee stage I wish to place on record my opposition to the provision in this clause to deregulate shopping hours in the Australian Capital Territory. The case for opposition to this provision has been very ably put in the debate on the motion for the second reading by my colleague, Senator Mulvihill. Indeed, there is very little I can add to the case he made.
—A man of the people.

—A man of the people indeed. Senator Harradine also argued very ably that deregulation of shopping hours in the Australian Capital Territory is bad news for the small business people, for the shop-assistants whose jobs are disappearing at a rapid rate anyway-the disappearance of those jobs will be accelerated by this proposal-and, of course, ultimately for the consumers, the ordinary shoppers in the Australian Capital Territory because they will lose the services offered by the small shopkeepers as they are forced out of business by this measure. They will lose the services of the permanent, properly trained shop-assistants who will be forced out of their jobs to be replaced by temporary casuals.

SPEECH.PARA: I say too that this provision is just another example of the contempt with which the Fraser Government treats the Australian Capital Territory and of the incompetence of the Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Michael Hodgman. This provision is opposed by most people living and working in the Australian Capital Territory and is supported, as far as I know, by nobody living and working in the Australian Capital Territory. I understand that Senator Reid supported the provision so I must exclude Senator Reid from my remarks. Certainly, I have received no submissions in support of deregulation. I understand that some interstate big business interests which run large chain stores believe it would be to their advantage to be able to stay open of a Saturday afternoon and force the small shopkeepers out of business, but they have not approached me. On the other hand, I have had hundreds of representations from people who work in the retailing business or who have invested their livelihoods into small shops and who rightly fear that this deregulation will be against their interests.

I can only urge honourable senators opposite to consider at this stage what we are asking them to do. We are asking them to vote against a provision which nobody in the Australian Capital Territory, with the exception of Senator Reid, wants. The provision was never the result of consultation with the elected representatives of the Australian Capital Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —You know that is a lie.
—I raise a point of order. The hand that rocks the cradle rules the world. The honourable senator said that Senator Ryan was telling lies. That is unparliamentary and he should withdraw.
—I withdraw. It was an untruth.

—The truth of the matter is that most people living and working in the Australian Capital Territory and most people whose livelihood is tied up with retailing businesses in the Capital Territory are opposed to this measure. The interests that will be served by this measure are not local. The Minister, with his usual contempt, did not consult the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly and the elected representatives of this Parliament; nor did he consult the trade union movement or the shopkeepers' associations. There is no reason at all to support this provision. There is every reason, I suggest, to oppose it. I urge honourable senators sitting opposite to act in the interests of the Australian Capital Territory citizens and oppose this measure. They should do so as there is no Australian Capital Territory legislative body to do so.

—I recognise that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) who was in the chamber earlier does not represent the Minister for the Australian Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) in this place and therefore may not have fully stated the situation. Certainly he ignored three major points which were made during the second reading debate. I ask the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner), who is at the table: Precisely what are the guarantees that have been made by the Minister in respect of this clause?

—Let me refer to the several matters which were raised. I deal firstly with those raised by Senator Ryan. Without entering into the debate about the principle of regulation of shopping hours I point out that in regard to the question of consultation with groups within the Australian Capital Territory the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) received deputations from groups representing traders at two of the major shopping centres in Canberra, the Belconnen Mall and Woden Plaza. In addition, the Minister has spoken to groups from all areas of the retail industry and asked his Department to consult with those other groups on the implementation of the decision. The groups concerned are the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Association, the Australian Association of Independent Businesses, the Canberra Chamber of Commerce, the Confederation of Australian Capital Territory Industry and the Trades and Labour Council of the Australian Capital Territory.
—Oh Tony, don't.

—I thought these would have been interesting to Senator Harradine. All these groups have opposed the decision, although the Chamber of Commerce and the Confederation of Industry support the philosophy behind the decision. As a result of those consultations the Minister has agreed to recommend that proclamation of the commencement of the relevant provisions of this Bill be scheduled in three to four months time in order to allow a smooth transition to deregulation. All groups have supported that approach. In addition, the Minister, at the suggestion of members and of interested persons, will establish a widely representative committee to monitor the effects of deregulation. As to the specific question which Senator Harradine asked, the Government's decision is in line with its philosophy to stand away from the question of regulation of shopping hours in the Australian Capital Territory and has provided for the smooth implementation of that process in the way in which I have just outlined.
—I am more confused now because earlier something was stated about reference to the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory. Can the Minister explain what that meant?

—I believe that the question of the monitoring committee has been refined more closely. Following discussions with the Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Hodgman, and others there will be a reference to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the Australian Capital Territory. The Joint Committee would be required to report on the process of deregulation of shopping hours and steps for implementation of that decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to try to analyse precisely what we have been told. As I see it we are being told nothing. We are being told that the deregulation will occur in any event. The groups will be brought together and they will have some say as to how they will cut their own throats. That is what it appears to me to be. Let me make it perfectly clear that there was no consultation whatsoever with the retailers, the shop assistants and the public about this question before the decision was made. There was none whatsoever. That is in contradistinction to the publicly stated attitude of the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) who stated that the principles of good government demand that the interests of the retailers, the shop assistants and, not less, the shopping public should be taken into account when the government determines these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: We are being told by the Minister that there is now no movement at all by the Government. We are told that it will not backtrack on its headlong attitude on this matter. The Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) totally ignored the evidence that I produced to the Senate to the effect that deregulation will have the effect of ensuring that managers of shopping complexes will have the say in respect of shop trading hours. He ignored the document from which I read from the Lend Lease Corporation which stated quite bluntly what Lend Lease would do if a particular retailer, small businessman or lessee did not comply with trading hours as specified by the owners and managers. I repeat, for the information of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner)-he was not in the chamber, from memory-what Lend Lease said. It wrote:
Any future advices on trading hours which are ignored will be treated in a very serious nature. You must realise that your tenancy could be at risk in any similar situation.

This statement comes from the very company which manages the Boulevard, Cooleman Court, Monaro Mall and Woden Plaza. It is all very well for the Minister to say the monitoring committee will have a look at that matter. What a lot of nonsense! What will the monitoring committee do? Will an ordinance be introduced and regulations commenced when the Government is committed against regulations?

The second matter relates to the Minister's comment about having these monitoring committees to, as he says, report on the process of deregulation. This totally ignores what will happen to the jobs of shop assistants in the meantime and, more importantly, what will happen to the opportunities for full time jobs in the retail trade.

Let me refer to G. J. Coles and Co. Ltd, a company which is behind the push for open slather trading. Let me show what has happened in Coles in Queensland. There, the percentage of those employed full time in stores which open all day Saturday has dropped markedly. In regard to the employment of union members in Coles New World supermarkets in Queensland where six day trading, Monday to Saturday inclusive occurs, the full time percentage is 6.4 per cent, the part time percentage is 0.9 per cent, the casual percentage is 65.1 per cent and night fillers constitute 17.6 per cent. In those Coles supermarkets in Queensland which trade for five and a half days a week, the full time percentage is 21.5 per cent, part time 0.2 per cent, casual, 60.9 per cent, and night fillers, the same, 17.4 per cent. Those figures show the comparison. In the seven stores that trade all day on Saturday, there is a drop of more than 5 per cent in the number of full time employees compared with the stores that trade for five and a half days a week.

The situation is not only leading to the casualisation of the retail trade in closing off job opportunities for young unemployed looking for full time work but also providing for an increase in the participation rate of school children in the work force. It may come as a surprise to honourable senators that, whereas in 1972, the participation rate of full time school students in the paid work force was something like 4 per cent, the participation of full time students now in the paid work force is between 26 per cent and 35 per cent. It is extraordinary that we have a situation in which the Government, on top of this casualisation, is now attempting to deregulate shop trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory and worsen the situation for unemployed youth seeking full time work in this city. It is just not on. I regard this as a regrettable circumstance. As I said in my speech during the second reading debate, certain people are seeking to make Canberra a social laboratory for their commercial experiments. Certain major interstate retailers and international finance companies which own shopping complexes would like to see Canberra made the guinea pig for their commercial experiments.

The Minister for Social Security in his reply to the second reading debate mentioned the Bureau of Industry Economics. He referred to a paper from the Bureau of Industry Economics which was 'designed to elicit constructive comment and debate'. A number of statements are made in the paper. The first question that has to be asked about this paper is: Who commissioned it and what was the Bureau of Industry Economics doing involving itself in a sphere which is the proper sphere of State governments, namely, the regulation of retail trading hours? If the Government does not believe me when I say that this is a proper matter for State governments, let me refer to the statement by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) on 22 April 1981. He made comments about foreign investment proposals for British Petroleum and Caltex 'convenience stores'. We should not forget that these so-called convenience neighbourhood stores, which are to be tied to the oil company outlets, are on the horizon. This is part of the operation that is taking place. The Treasurer, in the final paragraph of his statement, said:

In taking its decision on this matter the Government noted that a number of State governments were not in favour of oil companies extending the range of products sold by service stations. They were concerned because the range of services offered by convenience stores has traditionally been provided by and would be in direct competition with the small business sector. The Government, however, considers that the regulation of such developments was more appropriately a matter for the States.

What business is it of the Bureau of Industry Economics to go into the question of shop trading hours? Furthermore, I noticed in the report of Estimates Committee H that four of the research staff of the Bureau of Industry Economics are engaged in a study of the impact of technological change in the service sector, with particular reference to the finance and retailing industry. If the razor gang wanted to cut something off the fat, why did it not cut that off the fat? There are half a dozen such inquiries. There has already been the Committee of Inquiry into Technological Change in Australia. If such an inquiry were to be established, it ought to be a tripartite inquiry-in other words, representatives of the retailers, the shop assistants union and other unions involved and perhaps a representative of the public. What right has the Bureau of Industry Economics to do that? Four full time, fat cat, well paid public servants are sitting in their ivory towers telling the retail trade what to do. If Sir Phillip Lynch-this is a group in his Department-had any concern for the taxpayers' money he should have chopped out that section for a start. That brings me to my final question of the Minister. I ask: Just what is the Government saving in this particular exercise? Can he tell us what it will save? The Government is not saving anything. The effect of this measure will have ramifications throughout the length and breadth of Australia. I guarantee that all honourable senators and all members in the other place will feel it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a quick question to ask of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner). As a member of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory, I am interested in the possibility that this matter will be referred to the Committee, of which Senator Reid is the chairperson. I ask why the matter was not referred to the Australian Capital Territory for report in the first place. Why do we now have to follow the decision of the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee?
—It is too late because Senator Reid, the Chairman, has already said that she favours deregulation. She is biased from the start.

—She may be, but that is countered by the fact that I heartily disagree. I see this move as resulting in a harsh and unnecessary increase in competition across extended hours that will enslave not only small businesses but also the employees therein. Let us consider the experience of past years when there was no regulation of trading hours. It meant that concerns in competition with one another stayed open for extended hours-long hours-right across the day and sometimes into the early hours of the morning because their opposition was open. That is what I mean by enslavement. I think that that has been covered. The question I am asking is: Why was the matter not referred by the Minister for the Capital Territory to the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory for it to carry out a thorough investigation? It seems to me that this is a plan on the part of the Liberal Party to casualise and privatise Australian society. If honourable senators look at what has happened in undeveloped countries and other places in South East Asia they will see exactly this philosophy at work. It is planned; it is deliberate. It seems to me that the thin edge of the wedge is being thrust at the Australian Capital Territory. I repeat: Why did the Minister not refer it to the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say a few words about clause 90. Both Senator Georges and Senator Harradine have sounded a very grave warning to every other State in Australia because the repeal of clause 90, which applies to the Australian Capital Territory, is, as my colleague Senator Georges said, just the thin end of the wedge. Senator MacGibbon let the cat out of the bag when he blamed payments to the trade unionists of penalty rates and holiday pay for the low profitability of big business. It is quite evident that this matter has been discussed in his party room. He has let the cat out of the bag by his remarks. We know what is already taking place in the supermarkets. In my State of South Australia there is very little permanent employment now. Married women are being employed for three hours a day and when their three hours are up another group of people is brought in for three hours, which takes those people up to the time when school comes out and then a group of school girls and boys are put on to do the work at lower rates of pay than casual adults get.

SPEECH.PARA: We must bear in mind that the people on casual rates do not get paid sick pay, holiday pay or long service leave. Nothing is built into their pay. The result is that things are not cheaper to the consumer but greater profits are being put into the pockets of big business. That is the whole crux of the matter. Senator MacGibbon conveniently let the cat out of the bag. That is the whole purpose of clause 90. It will be the thin end of the wedge. The Government will say to the people: 'It is operating in the Australian Capital Territory. Let us try it in the other States'. The trade union movement should heed the warning in this regard. Strength to its arm when it opposes it in the other States. It should not let itself be fooled by what the Government is doing here by usurping the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission by legislating in this fashion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will answer the points raised, in particular, by Senator Harradine and Senator Georges, who both touched on the same matter. Senator Georges sought information as to why the matter was not referred to the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory in the first place. Quite clearly-I think this answers substantially the points which Senator Harradine made-the Australian Capital Territory matter, along with all of those which are included in the total package of this legislation, as well as the report which was brought down on 30 April by the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee, was not made public. None of the matters included therein was made public for discussion in advance of the release of the report. That, of course, was an essential element of the report which was brought down.

SPEECH.PARA: The matters which Senator Harradine raised during this discussion-I understand from what he said that he also brought those matters forward in his speech on the motion for the second reading of the Bill-clearly would be the subject of suitable submissions by him and others to the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory and to the monitoring bodies. Consequently, we would expect that to occur. The outcome of the inquiries made by those two committees-the monitoring committee and the Australian Capital Territory Committee-would be a matter for Government decision following receipt of that report and appropriate consideration. Senator Harradine asked what savings would transpire as a result of the implementation of this decision. Clearly, there will be no savings. This is a matter of the implementation of philosophy in terms of the Government's approach to the question of shopping hours generally and the question of deregulation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, I wish to ask Senator Messner what he means by 'appropriate consideration'. Does he not agree with me that the increased casualisation of an already deeply casualised industry is a bad thing for the future full time job opportunities for young people in the city of Canberra? If he does, and if it is proven after the implementation of the deregulation that stores on a percentage basis are employing fewer full timers and more casuals, will the Government introduce regulations to govern shop trading hours? If it is found that small businessmen in shopping complexes-those who are owner-operators and cannot afford staff-are forced into slavery because of extended trading hours either by virtue of the dictates of the owners or managers of those shopping complexes or by the economic circumstances generated by the Government's decision, will that result in the Government introducing another ordinance or placing legislation before this Parliament?

—To answer that specific point, it seems that Senator Harradine may not have got clear the point that this Bill will not be proclaimed until some three or four months from now. Consequently, the implementation of the decision is at stake here. I would have thought that the matters which he has raised would appropriately be brought forward as representations to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —That does not answer the question I raised. What is the use of anybody raising a matter now when the Government has said that it intends to proceed with the deregulation? The only purpose of the monitoring committee and the reference to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the Australian Capital Territory, of which Senator Georges is a member, is to wield the axe in as gentle a way as possible. Their job is to cut the throats of the full time shop assistants and the small businessmen in as gentle a way as possible. That is precisely what the legislation means.

SPEECH.PARA: I have asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) an honest question. I want to know whether the Government will respond by an ordinance or by legislation if it is proved that this action will cause the casualisation of industry, as it has done in other places, and force a number of small businessmen out of business. Will the Government react if this happens? What will happen if stores open on Sundays or on public holidays? What will the Government do then? I do not know whether the Minister heard my speech in the second reading debate. However, I pointed out to the Minister who represents in this chamber the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) that I support in principle the Government's attitude that Anzac Day should be properly observed.

At the moment we are discussing proposed deregulation under clause 90 of the Bill. This clause proposes the repeal of the trading hours ordinances. The Trading Hours Ordinance 1962, which this legislation seeks to repeal, states that the shops in question cannot open on a day that is a public holiday in the Territory or in part of the Territory in which the shop is situated. The Trading Hours Ordinance that we are asked under this clause to repeal defines 'public holiday' as meaning, in relation to the Territory, or part of the Territory, a day that is observed as a public holiday in the Territory, or in the part of the Territory, by virtue of the Holidays Ordinance 1958.
