The Holidays Ordinance 1958 stipulates the holidays as New Year's Day, Australia Day, Good Friday, the Saturday following Good Friday, the Monday following Good Friday, Anzac Day, Labor Day, Christmas Day and Boxing Day, as I see it, and certainly Anzac Day.

What I want to know from the Government is how it considers itself to be consistent in its attitude when on the one hand it seeks to repeal the trading hours ordinances and to allow open slather trading, including trading on Anzac Day and all other holidays whether of religious significance or not, and then turns around and asks the Committee to support a proposition in respect of the proper observance of Anzac Day which, of course, in principle I would support. But how can I support a government which completely ignores that principle and says to the big retailers, to any retailers 'No matter about Anzac Day; make your quid out of them. As they come back from the march, grab them'?

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Harradine's further argument on this point, the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory is obviously a most important body and committee members as august as Senator Georges must contribute to the worth of its recommendations. If a decision takes into account the factors which Senator Harradine has outlined during his speech and does in fact bring down recommendations of the kind that he has mentioned, clearly the Government would have to take them into account in coming to a decision to implement a proposal. It is that which the Government has given an undertaking in connection with and, in terms of what the final decision will be, that is a matter for proper consideration by the Government at the appropriate time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise for having to take up the time of the Committee but this is an extremely important matter, as Government supporters will find out at a later stage from the people of Australia. What evidence was gained from the people of Canberra which indicated that they sought to have the repeal of the trading hours ordinances? In the second reading speech the Minister attempted to speak on behalf of the people of Canberra. I ask the Government: What survey was done by the Government in respect of this matter to find out the interests and the attitudes of the people of Canberra? I refer the Minister to a survey carried out in Tasmania in the division of Denison, the electorate of the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman). These are the official figures for the Tasmanian opinion poll. Of the people surveyed in the division of Denison, 22.5 per cent said they did not want any weekend trading at all. Only 58.6 per cent wanted Saturday morning only trading, and only 15.2 per cent wanted all day Saturday trading. Only 15.2 per cent of those surveyed by this professional survey in Denison, the electorate of the Minister for the Capital Territory, wanted all day Saturday trading, and only one per cent wanted all day Sunday trading.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Committee that it was the managing director of G. J. Coles Pty Ltd who said in February last year that it was his opinion that all day Saturday trading and probably all day Sunday trading as well would be a fact of life which would emerge during the 1980s. The Minister in his reply has ignored the other point that I have made, and I want him to address himself to it; that is, that all this Bill does is to encourage the use of casual school labour at the expense of full time jobs for young workers. Australian Bureau of Statistics figures indicate that as at January 1981 the participation rate of 16-year-olds attending school in the paid work force was 33.6 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is exploitation.

—Exactly. It is exploitation of children. This is a matter of vital concern to all States. Because Canberra is being used as the social laboratory for the experiments of these large commercial enterprises, with the acquiescence of the Government, I want to know what the Government intends to do about that situation if more school casuals are employed and if the full time jobs of workers are affected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I understand the argument that is running on the other side of the chamber, it is really an argument against any change at all in the Australian commercial world. Certainly there will be some change, but there has inevitably been change since time began. If we go around the cities, we will find very few lamplighters today in Sydney or Melbourne. It might come as a surprise to Senator Ryan, but there really are not people out with brushes over their shoulders. Those people have moved into other industries, and that is all that will happen here. Does the casualisation of labour that Senator Harradine has made such a thing out of really matter? Does anyone here really believe children are being exploited, that they are working for nothing? More importantly, are they being driven to work? They are not. They are doing it of their own volition, and I say good luck to them. They are displaying a bit of initiative to do something for themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: Since this matter has been raised, I should like to talk about it for a minute. Since the Government announced that it was looking at the idea of selling Trans-Australia Airlines-almost certainly it will go down that path, with great benefits to the Australian community-it is very interesting to look at the surveys which have been published and which show the support in the community for the selling of TAA. If honourable senators would look at the support as it is laid off against age groups, they would find the highest level of support in the under 45 years age group. The percentage increases as the group gets younger. It is rather bad news, I would suggest, for the Opposition because it shows very clearly that the old socialistic beliefs that the Government can do everything for people do not have the hold in the younger community that they had 20 to 30 years ago. I think that is a good thing. It shows that the Australian community is maturing.

One of the things that Senator Georges in his wandering statement a little while ago said was that underdeveloped countries are the only countries which have unrestricted trading. I may be wrong, but I think Senator Georges said something about Asian countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I did not say that at all.
—It may have been South East Asia. It may be that Senator Georges has trouble getting a visa to enter the United States of America. But if he goes to the United States--
—If you want to introduce coolie conditions in this country, go ahead.
—If Senator Georges does go to the United States, he will find that probably--
—Someone has to produce it under your deregulation.
—Order! Senator Georges.
—You get a quick--
—Order! Senator Georges, Senator MacGibbon has the call.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, Senator Georges was just reiterating the point that South East Asian countries are the countries in which deregulation flourishes. I was saying that if Senator Georges went to the United States he would find that probably the most highly developed country has some of the least restrictive regulations imaginable on trading. That is one of the reasons why the United States became a great country. The corollory is not true that the people are ground down by poverty and all the rest of it if there is no regulation on them. Another point was made that shopowners have to stay open because their competition, their opponents, do so. The market forces are such that if a shopowner is losing money, he just will not stay open because he will not be able to.
—You go broke.
—That is right. The person goes broke. So a smart person does not put himself in that position.
—Righto.
—Order! Senator MacGibbon has the call.

—The whole thing demonstrates once again the great rigidity of Australian Labor Party thinking. Opposition senators do not realise that the Australian society is a dynamic society and that in a dynamic society there is change, just as there is change in the commercial world. I am happy to support those changes.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, I am sorry, but I am just formalising my remarks. I can no longer offend the Chair by interjections. The path that Senator MacGibbon is going down will lead us to deregulating the roads. If Senator MacGibbon had his way, every bridge is Australia would be deregulated and he would put in tolls. He would deregulate the roads. He would even deregulate the traffic if he had his way. What he is doing is going away from a planned economy--
—A socialist economy.

—Oh, rubbish! How can you go right back to the conditions of the last century. In your stupid following of a so-called free enterprise ethic you are just going back to the conditions of the last century when people were enslaved in poverty. Whole families were enslaved and child labour laws of countries such as Singapore, Sri Lanka, Taiwan and Hong Kong-all those places-permitted children to be employed under the conditions which you are advocating.
—Order! Senator Georges, direct your remarks through the Chair.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, I was just waving my arms around and looking around to encompass Senator MacGibbon in my remarks, but I apologise to you. I have never heard so much dangerous talk in all my life as I have heard from Senator MacGibbon.
—How about part time dentists?

—Oh, yes, we can deregulate them. We have allowed a few highly qualified dentists into this country from the countries which Senator MacGibbon has mentioned such as Sri Lanka and others. They are highly qualified people who would be prepared to have their surgeries open from 9 o'clock in the morning until 12 o'clock at night. If Senator MacGibbon were still a practising dentist, he would have to keep the same hours to survive. But he is smart, he got out of the trade and he is in the Senate. The people who would support the casualisation of the distribution industry are those of us who are on fixed salaries, who have a touch of socialism. We are in the Public Service; we are bureaucrats. We get our pay packets at the end of the month. We work our 35 hours a week or 37 1/2 hours or even less-whatever it may be-and we expect some poor devil to stay open until 12 o'clock at night because we forget to buy a carton of milk; or we expect a hardware store owner to be open for the same hours because we are doing a bit of painting and we have run out of paint. So we expect some poor slave to stay open because, under the deregulation principles of Senator MacGibbon, we expect to have that sort of service.
—You can't get a dentist at the weekend.

—One cannot get a doctor at the weekend. This country has achieved the conditions that it has achieved by the adoption of regulation right at the very start and by careful and sensible planning of what has developed into a mixed economy. If this Government stays in power much longer it will destroy the mixed economy. It will destroy those areas of planning which are to our benefit. But never mind! Senator MacGibbon can be assured that by this legislation the Government will disadvantage a few more people who will vote against it. This thinking is spreading right across the board. The razor gang report and the madness of a so-called free enterprise philosophy are bringing down our conditions. The Government will be voted out irrespective of who the leader happens to be. We should be celebrating here today because the Government has disadvantaged people in Canberra! Senator Reid might take note of it. She is the only Liberal representative of Canberra. I would say that she has placed her own position in jeopardy by the speech she made today and by her support of the proposition which is before the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) has not answered my questions. I am not interested to know whether the Government has people voting against it; I am interested in the question as to how this legislation affects the people within the retail trade. The Minister has not answered the questions I have put to him. I intend to proceed until such time as he does answer. I have until 8 p.m. in which to do so.
—He is not going to answer you.

—I intend to try to see whether we can get an answer out of him. Perhaps the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) is listening to this debate. He may be able to advise us of precisely what are the advices given to Ministers in this chamber in respect of this matter. I remind the Committee that the Minister for the Capital Territory forthrightly and quite rightly made the statement that matters such as this must be dealt with and that good government requires that the interests of the retailers, the shop assistants and the buying public should be taken into consideration when decisions are made on this matter. That has not been done. There has been no consultation with the retailers or with the shop assistants. I asked the Minister-he has not replied-what sort of survey has been undertaken to ascertain how the people of the Australian Capital Territory feel about this. I have cited the figures in respect of the Minister's own electorate of Denison where only 15.2 per cent of all persons interviewed did wish to see all-day Saturday trading and only one per cent wanted all-day Sunday trading.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot conceive of the possibility that the Minister for the Capital Territory likes this Bill. His public statements are quite to the contrary. The Bill emerges not from the Minister but from the razor gang. Why was the razor gang established? It was established-in the words that I have heard so often-to cut off some of the fat. We have heard the Minister state that this proposal by the razor gang will save the Government precisely nothing. At least we have got that statement out of the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will put people on unemployment relief.

—Of course, as Senator Mulvihill's incisive interjection reminds me, it will put people on the dole. It will casualise the retail trade. I do not know who the Minister's advisers are, but this is not funny. Furthermore, the casualising of the retail trade will mean that young people will not be able to get jobs. There will be more payments to people on the unemployment benefit. I regard with disappointment the failure of the Government to give any guarantee whatsoever to small businessmen that standover tactics will not be engaged in by the managers of the market, as I stated before. Mr Temporary Chairman, I seek leave to table this letter from Lend Lease Investments Pty Ltd which was written to a small businessman, a lessee of the shopping centre at Eastlands in my home State of Tasmania. It was written by Lend Lease on 9 April 1980 and, in effect, it states that, if the lessee did not comply with the trading hours as specified by the owners or managers, the lessee's lease would be at risk.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators. I hope the Minister will now be able to have a look at it. I hope we can have his comments on that document which indicates precisely what will occur if this takes place. I feel that Senator MacGibbon's intervention at this stage was unwarranted. The matter was dealt with by the preceding speaker. I point out to Senator MacGibbon that almost 40,000 jobs have been lost in the retail trade over the period as indicated in the document that was incorporated, I think, by Senator Mulvihill. If that is something to be praised by the Government, be it on its head. The loss of 40,000 full time jobs since the introduction of late night shopping has caused a massive loss of full time jobs in the retail industry. At the same time it has caused the big increase in the number of casuals. The Minister has not adequately responded to my pointing out the participation rate of school children in the work force, I hope that, during the suspension of the sitting, the Minister for the Capital Territory might well consider whether the investigations by the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory should take place before any decision is made in respect of the proclamation of the Act. Frankly, I would not have spoken at all at length had I believed that the Minister would have given a guarantee that, before any decision is made on the proclamation of this Act, the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory and other committees involved would meet and a report would be made to the Parliament in accordance with the procedures laid down and suggested by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs so that positive legislation is introduced in the Parliament on this very important matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was telephoned by a small retailer from Melbourne who has seven stores. He had been listening to the debate and he confirmed that, since late night trading began, prices in that area have increased by 6 per cent. Before the Minister replies, I point out that the replies to date have been totally inadequate. I suggest that there are four matters upon which the Government has not given adequate replies. One further matter which requires a reply is whether those particular inquiries are going to be undertaken before the clause is assented to and whether the Parliament will have the opportunity of debating and determining the issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, does the Minister realise that the action now being proposed by the Government to deregulate shop trading hours is contrary to the recommendation of the experts at the International Labour Organisation meeting in Geneva, held between 4 May and 8 May of this year, on the relationship between the hours of work and shop and bank opening hours? This was a meeting about which the Government ought to know-it is not a matter for mirth-and on which it ought to have an answer. A concensus was reached at that meeting that the best interests of all concerned would be served by these matters being dealt with by legislation, regulation or collective bargaining where the participants had that power, and only after the fullest possible discussions have taken place with all those concerned. That is a vital matter.

Having asked those questions of the Minister, I remind all honourable senators that in voting against this clause they would not necessarily be voting against the Government's razor gang decision. A Government senator can vote against this proposition with a clear conscience, and that would not nullify the decision of the razor gang. It would simply throw back to the Minister for the Capital Territory the onus of bringing down an amendment to the trading hours ordinance, which of course would be subject to debate in the Parliament on this issue alone. I am only sorry that, because of the Government's intention to include this in an omnibus piece of legislation, time does not permit the Senate to go into this matter with the full consideration that it justly deserves. What happens here tonight will have ramifications throughout the length and breadth of Australia. I expect that the Minister and those behind him would understand that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —With regard to the matters which have been raised by Senator Harradine at earlier stages of the debate, but more particularly in the last few moments, I direct his attention to clause 2, and especially sub-clause (10) thereof, which states that the provisions of the Act, which of course include those covered by section 90, will not come into operation until a date to be proclaimed. Specifically, both I and the Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Hodgman, have stated unequivocally, in the Senate and in the House of Representatives respectively, that clause 90 will not be proclaimed forthwith; that there will be an interim period during which the monitoring committee and the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory will consider comprehensively the question of implementation and the possible effects to which Senator Harradine and others have referred.

SPEECH.PARA: I imagine that the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory would take at least three to four months to consider the question and table its report. I give honourable senators an absolute assurance that section 90 will not be proclaimed until the report of the Committee has been tabled and an opportunity has been given to debate it. Of course, the Committee will provide every opportunity for all views to be heard. I assume that the Chairman will take such steps as are necessary to ensure that the terms of reference of the Committee are advertised widely, and I know that the Committee will give every consideration to all who wish to express a point of view. I repeat, the provision will not be proclaimed to come into operation on a particular date until the report of the Committee has been tabled and the Parliament has had an opportunity to debate the issue fully.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a simple question of the Government. If that is the position, why does it not now withdraw this clause, allow the Committee to do its work and, four or five months later, at the end of this year, bring the matter before the Parliament for debate and consideration?

—I would like to add to what Senator Chipp has said and ask: What is to be monitored? Does it mean that the hours are to remain as they are or, conversely, that in view of the expected changes employers will begin to perform a transfusion, bringing in casuals and dispensing with permanents? Or will employees be told: 'Your are rostered to work at a time other than is provided for in the awards'? Just what is encompassed by the magic word 'monitoring'?

—I would respond to Senator Chipp by saying that the Government has made perfectly clear that it does not intend to withdraw the clause, but will be proceeding with it. Senator Mulvihill's question is one that should be considered by the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory in the way that I believe Senator Harradine envisaged earlier.

—I could not have expressed myself clearly to the Minister, because he did not answer the question that I thought I had asked. In his own words, the Government has no intention of proclaiming this clause until a date three or four months after the Committee has met. That would take us to October or November of this year. If the Government does not intend to proclaim it until October or November, why does it not wait before bringing in such legislation as we are not debating until the Committee reports? Why is it rushing this provision through now, using sittings which continue to 3 o'clock in the morning? Why is there a need to have this provision approved today, in June, rather than wait until October, after the Committee has reported?
—The question is 'That clause 90 stand as printed'.
—Do I take it that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner), by his silence, is treating my question with contempt and is going to ignore it?

—I think I have answered that point as have others in the course of the debate. It is quite clear that the Government has no intention of withdrawing this clause of the Bill. The Government will be proceeding with it. I make that position quite clear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Finally, to make my position very clear, I say that I regard even the latest statement by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner)-although coming along the road a little further-as not satisfactory. Therefore, I appeal to the Senate to reject clause 90.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the clause be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses 91 to 113-by leave-taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a question I want to ask the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner). Why is it necessary to omit from clauses 93 to 104 the words 'proper authority' and substitute the words 'delegate of the Minister'? What is the reason for that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the reason for doing this is, of course, to make the responsibility of the Minister clearer in these situations rather than have a vaguer responsibility relating to the statutory authority.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
Clauses 114 to 121-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Part IV of the Bill is concerned with the future of the Australian Wool Testing Authority which was mentioned earlier this afternoon by Senator Chipp. Very few of these razor gang decisions demonstrate more clearly the fortuity and futility of this exercise than the decision announced in its original form to sell the Australian Wool Testing Authority to the private sector. It is a testimony to the fundamental incompetence of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) that this decision ever appeared in the razor gang report. I suspect that neither the Minister nor the razor gang committee, which of course includes Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, had any understanding at all of this matter. The matter was considered in the context of the sale of government assets, the liquidation of capital. Since the Wool Testing Authority's assets have a market value in the vicinity of $10m, it was assumed by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle and by the other Ministers on the committee that the Government would gain $10m in revenue if the Wool Testing Authority were sold. One could excuse Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle for reaching that conclusion. One cannot be so charitable to the Minister for Primary Industry because the arrangements are such that the proceeds from the sale of the Wool Testing Authority would accrue, not to the Commonwealth Government but to the Wool Industry Trust Account.

SPEECH.PARA: However, this decision was announced along with dozens, or perhaps even hundreds, of equally ill-considered decisions outlined in the razor gang report and the Government was stuck with the consequences. The decision does not provide any money for the Government; it does not save the Government any recurring expenditure and therefore the question arose of what was the point in making the decision. Somewhat predictably, that question was asked by the wool industry itself. By 'wool industry' I mean not only the farmers who produce wool but also the International Wool Textile Organisation which involves the wool buyers who are mostly domiciled outside Australia. Nobody could find any rational reason on any grounds for disposal of the authority. That problem caused the Minister for Primary Industry, when this legislation passed through the House of Representatives, and the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) who represents him in this place, to waffle on with statements such as that this legislation will facilitate the implementation of a decision, if a decision should subsequently be made to sell the Australian Wool Testing Authority. There were references to the establishment of a foundation to administer the Wool Testing Authority as well as, in typical National Country Party style, guarantees of consultation with the Australian Wool Corporation before the actual enactment of this decision or any action is taken to sell the Authority, the possible sale of which is facilitated by this legislation.

The Australian Wool Corporation, in keeping with the Australian Wool Council and various State based wool grower organisations, made its opinions very clear to the Government and to the Minister. It does not want any change. It wants the Australian Wool Testing Authority to continue to operate on its present basis. So, it is quite spurious to suggest that consultation with the Wool Corporation or any other organisation associated with the wool industry is necessary or has any relevance. The Australian Wool Corporation and all the other groups have made it perfectly clear that they want the Wool Testing Authority to continue to operate in precisely the way that it operates now. Because of the fundamental incompetence, ignorance and negligence of the Minister for Primary Industry, the Government is saddled with this embarrassing announcement contained in the razor gang report. I confess that I do not know where the Government intends to go from here.

The clause which is before the Committee facilitates, as the Minister says, the implementation of a decision to dispose of the Wool Testing Authority to the private sector. However, it does not make such a disposal obligatory or mandatory. I suspect either that the Government hopes that the present very strong objection to this proposal which has come from the Australian Wool Corporation and all the other wool industry bodies will gradually fade away and that the Government may then be able to sell the Authority as it has stated it intends to do. Alternatively-my colleague John Kerin said something similar in the House of Representatives-I suspect that this is in fact a face saving device and that the Government's real hope is that this issue will slowly fade away, that the Bill will be passed but that in six months' time nobody will be particularly conscious of the fact that the Government said some time in the past that it was going to proceed with some stupid decision to sell the Wool Testing Authority. I suspect that that is the case, that the Government hopes the issue will fade away and that the Wool Testing Authority will continue to operate as a segment of the Australian Wool Corporation, as it has done for many years. Of course, that assessment could be wrong.

Therefore, the Opposition is strongly committed to the maintenance of the Australian Wool Testing Authority in its present form as a de facto agency of the Government of Australia. Certificates of quality issued by that Testing Authority therefore carry the imprimatur, the guarantee and the prestige of the Government of Australia. We still have some prestige in spite of the present Government being what it is. Honourable senators should have the opportunity to ensure that the Wool Testing Authority continues to operate in the future in precisely the same way as it has done in the past. I observe in passing that the same attitude was taken by members of the Labor Party in the House of Representatives, as is normally the case, and that two members of the Liberal Party crossed the floor of the House and voted with the Labor Party in an attempt to ensure that the Wool Testing Authority would continue to operate on the same excellent basis as it has done in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —There were two honest Liberals.

—There were two honest Liberals and no honest members of the National Country Party, which is the point I was about to make. The Country Party members who have the audacity to claim that they represent the authentic interests and the authentic will of the wool industry and of rural Australia generally, when given the opportunity in the House of Representatives to ensure, to guarantee that the Wool Testing Authority continued to operate in the way it has done for many years, turned down the opportunity to do so.
—The Labor Government was the only government that did anything about the wool industry.

—That is undoubtedly correct. I am not in conflict with what Senator McLaren has said, but the fact remains that two members of the Liberal Party had the common sense and moral courage to stand up and be counted in the House of Representatives as supporters of the wool industry. No members of the Country Party had the common sense or the courage to do so. We are giving the Country Party an opportunity, in opposing Part IV of the Bill, to ensure that the Wool Testing Authority continues to operate 'in precisely the same way as it does now'. Those were the words of the Country Party's own Minister who said that the Government's intention was to ensure that the Wool Testing Authority continues to operate in precisely the same way as it does now. That is what Mr Nixon, the Country Party Minister, said.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition will be opposing this Part of the Bill. We will be calling a division on it. Senator Chipp has already indicated that the Australian Democrats will support the Opposition in opposing this Part of the Bill. We will be giving members of the Liberal Party an opportunity to join their colleagues Mr Bungey and Mr Burr in the House of Representatives, who voted with the Opposition on precisely the same matter. We will also give National Country Party senators the opportunity to stand up and be counted.

TALK.START.PARA: —But there are not two honest Liberal senators.

—I will not pass judgment on that prematurely. I hope that there are but I am not entirely confident that there will be. In particular, we are giving the opportunity to those members of the National Country Party who claim to have both special knowledge of the agricultural constituency and a special obligation to represent its wishes which have been made perfectly clear. I stress that the wishes of the agricultural constituency have been made perfectly clear on this issue. If members of the National Country Party are actually living up to their claims to represent the agricultural constituency they will cross the floor and vote with the Labor Party, the Democrats and the Liberals, if any, to ensure that Part IV is deleted from this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walsh has drawn attention to the main thrust, I think, of the concern in the community in regard to this matter. It has been publicised in some degree not only in the Parliament but also in the media in recent weeks. Certainly, the vociferous opposition to the proposed sale of the Australian Wool Testing Authority has caused concern to customers that there might be some change under the new ownership proposed by this legislation so as to cause some doubt as to the validity or otherwise of the certificates which may be offered by the Authority. That certainly is not the intention of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the Minister for Primary Industry, the Honourable Peter Nixon, made this perfectly clear in his media release on 15 May. He said that the fundamental aim was to ensure that the Australian Wool Testing Authority continued to operate in precisely the same way as it does today. We are talking about a continuation of the operations so as to ensure that the quality of certificates which are made available remains high. We are talking about the ownership of the organisation being in the general community. It is clear that the Government has the fullest possible intention of consulting with the Australian Wool Corporation as the various steps are undertaken towards the implementation of that goal. That remains the Government's position in this matter. It will ensure that the highest possible degree of concern is expressed in any stage of development of this process. The Government would like to assure the wool growers of Australia that in the event of the sale occurring, as it undoubtedly will because the organisation is, in fact, a profitable one, it will have regard to the maximum level of validity of the certificates of the Wool Testing Authority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) claimed that the Government's objective is to ensure, as stated by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) on 15 May, that the Australian Wool Testing Authority continues to operate in precisely the same way as it does now. The way to ensure that is to cross the floor and vote with the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats. Negativing this clause of the Bill will ensure that the Wool Testing Authority does just that and that it will continue to operate in precisely the same way as it does now. If the Minister really believed what he said on that day and if he knew what he was doing-quite clearly he does not on this issue among many others-he would have ensured that the stupid recommendation made by the razor gang had never come down. The Government cannot have it both ways. If it wants to ensure that the Wool Corporation continues to operate in the way that it does now it will drop this stupid provision from this Bill. On the other hand, if it does not want the Wool Testing Authority to operate in the same way as it does now, it would act upon the recommendation contained in the razor gang report, that is, to sell the Wool Testing Authority to the private sector-an action which is very vigorously opposed by the Opposition for a variety of reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government cannot have it both ways. If it is to go through the farcical, face saving exercise of setting up some sort of foundation, some pseudo, bogus or quasi statutory authority to control the Wool Testing Authority in a similar way to that in which it is now controlled by the Australian Wool Corporation, what it will in fact do, is establish two statutory authorities where one statutory authority previously existed, which is of course the antithesis of one of the major proclaimed objectives of the razor gang report. The plain fact is that the Government is highly embarrassed by this issue. It is on the hook over this issue because of the fundamental incompetence, stupidity and ignorance of the Minister for Primary Industry. Liberal senators who are sitting in the chamber now are embarrassed by this because of their alliance with the National Country Party. Serve them right for going into an alliance with the Country Party in the first place. But if Government senators really want to ensure that the Wool Testing Authority continues to operate in the way the wool industry at all levels has made it perfectly clear it wishes the Authority to continue to operate, and in the way that the Minister for Primary Industry claims the Government wants it to continue-that is, in precisely the same way it is doing now-those Government senators will cross the floor and vote with the Labor Party to knock out this part of the Bill.

If they decline to do so only two conclusions are possible, the most charitable of which is that Government senators, like the Minister, do not know what they are doing. In most cases I suspect that would be true. The less charitable conclusion is that they are hypocrites who are willing to pay lip-service to the stated objective of ensuring that the Wool Testing Authority operates in precisely the same way as it does now but they are not willing to record their votes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Either mad or bad.
—They are either mad or bad as my colleague Senator Evans said. I will be very interested to see how they line up on this matter.

—I find it very hard to believe the statement of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) that the Australian Wool Testing Authority will operate in exactly the same way as it has operated before. He expects the Senate to believe the assurance he has given on behalf of the Government when over 95 per cent of the assurances given in policy speeches by this Government since 1975 have been broken. The Government has not honoured its assurances to anybody-primary producers, ordinary citizens, or anyone else. Yet spelt out in this very document, with which this Bill is associated, that is, the Review of Commonwealth Functions report, in attachment A, under the heading 'Assets to be sold', we see that the Wool Testing Authority is named. Now we find the Minister saying, in answer to a question by Senator Walsh, that the Authority will operate in the same way as it operated before. Senator Walsh raised the matter of a statutory authority. If the Wool Testing Authority is put under a statutory authority we could well see another burden placed on the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. In the Senate Notice Paper, nearly half a page is devoted to listing the statutory authorities that are being investigated by that Committee under the chairmanship of Senator Rae. It could well be that 18 months from now this will be another statutory body which will be referred to that Committee for investigation. The Authority has been operating satisfactorily. It has operated to the satisfaction of all Australian woolgrowers. Why should it be changed? As I understand the Minister to say that, prior to the razor gang making its decision to sell the Australian Wool Testing Authority, it had had consultations with people in the industry-that is, organisations representing woolgrowers-I ask the Minister for the names of those organisations with which the razor gang had consultations. I seek an answer to that question before I ask any more questions.

—That is not what I said at all. I did say that there would be consultations between the Government and the Australian Wool Corporation with regard to the way in which the sale of the Wool Testing Authority would be effected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) for his answer. He has now made the record clear. There has been no consultation at all with the people who are vitally concerned with the proposed sale of the Australian Wool Testing Authority, that is, the woolgrowers of this country who have to depend on overseas markets to sell their wool. As I pointed out last week in debating another piece of legislation before this chamber, many representatives of woolgrowers organisations are fearful of the fact that the Government is to dispose of the Authority. They are concerned that the Authority will lack credibility in the eyes of overseas buyers if it operates in the same way as private enterprise operates.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no guarantee that the Authority will be under the control of the Australian Wool Corporation. Part IV of the Bill contains certain provisions to be undertaken by the Corporation 'if directed' by the Minister for Primary Industry. The words 'shall if so directed' by the Minister appear throughout the Bill in relation to what may be done. Of course, knowing the policy of this Government, the present Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) could direct in any way he liked with the result that some of his wealthy mates in private enterprise might get hold of the Authority. This could sound the death knell of the wool industry. As Senator Walsh said, this is the testing point for those people from cocky's corner, as members of the National Country Party are often referred to. Are they going to support the people who have supported them over the years? Let them forget about the Liberal Party. We know that it is only a facade when the Liberal Party says that it is interested in country people. The people from cockies corner should come over to this side of the Chamber and support those who have supported country people in the past.
Question put:
That the clauses be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I have been waiting about 4 1/2 hours to utter about four sentences which I shall now produce on the question of bankruptcy. It is important however, I think, to indicate the Opposition's hostility to this Part of the legislation along indeed with most of the others even though, pervaded as we are by a healthy sense of realism, we shall not pursue this opposition to the point of a division. What we object to here is the hiving off of a significant proportion of bankruptcy administrations to public accountants in private practice. This is another decision which clearly is the product of ideology rather than any rational argument, with no justification whatsover being offered for this move. Certainly, no consultation has been undertaken with either the accountancy or legal professions, this being in marked contrast with the United Kingdom Green Paper exercise of last year which, as might have been expected with a Thatcherite government of a similar ideological bent, brought forward proposals of this kind, but which proposals were followed by consultation with the accountancy and legal professions and resulted in a very trenchant battery of criticism being directed against proposals to hive off matters to the private sector without there being an articulate justification for the public sector administrations being reduced in this way.

SPEECH.PARA: To come to my fifth and last sentence-I see that Senator Puplick has been keeping count-there has been no complaint, as I understand it, about the way in which bankruptcy administrations are being conducted within the Department at the moment. The only exception is complaint in terms of the delays that have arisen as a result of two phenomena, one being the staff ceilings, which here, as elsewhere, have made it very difficult for public administrators to keep up with the pressures upon them, and the other being the escalating number of bankruptcies operating in the community at large. Indeed, it can be said that about the only visible growth industry in the Australian economy at the moment is the industry of bankruptcy.
Honourable senators-And tax avoidance.

TALK.START.PARA: —And tax avoidance, which we will come to later on in the evening. I am indebted to the interjections, which came from about 18 places around the chamber. As has been the case with so many other provisions of this kind in the razor gang Bill, no justification has been articulately mounted in defence of this exercise and ideology, and it is for that reason that we wish to make explicit and very clear our rejection of the proposal.

—Very briefly, the Australian Democrats support the position of the Australian Labor Party on this proposal. We find this to be one of the most extraordinary recommendations of the razor gang. The thought of transferring this responsibility to the private sector is to us a philosophy of handing things to private enterprise gone absolutely mad. No good reason has been advanced for this switch, from what I have read from the Government, other than a vague philosophical reason. I raise two points in this regard. With bankruptcies at the present time running at an all time high, as Senator Evans just said, the opportunities for future corruption in this area when the responsibility is handed to private enterprise are mind boggling. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe, Mr Temporary Chairman, that it might expedite the rational consideration of our business, not that that is ever a significant criterion in this chamber, if we were to consider at the same time not only these clauses but also Schedule 2, which relates to further amendments to the subject matter of this part of the Bill, namely, the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act. TALK.START.PARA: —We seem to have leave for everything except getting on with the business of the chamber. Now that I have leave--
—The procedure was quite correct.

—I appreciate what the Minister says. I am getting as impatient as, I suspect, are most other senators, not to mention the two dogs presently listening to this broadcast, about the molasses-like pace at which we have been proceeding in dealing with this important legislation. The second amendment endeavours to preserve that part of the existing Commonwealth employees' legislation which allows an option for litigants to go either by way of appeal to the compensation appeals tribunal or to prescribed courts. The third amendment which has been circulated seeks to establish by an amendment to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975 a separate division within that body for the determination of Commonwealth compensation appeals. —You have already received leave.
—That is splendid, Mr Temporary Chairman. I now move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 72, Schedule 2, proposed amendments of the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971, after
'Paragraph 51 (3) (B) . . . Omit 'Compensation' '', insert
'After section 54 . . . Insert the following new section:
''54A. The Commissioner shall determine a claim for compensation as soon as practicable but in any case within 120 days of lodgement of the claim.''.''.

'Retention of Appeals to Prescribed Courts

66. Nothwithstanding the amendment of this Act by the Commonwealth Functions (Statutes Review) Act 1981, where no application is made to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for a review of a determination in accordance with this Part, an application may be made to a prescribed court for a review of the determination in accordance with this Part as if this Act had not been amended by that Act.''.

'(ca) Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Division; and'.''.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now that we all know where we are, may I briefly describe to the Committee what the amendments are all about? The first of them, which is concerned with setting a time limit for the determination of original claims by the Commissioner, is advanced by the Opposition simply because there is a vacuum within the law here at the moment. There is no time limit on the Commissioner for Employees' Compensation within which determinations as to qualification for compensation must be made. That, of course, is a threshold consideration which must be satisfied before appeals of any kind can be launched.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been a concern of a number of people, not only litigants but also those acting for them, that there is no cut-off point of this kind. The situation in practice has been that it is only really simple traumas like broken legs that are dealt with quickly by the Commissioner for Employees' Compensation and that even the simplest of major injury claims-for example those involving loss of hearing-tend to take a minimum of six months with the average closer to 12 months. In the case of death claims-especially those based on strokes and heart conditions-the average has been closer to 18 months with many claims taking as long as two years or more to determine. The concern, as I say, is that some time limit ought to be set. The Administrative Review Council in paragraphs 16 to 21 of its report to the Attorney-General (Senator Durack), which was tabled recently in this Parliament, suggests 60 days as being an appropriate time limit to be inserted in the legislation. My own soundings suggest that that might in fact be too short as a matter of practice and that that may be the reason why in the Bill we have before us at the moment no time limit at all is set. That is why the Opposition is suggesting as a compromise amendment that a time limit of 120 days be here fixed.

The second amendment which is proposed to this collection of provisions relates to the retention of the appeal option to prescribed courts which is available under the present compensation legislation but which is proposed to be removed by the provisions with which we are now dealing. Part 5 of the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act allows appeals to prescribed courts which are, for example, the County Court in Victoria and the Workers Compensation Commission of New South Wales. The recommendation of the Administrative Review Council report which deals with this matter in paragraphs 35 to 40 and also paragraphs 74 to 78 is that this option be in fact removed. However, it is the view of the Opposition, based again on some fairly extensive discussions which do not appear to have been entered into by the Administrative Review Council with both individual parties concerned and more particularly members of the legal profession who are experienced in this area, that the alternative option ought to in fact be preserved.

I make it clear that here, as elsewhere, the Opposition's concern is not to reject the basic thrust of these amendments which is to remove the existing Commonwealth Employees Compensation Tribunal and to provide that appeals in future be directed to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Perhaps with all the subtlety of these amendments that rather basic point has been overlooked. That is not our concern at all. Our concern rather is with a series of peripheral aspects of this proposed transfer of jurisdiction. We see the failure to consider these peripheral aspects as being one of the penalties we pay when we have this kind of compendious omnibus legislation which squeezes into a single statutory formula literally dozens of changes to existing arrangements and makes it very difficult for any reasoned consideration to be given to any of them.

But against that context, I am suggesting that there be several improvements to the Government's legislation in this area. The first of them was the setting of a time limit; the second one being to retain the alternative option of appeal not only to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal but also to the prescribed courts. Let me indicate very swiftly the reasons why it is thought that this alternative option ought to be preserved. The first reason is that it is after all an existing right which ought not be taken away from any potential litigant without there being strong affirmative justification for such removal. The point I am making here is essentially a threshold one that the onus is in a sense, because it is an existing right, upon those who would wish to remove that right to provide strong justification for the removal rather than it being on those who would wish to retain the right.

My second point, which is the more fundamental one, is that litigants should in our view be entitled in principle to go before a judge if they so desire. Large sums of money are usually involved in these compensation claims, and very often issues of considerable legal complexity are involved. It is our view that persons in these circumstances should be entitled to have confidence of a judicial resolution of their claim if they feel, for one reason or another, that the complexity of the case or the amount of money and so on involved is not such as to make it appropriate to be dealt with by a non-judicial arbitrator.

The third point-this is very much reinforced if there is no separate division of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal preserved or formed for the determination of these appeals-is that persons involved in this kind of litigation simply will not be able to guarantee that their appeals will be heard within the Administrative Appeals Tribunal by someone who is experienced in and familiar with this jurisdiction and the numerous complexities associated with it. The final point is that even if there is a separate division of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal carved out for this particular purpose there is, it must be said, a possibility of its being stacked, if that is not too strong a word, with inappropriate appointees, perhaps on a patronage basis, or more likely appointees who are chosen by a government of the day-certainly only a conservative government would do this-with a view to their having a fairly robust attitude towards compensation claims and a basic orientation towards preserving the Treasury from undue claims upon it.

In other words, the situation might well arise where the only available tribunals are those within the Administrative Appeals Tribunal constituted by persons who have been appointed by the Government, with a very clear idea of what the Government wants to achieve in its manning of this particular jurisdiction. Under these circumstances the point is made that litigants ought to preserve the option which they presently enjoy of making a decision not to run that particular gauntlet but rather to go to the courts. They are the reasons behind this amendment.

I readily acknowledge that as this amendment is framed it is perhaps somewhat technically inadequate fully to preserve all the relevant existing language of the present Act. Nonetheless a vote upon it will make sufficiently clear, if it is an affirmative vote, the Senate's desire that that option be preserved.

The final matter which is the subject matter of these amendments-I have moved them all together-concerns an amendment designed in fact to ensure that a separate division of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal will be maintained for the determination of compensation appeals of this kind. Paragraphs 56 to 58 of the Administra- tive Review Council report in fact recommended against such a division because it was argued that this would reduce the flexibility of the organisation of the Appeals Tribunal. I simply suggest, without going into the argument in any more detail than this, that the way in which that proposition was argued for by the ARC does not seem to be sufficiently persuasive in the event to make me abandon this proposition. I readily acknowledge that as a practical administrative matter there may well be advantage in combining the miscellany of existing compensation appeal jurisdictions which are already vested in the Tribunal into a single large compensation division rather than having just Commonwealth employee compensation matters dealt with by a separate small division. There may well be room for manoeuvre and compromise of this kind. There is a quite strong expression by the Opposition that if this particular change goes ahead-basically we acknowledge it to be a reform-it ought to be accompanied by at least this much by way of deference to the worries that I have expressed.

The final point I make is a quick one along these lines: I am personally sensitive to suggestions that these changes by and large are not those which have been recommended by the Administrative Review Council. I for one am always suggesting to the Government that it ought to take more notice of the independent advice that it receives from advisory bodies of this kind. I am suggesting that that advice ought to be second-guessed. The only point I offer in my own defence in this respect is that although I agree that the Administrative Review Council's recommendations which have been acted upon by the Government deserve to be taken very seriously and treated with great respect, nonetheless they have not been based on full consultation with the legal profession and with other interested parties as, for example, is always the case with Australian Law Reform Commission reports. For that reason, I do not think they should be regarded as having quite the same kind of biblical certitude or justification for respect that might be the case with other classes of advisory reports. That is the situation. We do not oppose these clauses as a whole but we do believe they could be improved by amendments of this kind. We hope that the amendments will be accepted by the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite clear from Senator Evans's very carefully reasoned argument that there is considerable agreement on the amendments proposed in this part of the Bill. Any disagreement is on marginal matters. Senator Evans has already adverted to many of the arguments which I would want to put. I will not be tedious in going over them again. His amendments are threefold. Firstly, he believes that jurisdiction of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in relation to matters under the Commonwealth Employees' Compensation Act 1971 should be exercised within a separate division of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Secondly, he believes that the right under the present Act to appeal from a decision of a Commissioner for Employees Compensation to certain prescribed State courts should be preserved. The two amendments which Senator Evans has proposed-as Senator Evans himself acknowledged-are not supported by the Administrative Review Council which reported to the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) on matters relating to this Tribunal. Senator Evans knows that. The report was tabled in the Parliament, I think, last week.

SPEECH.PARA: The Administrative Review Council considered that the creation of a separate division of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal would place a limitation on the Tribunal's current flexibility of operation. Senator Evans has already referred to that and has said that in his view he is not persuaded by that. But it comes down to what weight one puts on this and how one is persuaded on this and some of the other matters. That is not to say that his arguments do not have weight. It is a question of where one comes down on the particular argument in the light of the information available. In relation to the question of the prescribed State courts, the Council considered that what is now proposed in the Bill was consistent with the view that specialist tribunals should remain in evidence only if special circumstances warrant that course as opposed to providing for review by a general administrative tribunal. Again, that is a question involving the value or emphasis one wants to place on it. For what it is worth, the view that I am putting was expressed in the 1971 Commonwealth Administrative Review Council report.

It is thought that if the right of appeal to State courts were removed, there would be a much greater likelihood of maintaining consistency of decisions as well as achieving a high standard of review particularly since under the system that we are proposing-which we hope will come into effect-appeals to the Federal Court will be limited to questions of law. The Administrative Review Council considered that forum shopping in this area was undesirable and that the number of different bodies hearing appeals at present inevitably leads to some inconsistencies. Briefly, I emphasise a point that was made by Senator Evans concerning the Administrative Review Council recommendations, of which four have been adopted. They are: Firstly, that the jurisdiction currently excercised by the Commonwealth Employees Compensation Tribunal should be conferred on the Administrative Appeals Tribunal-we are all agreed on that point; secondly, that legislation should provide for the Commonwealth to be a party in proceedings for a review of decisions of the Commissioner for Employees Compensation-I do not think there is any argument on that; thirdly, that the Administrative Appeals Tribunal should have power to award costs in compensation matters-I do not think there is any argument on that; and, fourthly, the matter that we have been discussing-that is, the existing right to apply to a prescribed court for a review of a determination under the Compensation Act-should be abolished. We are, in fact, endorsing that recommendation. Senator Evans has presented argument which, in his view, would lead us to take the other course.

I simply observe in passing that the AAT includes some judicial members and a right of appeal does lie from the AAT to Federal courts on questions of law. The membership of the Administrative Review Council is fairly prestigious and representative. It includes the President of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the Ombudsman, the Chairman of the Law Reform Commission, the First Parliamentary Counsel and the Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department. The Council is a fairly prestigious body. As my colleague has said in advancing his arguments, its recommendations have generally been ones that have been welcomed.

That then leaves me with the other matter raised by Senator Evans, the third of his amendments, that is, that the Commissioner be required to determine claims within, at most, 120 days of lodgment. There is no doubt that this third amendment is attractive in some respects. There are, however, problems with it. Those problems relate to the practicalities of making the system work. I am as concerned as the honourable senator was by some of the examples which he could adduce to support his case. I do not want to go through the details of some of the practical problems. The honourable senator knows that it is not a simple matter, whichever way one decides to go. It is a question where medical reports, especially from specialists, often take a long time to obtain. Yet the obtaining of these often works to the considerable advantage of a claimant.

Again it is questionable whether such an amendment is really necessary and whether we cannot by other administrative means achieve the very desirable ends that the honourable senator is seeking. Given that there will be a right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the Ombudsman may issue a certificate enabling a person to appeal to that Tribunal as though the Commissioner had decided not to award compensation to that claimant, if the Ombudsman is of the opinion that there has been unreasonable delay in determining the claim. That seems to give another way through to meet the kind of circumstance which Senator Evans adverts to. This is a section of the Bill which confers new benefits and which assists the people for whom it is designed. As I said, there is general agreement on the matters, but there is some disagreement on particular points. It is disagreement based on the interpretatin one puts on various review reports which are available. I say to my colleague, in the very best spirit, that we are not going to support his amendments but we recognise the arguments he has put.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the Minister for the relatively civilised and constructive tenor of his remarks in relation to the Opposition's proposals. It appears that there is a degree of unlikelihood that pressing this matter to a division would resolve it in any way that the Opposition would prefer and, particularly given the constraints of time, I do not go that far. However, I would appreciate some indication from the Government-perhaps this is quite consistent with everything Senator Baume has said-that it will keep closely under review the particular matters to which I have adverted; that it will monitor very closely the operation of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal; and that it will monitor a little more closely than it has in the past the operations of the Commissioner himself, in particular insofar as the time the Tribunal has been taking for these determinations to be made, with a view, perhaps, in the spirit of improving this legislation, to having some fresh analysis in a year or so's time of the operation of this legislation with a view to its improvement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable senator. I will make those points known to my colleague who administers the Act and who, of course, is a colleague of ours in this chamber.

The Government will say to the Australian Democrats: 'That is a Budget measure. If you oppose it you will be breaking your undertaking'. I sound that note of warning. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition wishes to put very explicitly on record its opposition to this part of the omnibus razor gang Bill which has the effect of abolishing the Legislative Drafting Institute. That Institute has been in existence since the late 1960s or early 1970s as a training institution for draftsmen from Third World Commonwealth countries especially. As was explained, incidentally, in evidence given to Senate Estimates Committee B on 13 October 1978 and again on 4 September 1980, it was originally set up in response to suggestions which arose in the late 1960s from meetings of Commonwealth law Ministers with a view to there being in Australia, taking advantage of Australian experience, a legislative drafting institute of this kind. But since its establishment, and indeed from the very outset, it has been contemplated that the Institute should be capable of a very significant domestic role in training legislative draftsmen, namely, the people who write the statutes which we spend our time endeavouring to pass in this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Given the manifest continuing need for draftsmen of high quality to serve this country, quite apart from the larger international relations aspects of the matter, it seems very unfortunate indeed that this body will now suffer the fate proposed in this Bill. It has been operating as very much a shoestring concern with just one trained draftsman plus secretarial support. Nonetheless, it had the potential all along for playing a very significant training role. It is just a pity that the Office of Parliamentary Counsel and the Attorney-General's Department, which between them are the main users of qualified draftsmen, seem to have had something of a dog in the manger attitude about using formal training institutions of this kind to produce draftsmen, taking by contrast the rather old-fashioned view that drafting is a skill that could be learned only on the job. The result of that has been, I think, to create a situation where there is a number of evident things going wrong. It seems to me, and there is plenty of evidence of it in the quality of the drafting coming before us, particularly in the rushed circumstances this session, there is still a shortage of senior and capable draftsmen within the Office of Parliamentary Counsel capable of meeting the peak demands imposed by this Parliament.

It seems even more evident that there is a shortage of qualified draftsmen within the Legislative Drafting Division of the Attorney-General's Department, which has the major responsibility for drafting regulations and ordinances. The preparation of these is notoriously lagging way behind any reasonable schedule and, in particular, the shortage of these is making impossible the production of properly consolidated volumes of territorial statutory law. It is also our concern that the shortage generally of trained draftsmen around the place results in a situation where there is little or no help for the Opposition in doing its job of generating alternative draft proposals, in statutory language, of the propositions that it wants to put forward. It is one thing to express our concern about matters in generalised second reading debate language; it is another thing again to be able to produce sophisticated technically competent drafts of the precise points that we want to make and the improvements we want to suggest in the Committee stage of debates. Were there more legislative draftsmen qualified and available to be used in this way the Opposition believes it would improve the quality of the parliamentary process.

We also believe there is a shortage of drafting resources available for such subsidiary perhaps, but nonetheless important, tasks as the servicing of bodies such as the Australian Law Reform Commission in its generation of reports and draft legislation and also in tackling the tasks of the preparation of uniform law reform legislation in this country which, regrettably, has been something which always has had low priority. By its very nature uniform legislation, the product of co-operative arrangements or agreements between the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, is not legislation which is the sole province of any one of the participating governments. For that reason such legislative proposals invariably get shuffled to the end of the queue. That is one of the reasons that by contrast with the United States of America and Canada and other comparable federal countries Australia's progress in the development of uniform law has been appallingly slow.

That is a very brief statement of the problems that exist with legislative drafting in this country. I suggest that it is another demonstration of the short-sightedness of this Government in now removing completely the organisational framework within which a sensible and coherent ongoing program for the training of legislative draftsmen could take place. I will finish on the point that I do not think anyone would reasonably claim that legislative drafting is a skill or an art that can be learned entirely in an isolated surrounding such as a technical Legislative Drafting Institute. Clearly it is the kind of skill which needs some on-the-job training to supplement the formal skills that can perhaps be taught in an academic environment.

I make the point in this respect simply that that was always the argument of lawyers generally so far as the training of future generations of lawyers was concerned and it is an argument which has long since been acknowledged to be fallacious in that context, as the establishment of the College of Law in Sydney and the Leo Cussen Institute for Continuing Education in Victoria has shown, that practically competent lawyers in fact can be generated by training institutions of this kind with the formal training being supplemented from time to time by practical on-the-job experience. I think this is, although it perhaps sounds somewhat esoteric, an important matter that I raise. It is a matter for which the Opposition feels a deep concern. It is a matter that has ongoing implications for the quality of public administration in this country and, as such, I believe--

TALK.START.PARA: —And abroad.

—Indeed, as Senator Tate reminds me-I come back to where I began-and the quality of public administration abroad in all the countries; and there are many in the Pacific area, the Caribbean and Africa which we have assisted through the operation of this Institute. Questions as to the quality of public administration are in issue. It is our strong hope, although regrettably not our expectation, that the Government will reconsider what seems to have been yet another casual, cavalier slash of the razor without any real thought to the long term implications of what was being done.
