Clauses 231 to 235-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This has been a somewhat gruelling debate and we are now very close to the end of it. This is one of the most important Parts of the Bill because it involves the abolition of the Prices Justification Tribunal. It is an abolition which we oppose vehemently and completely for a variety of reasons which I will now endeavour to articulate. Ever since 1975 when the Fraser Government assumed office, it has been the case that the Prices Justification Tribunal, a creation of the Whitlam Government, has been subject to steady emasculation. Its staff has been slashed by 45 per cent in the years since 1976 and its funding has been cut to a level where nowadays it has had the resources to produce only one major report a year.

SPEECH.PARA: The Tribunal was established in 1973 to report on whether prices were justified. It was never established as a price control agency, although there is ample justification in principle for that being done. The barrier, the inhibition, felt was, of course, the constitutional one that the Commonwealth was simply thought to lack the sufficient constitutional power, with respect to at least all classes of price setters, to set in train a penally sanctioned operation of that kind. The creation of the Tribunal has undoubtedly been justified by its activities over the years since its initial establishment in that it has found in a great many instances that industries were fixing prices above those which a classical free market system would have produced. Even, indeed, with all the staffing constraints that have been systematically imposed upon the Tribunal since the advent of the Fraser Government, in the financial year 1979-80 the Tribunal, in fact, rejected 230 prices increase applications, in the process saving consumers an estimated $160m. So, the Tribunal, even in its declining years, as it were, has manifestly played a significant role.

Equally evident should be the need for some continuing price justification procedures of the kind that the Prices Justification Tribunal was supposed to be administering. There are plenty of ways of articulating the arguments in this respect. Perhaps the most basic argument is simply that price Justification procedures are an essential ingredient in any serious attempt to create a wages-prices package of anti-inflationary policies which have a chance of gaining acceptance by working people, by the trade union movement. Trade unions have to justify their increases before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Similarly, companies should be subject to the same kind of discipline. Another way of putting the argument, or of putting another gloss upon it, is in terms of the increasing power of major corporations. Trade practices legislation, which is another crucial element in the regulatory armoury in this respect, necessarily will be inadequate to cover everything that needs to be covered. In a small market such as Australia is, monopoly and oligopoly situations to a considerable extent will be unavoidable. As a result the market, for all the Friedmanite huffing and puffing that this Government might go on with, simply will not achieve by its own discipline satisfactory controls on prices.

A third argument which perhaps links together the previous two can be articulated in terms of social cohesion. Justice must not only be done but also be seen to be done. Economic success cannot be achieved without public faith in the honesty of the system. People have to be aware not only that the system is working but also of how it is working. One of the greatest advantages of the Prices Justification Tribunal was that it laid out for public inspection the kinds of commercial processes in price setting that were at work within the corporate sector. So, bearing those sorts of arguments in mind, what the Government has to come to grips with, I suggest, is this: What do honourable senators opposite have to say to consumers when they ask them what the Government intends to do about rising prices? Do they simply say: 'Oh, it's only the free market'? The Australian public will not accept that. They know, because after all most of them work for the firms that produce the goods that they in turn buy as consumers, that not all firms operate in free markets. They know, as the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and his advisers apparently do not, that not all firms have the kind of competitive discipline of the market-place. They know that when a firm is making its pricing decisions it will charge what it can get away with.

How naive this Government must be if it really believes that prices in markets where a monopoly or an oligopoly naturally exists because of market size will be determined by free market forces. Where is the competition? Where are the unseen hands? Will they descend into the Australian market-place from above with some sort of grace and favour dispensation from the Almighty? That is the problem-that even free marketers themselves, perhaps more accurately described as free-booters like Milton Friedman, recognise, that private monopoly is not a virtue and it must not be given free rein to trample over the rights of consumers. We do need regulatory mechanisms of the kind that involve trade practices legislation and of the kind that involve PJT legislation.

This fact becomes very clear indeed when one looks at the situation in a number of present market environments. Look at the situation, for example, in the aluminium industry, which was ironically one of the areas which was going to be subject to the next major scrutiny by the PJT. On the London Metal Exchange aluminium prices have recently been running at around $1,140 per tonne. In Australia, Comalco Ltd and others in the Australian sellers market are getting close to $1,545 per tonne-35 per cent more for a product for which Australia should have a significant international comparative advantage. Another example put by my colleague Mr Hurford in the other place was in terms of a primary food commodity such as coffee. There has been a 40 per cent reduction in recent months in the price of raw coffee on world markets but that simply has not been transferred, passed on, to the pockets of the Australian consumer. Another example, which is perhaps even closer to home for most honourable senators, particularly as this session grinds towards its conclusion, is the price of beer. Honourable senators would have noted, to take a Victorian example, that it was reported over the last weekend that 44 per cent of Melbourne hotels were pocketing the 5c per bottle difference between light and standard beer that they were receiving as a result of a cut from 8 per cent to 2 per cent in the licence duties on light beer.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Victorian stuff they ought to give away.

—I know that Senator Puplick is a chauvinist in most respects. I thought that he was a little more civilised when it came to imbibing, but apparently the contrary is the case. The Liberal Minister of Consumer Affairs in Victoria, who after all is a tory and who as a result ought to have some creditibility with Senator Puplick, said that this was okay provided they were not selling below the minimum price. What an extraordinary comment that is upon the Liberal Party's commitment to free market forces and the discipline of the market-place.

SPEECH.PARA: The extent of Liberal governments' concern for the consumer could scarcely be better illustrated than by that comment, other than by the even better illustration constituted by the abolition of the Prices Justification Tribunal in the legislation before us tonight. The PJT, in a whole series of recent inquiries, has gathered evidence in a number of different industrial contexts, that firms are now basing prices on cost estimates which incorporate their expectations of future inflation levels. They are building expectations into the present pricing cycle. Firms are also using what is often their monopoly or oligopoly situation to finance, by their pricing, rapid expansion into overseas markets. These are the sorts of things which do not have any justification by reference to the kinds of criteria the PJT was applying, which will lead to increased inflation, and which are evidence, if more is needed, of the failure of free market competition. Profits are up and the consumers are being taken down.

I suspect that, however plausible, however persuasive, however rigorous, however conclusive the arguments that are being advanced by the Opposition on this occasion, they will just be greeted by the kind of giggles that are emanating at the moment from Government back bench senators, in particular from Senator Puplick. There is no disposition on the part of Government members and senators to take seriously the interests of Australian consumers. That fact could not be better demonstrated than by this legislation. Perhaps with my parting breath in this respect, with the last ounce of disgust that I can muster about the Government's attitude--

TALK.START.PARA: —You can always muster an extra ounce if you have to.

—I will be mustering some more disgust in relation to the Bills which are next to come before us, but in relation to the razor gang Bill the only remaining kind of disgust that I feel able to muster at the moment can perhaps best be articulated in terms of putting some questions to Government senators. I will leave the questions to burn into their consciousness, but no doubt to be unanswered unless Senator Baume's footwork is much more dexterous than that of other front benchers has been. In the first place, why is it that just as the PJT is about to conduct an inquiry into the aluminium industry-an inquiry which even the more vocal dullards opposite will realise is likely to provide findings which are extremely damaging to those who adopt an unthinking free market fetish-the PJT is to be abolished? Secondly, if the Minister and the Government believe that the PJT is ineffective, why was it not given greater resources? In particular, since 1979 why has the Minister not used his power more effectively under the amended Act-he has had the power to do it-to direct the PJT into areas of real concern to the community at large?

SPEECH.PARA: Thirdly, how can the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) say with one breath that he opposes sweetheart deals in the 35-hour-week campaign and, at the same time, support a measure which would abolish the one existing appropriate body for clamping down on such arrangements by having the capacity not to authorise any consequent price increases which will follow from them? If he is serious about having a mechanism for dealing with that, why does he not retain the body which enables that bit of huff and puff to be given flesh and blood? Finally, if the Government recognises the value of an institution such as the Prices Justification Tribunal in scrutinising, in particular, industries such as the petroleum industry-it does recognise that, as is demonstrated by the proposed passage in the next few minutes of the Petroleum Products Pricing Bill, which reincarnates the Prices Justification Tribunal in the context of that industry-and it is prepared to acknowledge the legitimacy of the Prices Justification Tribunal principles operating in that industrial context, why is it not willing to acknowledge it in other industrial contexts which are, equally, obviously deserving of this kind of intention? Once again, this part of the Bill demonstrates, just as everything else in the Bill does, that this is a government which has substituted a passion for ideology for any kind of common sense or detailed sensitive attention to what is in the interests of ordinary Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is considering that part of the Bill which seeks to abolish the Prices Justification Tribunal. Senator Evans has put strongly the case of the Opposition. There is a philosophical difference between the two sides of the chamber on this matter. The abolition of the Prices Justification Tribunal is consistent with this Government's continuing process towards the removal of what it considers to be unnecessary regulation. I noticed that in the ministerial statement on the report of the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee this was adverted to directly. I will read a little of it. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Over the years there has evolved a great deal of legislation which involves regulation of industry. Although some of this legislation benefits the community as a whole, and some of it has been put in place at the request of the private sector, it nonetheless imposes substantial costs on the taxpayer and the consumer and particularly on individual business enterprise.
Many of us will know that individual businesses resent some of the ways in which they are involved in these regulatory activities. The statement continued:
It is evident that much of government regulation of private sector activity is neither necessary nor effective and is certainly more costly than is self-regulation.
Of the Price Justification Tribunal itself the statement read:
This body has outlived its usefulness as a regulatory mechanism and is placing an undue burden on industry; there is no evidence that it is having any signficant impact on the restraint of inflation.
As Senator Evans has already pointed out it stated:
An appropriate mechanism will be established for the maintenance of the Government's petroleum product pricing policy.

It is our belief that the PJT is no longer performing an essential function. The 1979 amendments to the PJT significantly reduced the regulatory burden imposed on the business sector by it. The experience of the two years since those changes has indicated that the market is capable of ensuring competitive pricing. This experience has led us to the conclusion that the effect on price regulation has not been adverse. We have noted particularly that during the last two years there has been a general recovery within the economy. In fact, over the past two or three years the PJT has concentrated its activities mainly in the area of petroleum product prices. It is because of this emphasis on its activities that the Government has decided that it should continue to do this with the proposed Petroleum Products Pricing Authority to which reference has already been made.

I will touch briefly on the aluminium industry as it was referred to by Senator Evans. The main matter which has been before the PJT concerns pre-inquiry consultations with the aluminium industry. The PJT had not made any recommendations that there should be a public inquiry. Had such a recommendion been made the Government would have determined whether it wished to go ahead with such an inquiry and, if it did, how it would go ahead. But no situation arose where the PJT made such a recommendation. I remind honourable senators that the State Governments have constitutional powers over prices. They have powers to examine the prices of particular goods, for example, the price of beer, as they think necessary. What we have here is a philosophical belief by this Government that we are moving in the right direction. We acknowledge that our political opponents have a different view. We put it no stronger than that. We are trying to put some of our philosophies into effect with these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —With all respect to the Minister, I do not find his comments in reply to Senator Evans very explicit. He said twice that there was a philosophical difference between the Australian Labor Party and the Liberal Party over this matter. I suggest that he has not met the point that Senator Evans made and which I found very telling. Why abolish the Prices Justification Tribunal and then introduce a petroleum products pricing organisation? Surely if the philosophy applies to one commodity, why should it not apply to another? I ask the Minister whether he could clear up that point. Unless he can give us an answer to that specific point I suggest that his credibility is very much suspect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is reasonable to respond to the point that Senator Mason has made, I think, in a constructive manner. The fact is that petroleum product prices are of particular significance to energy policy in Australia. It is thought that special surveillance of these prices is therefore necessary. Prices of petroleum products are subject to external factors to a greater degree than are the prices of most other products in Australia. The honourable senator will be as aware as the rest of us as to why that is the case. The Petroleum Products Pricing Authority will maintain surveillance of petroleum products and of the industry with far fewer staff than the PJT presently requires. As I have said, it is a job which it has been doing for some time. A lot of its activities have already been concentrated in that area.

SPEECH.PARA: The regulatory function required to carry out that job will be minimal, and that will be consistent with the need for the PPPA to function effectively. It will be no more involved in the industry than is the PJT and in some areas it will be less involved. I acknowledge that one could have gone down a different road and amended or adjusted the PJT to do this task. The Government has elected to take the other road, to abolish one body and to create a special body to do the particular job in the way I have just described. It is simply a decision to go that way to achieve our end, rather than to go the way that Senator Mason feels is preferable. I think we have made the choice by facing the situation that we have.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it that the Minister is saying that it is perfectly all right to control prices in Australia if it suits and reinforces an area of Government policy, but for some reason it is not suitable to control prices in other ways. I would have thought that the whole question of price rises and the whole rationale of why things are the price that they are are of great interest and concern to most Australians. The Minister said earlier in his speech before last, that the PJT had not, in recent years, fulfilled the functions that it ought to have done. Is it then reasonable-I want to test this point because the whole question of prices is of great concern to the Australian public-to throw out the baby with the bath water? We do not necessarily throw away a motor car because it develops a fault. We do something about it. We repair and improve it. I would like the Minister's comments on why the Government has not taken that option? Could it not have looked at the PJT and said that this is an inadequate instrument and considered what it could do to improve it? I think this is a matter of deep concern to Australians and will increasingly become so in the next few years. If prices go on increasing people will want to know why. I think it is important to them to understand something which is of such basic concern to every household-why do things get more and more expensive? If indeed that has been investigated and a reason can be shown for it, that is great. I suggest that might have been a function of the PJT. But we as a parliament now say to the people: 'Right, there will be price increases and apart from petroleum price increases we will not give you any real indication of why it is happening. Our only reason for getting rid of the organisation was that we thought it was not doing the job properly'. I would like the Minister's comments on that whole area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not repeat the arguments which I have already put as I do not think it would help the Committee. I simply point out that there would be some validity in the question of just throwing out the baby with the bath water if we were to do that ab initio. I remind the Committee again that in 1979 the Government made a decision to alter the Prices Justification Tribunal in various ways in an attempt to do as Senator Mason has suggested, namely, to alter the structure and function of it and see what happened. The Government has concluded now that it is appropriate to abolish the PJT. Again, it is a matter of philosophy and judgment.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the clauses be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to inform honourable senators of the result of the ballot which was conducted yesterday on three options which were proposed as possible sitting hours of the Senate. Sixty-two honourable senators participated in the ballot. Of the votes cast, 37 were recorded for option No. 1, six were recorded for option No. 2 and 17 were recorded for option No. 3. There were two informal votes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On behalf of a large number of honourable senators, I pay tribute to you, Mr President, for the leadership you have shown on the matter of sitting hours. To my knowledge the subject of sitting hours has been under discussion by senators and members of the House of Representatives for two years in any sort of active way, but particularly this session. If I may very briefly state what some honourable senators but not all would know, at the beginning of this session I was approached by the then Government Whip, former Senator John Knight, who indicated to me that there was a wish abroad amongst Government and Opposition senators to have a change in the sitting hours. He asked me whether I would revive a proposal that I had put forward some time earlier. I said I would do so only if there was an assurance of strong support and a will to make it work. He assured me that conversations with Government and Opposition senators during my absence overseas indicated that that was so. That was on the Thursday night before John Knight died. One of the motivating factors for my proceeding, after a great amount of discussion I had with Opposition and Government senators, was the fact that John Knight had asked me to do it. We had reached a stage through many meetings and a great deal of work where it was necessary for somebody else to take the helm.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, I am enormously grateful that you and Mr Speaker agreed to undertake that task for the welfare of all senators and members. It was an arduous, a difficult and thankless task. Tonight I would like to say to you: Thank you for your help.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I point out that I speak as an individual, that there is no party attitude on this matter, and that there was a free vote on it. Mr President, I share Senator Martin's words of thanks to you and to Mr Speaker. I point out that it is my understanding that in both houses of the Parliament something like 66 per cent or 67 per cent of members and senators have voted for this change in sitting hours. I hope that the Government and the powers that be take note of this expression of opinion and that we at least make some effort to make the sitting hours in this place more sensible and more rational to enable all of us to work more efficiently. I hope we can do this in a bipartisan way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I join with Senator Martin and Senator Grimes in thanking you, Mr President, and Mr Speaker for the thankless work that has been done on this question. I also join Senator Grimes in thanking Senator Martin for her work. I think members of parliament have expressed very clearly that they want a change of hours. They have expressed very clearly the direction that those change of hours should take. I would just like to take issue in a friendly way with something that Senator Grimes said. He said that he hoped that the Government would take notice of this poll.
—I am a realist. It won't work unless the Government takes notice.
—That is a sad comment. I sympathise with Senator Grimes.
—Be a realist.

—I say to those honourable senators on the Government side that it is not the Government that determines what hours the Parliament should sit, it should be the members of the Parliament. If there is any area where the Parliament should divorce itself from the Executive and say its own piece it should be in connection with the hours we sit. I heard another sad comment from my good friend, Senator McAuliffe, that I should be realistic. Is he saying that there are enough gutless people or liverless people in this place who will tremble and crumble when the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) says 'This will not work', or when he says: 'We cannot bring in this reform', and say: 'Yes, Prime Minister, we will not now push for a change in hours'? I would have thought it would have been the worst of all worlds when parliamentarians say to the Executive: 'You are the boss and should determine the hours we sit'. Is that what Senator McAuliffe is saying?
—No. The Government has the responsibility to maintain the House in both places. You know that as a former Minister.

—I have never accepted that point of view. It is tradition that we have accepted through the years: a tradition that has made us prisoners of the system. I put to Government members: Is it not the wish of the Executive, whether it be Labor or Liberal, at any time to adopt the role of the head prefect and say: 'You must be here at 8 o'clock. You must not be here at one minute past eight because you might miss a division. You cannot behave like a civilised human being while you are in Canberra. Here you must behave like a schoolboy and do as we say. You must react to the bells'? That is part of the whole syndrome of the Executive versus the Parliament. I would have thought that with this pressure being put on the Liberal back bench in particular by the Government in its Party room this morning-the news of the way in which the Prime Minister stood over the parliamentary party is being barked all around Canberra--
—I must have been at the wrong meeting.

—It would not be unusual if Senator Archer were. It would not be the first time in Senator Archer's life that he turned up at the wrong meeting and voted the wrong way. Many of us here, including Senator Martin, have battled for years to get some sanity into the hours in which this place sits. We are the laughing stock of the Press Gallery which says that no other bunch of individuals could more inefficiently use its time over a three-day week by spreading 22 hours in the way in which we now spread our hours.

SPEECH.PARA: I speak so strongly about this at the moment because I feel that because of the work you, Mr President, Mr Speaker, Senator Martin and other people have done, that this is the last chance. If we buckle under now we ought to think of what we are doing. We are committing ourselves in the future to this absurd sort of situation in which we sit these hours. I give notice and hope for the support of thinking honourable senators, so that no matter what the Executive demands or asks, at least we in the Senate, when we resume in August, might have the gumption to determine by vote our own sitting hours. We believe that these hours should suit the convenience of the Senate so that we can best serve the people of Australia by looking at legislation which comes here in the way in which we are supposed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I share the elation of those who have spoken in this brief matter this evening because most of us have considered that the hours in which Parliament operates have been rather onerous from the point of view both of front and back bench members of the Parliament. I think what is encouraging as the result of the straw poll that has been taken in both Houses of parliament is that the Parliament has expressed a view in a rather informal way, but nevertheless in an overwhelming way, and suggested that the hours of sitting should be changed. That is not because there will be fewer hours of sitting, because exactly the same number of hours are involved in the views that have been expressed by the House of Representatives as well as by the Senate, but because we will work in a fashion which will enable the other work of the Parliament to continue in perhaps a more congenial way. That is to say that the policy committees of the respective parties will now not be obliged to work through their meal times but rather will have an opportunity in a more peaceful and placid way to consider matters that are before the Parliament as well as to develop policies in respect of the parties to which they belong.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think that many members of the public would be aware of the long hours that members of Parliament put in, not only in their attendance in the Parliament but in the important committee work that goes on both by the Parliament and by parties. As was indicated in the poll that was taken, no less time will be spent within the Parliament but we will have a much more rational use of time and a much more civilised time to spend within the Parliament. It seems to me that that is a very positive advance. I share Senator Chipp's concern about whether the views, so overwhelmingly expressed by these polls, will be put into effect. We would not want to see ourselves out of kilter with the House of Representatives. Therefore, we expect that the Cabinet will take this vote and will work out a system by which the function of Parliament, so far as hours are concerned, will be altered.

There will be problems, Mr President-there is no doubt. It will be an experimental matter and it will require a great deal of co-operation by all honourable senators to have the proposals working effectively and smoothly. I am sure there is enough good will among senators at least-and probably among members of the House of Representatives-to ensure that any bumpy roads we may encounter here will be overcome given the goodwill of the Executive. If that is not forthcoming we might find ourselves in conflict. Of course, that would be very difficult for us. Obviously we would require the assistance of the Joint House Department and other sections of the Parliament if the Senate were to take a view that was not accepted in the House of Representatives following a party political decision by the Executive.

Mr President, I do not know what is the next step. I recognise that your term here is rather limited. I do not know whether your successor, Mr Speaker and the back bench members would be able to impose their will upon the Executive of the day. I have heard that point referred to from time to time by many senior Government members, some of whom have left this place. I recall Senator Magnus Cormack making that point before he retired. We have taken an important step forward. But it now behoves Government members to see that the next step of implementation is, in view of what Senator Chipp said, imposed upon the Executive. That is the point we are at. We have expressed our view. We have had the opportunity in two polls, firstly, to say whether we favoured a change-we overwhelmingly said that we did-and, secondly, vote on certain options. Surely that is enough indication to the Government that the Parliament itself, as distinct from the Government and Opposition, has been able to express itself in a way that the Government should take into consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a statement and a personal explanation. My personal explanation is that possibly one of the two informal votes cast was mine. The returning officer will have noted that I wrote some remarks on my ballot paper. I briefly stated on the ballot paper that I believed that this exercise ought to have been undertaken after a debate on this matter in the chamber and after a committee was established to examine all of the alternatives because I considered that another alternative could have been put forward. This in no way is meant to denigrate the work that has been done by those who are concerned, as I am, about late night sittings. It is certainly no reflection on you, Mr President. It should be regarded, as has been stated, as a straw vote. The result of the vote is not overwhelming. I was reminded by Senator McAuliffe that one of the most worthy of our departing senators voted in favour of the first proposition. If all of the departing senators voted in favour of the first proposition and all of the incoming senators vote in favour of the third proposition the result would be that the third proposition would get up by 29 votes to 25. It seems rather extraordinary--
—The only thing is the outgoing senators have had more experience of the workings of the Senate than the incoming senators.
—But those senators who cannot get on committees are not going to be subjected to spending their nights on the loose in Canberra with nothing better to do.
—Have you any suggestions on that?
—As I see it, the only merit in the first proposition is to enhance the night life of Canberra.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite seriously, Mr President, I believe that, if you had remained after 30 June 1981, you would have insisted upon a debate in this Parliament on this matter. You would have ensured that the attitudes of the incoming senators were given due consideration and, as a result, possibly a committee would have been established to see whether some consensus could be formulated.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make my position clear. I did not cast a vote in either of the ballots conducted, nor did I return a ballot paper. The ballot paper that I received yesterday was torn up and put in the rubbish bin. I adopted Senator Haradine's view that it was unfair for me as a retiring senator to be deciding the hours for future members of the Senate. I thought on principle that I would not cast a vote.
—Most of the departing senators cast votes.
—I did not. I am surprised at the very big returns which were received from only 64 senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I would not want to go home tonight leaving honourable senators here filled with anxiety as to who was the other person who would be classed as voting informal. This would probably be the only occasion on which Senator Harradine and I would be in the same situation. I, too, did not vote for any of the three propositions because I did not agree with any of them. I wrote on my ballot paper that, if the present Standing Orders were adhered to, this Parliament could work satisfactorily. If the Government were not allowed under the Standing Orders to introduce any new business after 10.30 p.m. on Tuesdays, 11 p.m. on Wednesdays, or 10.30 p.m. on Thursdays, the Parliament would work all right. But, irrespective of which one of these propositions is agreed to, if the Government agrees to the first proposition, that will not prevent the Government of the day doing what it does here now, that is, sitting until 3 or 4 a.m. The Government has the numbers to suspend Standing Orders. My concern is that there was no vote given to the people working in the kitchen as to how they would be affected. All we are concerned about here is members of parliament. I have always expressed concern about the people who work in this place.
—They were consulted.
—They were not consulted. There were no ballot papers distributed amongst those people to allow them to have a vote.
—The Joint House Committee saw them.

—The Joint House Committee did not consult every person who works in the kitchen. If this Parliament is to sit here until 7 o'clock as proposed in the first proposition, in many instances the dining room staff will be expected to stay until 10 o'clock to provide meals. The transport officers will have to stay until they get the last person away from this Parliament. They are the people we ought to be concerned about. No doubt this matter will come to a vote when the proposition is put on our return for the Budget session. I hope that, in the meantime, all the people who service this Parliament-apart from politicians-are consulted by way of secret ballot as parliamentarians have been consulted. Let us see how they will be affected.

SPEECH.PARA: I need say no more tonight. Now nobody need go home trying to mull over in his or her mind who were those two nitwits who voted informal, because we know now that they were Senator Harradine and myself. We did not do it because we do not have any common sense. We did not cast an informal vote blindly. We did it because we are not satisfied in respect of the three propositions which were put to us that we could vote for any one of them and come up with a logical result.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill returned from the House of Representatives without amendment.
Message received from the House of Representatives intimating that it had agreed to the amendments made by the Senate to this Bill.
Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Messner) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to amendments to the Christmas Island Agreement concerning essentially the mining function on Christmas Island and future arrangements for stockpiles of phosphate rock. The amendments have been agreed to by the Australian and New Zealand governments.

Honourable senators will recall that on 5 March 1981 my colleague, the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Kevin Newman, announced in the House a number of wide-ranging decisions concerning the future of phosphate mining on Christmas Island, and the purchasing and distribution of phosphate rock for Australia's requirements.

One of those decisions was that as far as mining on Christmas Island is concerned the British Phosphate Commissioners would be replaced on the Island as managing agents for the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission by an Australian Government owned and controlled company. This is to be an initial step pending the winding up of the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission. Article 1 of the Schedule to the Bill enables these arrangements to be made by removing the requirement on the CIPC to employ the BPC as managing agents, and permitting the CIPC to engage such managing agents as are jointly nominated by the two Governments. The intention is that as from 1 July 1981 or as soon as practicable thereafter the new company-the Christmas Island Phosphate Co. will be nominated as managing agents. A further decision given effect to by the Bill-Article 2 of the Schedule-is to enable the CIPC to transfer its stockpiles at manufacturers' plants in Australia and New Zealand to the respective governments.

Finally, paragraph 2 of Article 1 of the Schedule reflects impending changes in purchasing and distribution arrangements for phosphate by removing the requirement on the CIPC to dispose of Christmas Island phosphate in conjunction with phosphate supplied from other sources by the British Phosphate Commissioners.
As Mr Newman indicated in his statement on 5 March, this responsibility will pass on 1 July from the BPC to the Australian Phosphate Corporation.
I emphasise that these amendments are of an interim kind. A completely new Christmas Island Agreement is to be negotiated with New Zealand.

I take this opportunity to inform honourable senators of developments which have occurred since my colleague's statement of 5 March. Action has been put in train to establish the Christmas Island Phosphate Co. which will assume responsibility for mining on Christmas Island. Coopers and Lybrand has been retained to advise on the establishment of the company generally, and the question of responsibility for the provision of municipal and similar type functions on the island. The company will operate in a commercial way.

The Australian Phosphate Corporation has been incorporated and is moving to assume responsibility for the purchasing and distribution of Australia's phosphate requirements generally. I understand that following discussions with a number of shipping organisations, the superphosphate manufacturers are entering into an agreement with the Australian National Line to take over the three Australian-crewed ships currently under long-term charter to the BPC.

In response to my colleague's statement on 5 March, the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) sought information on the stockpiles, in particular their value and the way they are financed. As at 31 March 1981, the stockpiles in Australia amounted to almost 1.2 million tonnes. Their market value at that date was nearly $79m. The stockpiles have been built up for two reasons: To ensure availability when production or delivery was disrupted, and to continue to achieve economies of scale in production when demand slackened. They have been financed over many years by way of surcharges placed on the price of rock to manufacturers, and in recent years, when prices of rock from various sources have been rising relatively quickly, by differences between the buying price and selling price. Rock is sold to manufacturers at current market price rather than historic cost. The honourable member also displayed a breadth of knowledge about the booby bird. The Government still has under consideration the appraisal of the bird made by Professors Ovington and Cullen and Dr Nelson. In the meantime the current moratorium on particular mining areas of the island inhabited by the bird has been extended.

I should not let this occasion pass, Mr President, without paying tribute to the Commissioners and staff of the British Phosphate Commissioners, as one effect of this legislation will be to remove that name from what might be called Australian phosphate legislation. The BPC was established by the Nauru Island Agreement of 2 July 1919, the Agreement being signed for Australia by the Right Honourable William Morris Hughes, for New Zealand by the Right Honourable William Ferguson Massey-both signing in the presence of R. R. Garran-and for the United Kingdom by the Right Honourable David Lloyd George, each of these Right Honourable Gentlemen being at the time his country's Prime Minister. Few bodies have started life with such distinguished godfathers.

The BPC's original charter was to extract phosphate from Nauru and dispose of it in the three countries. As time went by, it also became responsible for extracting phosphate from Ocean Island, Banaba, and Christmas Island, and for purchasing and shipping to Australia and New Zealand all the phosphate and sulphur requirements for manufacturers in both countries. That it has discharged these responsibilities most efficiently is indicated by the fact that Australia has in the past 60 years never been without phosphate rock. I pay tribute on behalf of the Government to the BPC staff who have achieved that record, and to the Commissioners, particularly the current Commissioner Mr Maurice Timbs. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Debate (on motion by Senator Gietzelt) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Messner) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to the Government's decision to pay a bounty on the printing in Australia of certain lightweight woven fabrics weighing less than 120 grams per square metre. The decision to adopt this form of assistance follows the Government's consideration of the recommendation by the Industries Assistance Commission contained in its report No. 240 of 30 April 1980 entitled 'Textiles, Clothing and Footwear'. This bounty proposal is part of the Government's broader program for the textiles, clothing and footwear industries intended to encourage the development of a more efficient industry structure. It is expected also to provide substantial benefits to user industries such as clothing manpfacturers. To this end, the proposal is in agreement with the broad objectives of the Industries Assistance Commission's recommendation.

The Bill provides for the bountry to be payable at the rate of 70 per cent of the additional value added to the fabric by the printer. The value added will be based on the factory cost of bountiable printed fabric less the costs of materials used in the printing process. The scheme is to operate for a period of seven years from 1 January 1982 and bounty payments for the first full year are estimated to be $2.5m.

The bounty assistance is designed to offset the effect on printers of another Government decision to grant import entry of certain fabrics at minimum rates of duty and free of quota-that is, those printed fabrics weighing less than 120 grams per square metre, and destined for garment use. Bounty is to be payable on fabrics printed at registered premises during the bounty period, if the fabric is used or is sold for use in making up into garments in a registered clothing factory. Clothing factories will be treated as being registered for the purposes of the bounty scheme is registered under a State law or, in the case of internal Territories which do not have laws suitable for these purposes, such places used for the production of garments and approved by the Comptroller-General of Customs.

This approach is consistent with exclusions from the proposed tariff concessions on certain lightweight woven fabrics which I mentioned earlier. The exclusions will protect the interests of manufacturers of other lightweight cloth, such as pocketings, linings and curtains. At the same time the Bill makes provision for an extension by regulation of the uses to which bountiable fabric may be put, if the Government decides that such an extension is desirable. The Government expects that the assistance proposed by this Bill will enable the local industry to compete adequately against printed fabrics of a similar nature which will be able to be imported at minimum rates of duty and free of quota after 1 January 1982. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Evans) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX (ASSESSMENT AND RATES) AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 June, on motion by Senator Carrick:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I understood that it was proposed to debate cognately the Petroleum Products Pricing Bill and the Australian Capital Territory Gaming and Liquor Authority Bill. The only thing that these rather strange bedfellows have in common is that they both represent razor gang policy. Nonetheless, that is the proposal.
—Is a cognate debate agreed upon? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

—The Petroleum Products Pricing Bill establishes a Petroleum Products Pricing Authority to monitor, as the name suggests, petroleum products pricing. Although we certainly believe that petroleum product prices should be monitored and for that reason do not oppose the basic concept of having this kind of regulatory agency; nonetheless, we are unhappy with a number of features of the way in which the Bill is put together and the circumstances in which it comes before the Parliament. The Bill contains a number of structural weaknesses to the extent, as we will make clear at the Committee stage, that it provides the Authority with virtually no independence from the Minister, with low status and with limited powers and resources.

SPEECH.PARA: The more general objection we have to the Bill is the one which I think was adequately canvassed and foreshadowed in the debate we had earlier this evening on the Prices Justification Tribunal, and that is that the very bringing forward of the legislation to establish a separate price monitoring authority for the petroleum industry illustrates beautifully the stupidity of the rationale for the abolition of the existing Prices Justification Tribunal. If we are on about deregulation, market forces and all the other spects of the private enterprise razor gang ideology that have permeated this Government's approach to this and associated legislation, why is the Government singling out petroleum products now for special attention? Why is this particular area of oligopolistic economic organisational activity being singled out for special regulatory activity? Why not let the free market forces do their best or their worst in this area as the Government seems to want to happen everywhere else?

Early this evening the Minister indicated, in answer to this sort of point made in the context of the Prices Justification Tribunal debate, that there was a need for special consideration to be given and special legislative attention paid to the petroleum pricing policy because it was intimately linked with the Government's energy policy which was of manifest interest and concern to the nation at large. Now that this is going to be a recurring theme in this relatively short debate on the Petroleum Products Pricing Bill I simply ask the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) about the public interest, in the nation and the community, not just in energy policy but in anti-inflationary policy. What about the role that the Prices Justification Tribunal was playing, or potentially had the capacity to play, in that particular across the board area of macro-economic policy? The Government cannot just single out and pretend that energy policy by itself is something separate and distinct from, or at least more important than, economic policy and in particular that part of the Government's economic policy which is supposedly directed to the control of inflation. They are all indispensable elements in any rational, effective and constructive economic policy and they all have their own justification.

What we have got with this legislation, which is re-creating the Prices Justification Tribunal for the petroleum industry alone-it is reincarnating the PJT in a new and limited guise-is simply a lame attempt to placate public concern about petroleum prices and, of course, concern among that very special interest group that this Government has been so anxious to nurture, the service station proprietors, with respect to the pricing practices of the major oil companies. There is not a shred of any principle which can be described as one of intelligible economic justification for what is being done.

The hypocrisy of this Government is something we have come to expect but not to love any more through its constant repetition. Once again it nauseously makes itself apparent in this particular context. In the establishment of this Authority we have a clear acknowledgment of the validity of the prices justification concept. What we have in the context of the petroleum industry is an industry which is heavily concentrated-even more so of course following the recent takeover of Golden Fleece by the Caltex company-and which is given, as we all know, to co-operative price setting through refinery exchange agreements and substantial integration of the different company operations and so on. We have an industry which is multinational and trans-national in a majority of cases. The multinational firms have something like 83 per cent of the Australian market. The industry is vertically integrated thus enabling, through transfer pricing, companies to make profits at any particular point on the scale--production, refining, wholesaling and retailing-that happens to suit their interest. For example in 1974 the PJT responded to that kind of situation by adjusting the proposed increase by the Shell company to take into account the doubts it had as to the reasonableness of the price charged by that company's overseas affiliates. It took very much into account the transfer pricing phenomenon and the necessity to compensate for it.

If we look at the way in which petroleum price setting has operated generally in Australia we find that in April 1976 the Collins Royal Commission on Petroleum reported, amongst other things, that motor spirit and petroleum products were over-priced and that both wholesale and retail margins were excessively high. We find that it reported that unfair competition and especially discriminatory pricing practices were rife. Yet we had a situation of the big oil companies going to their merry way. In 1979 they made profits of some $300m after tax. The increase in profits from 1978 ranged from 59 per cent in the case of British Petroleum right up to 194 per cent in the case of Mobil.

In that situation we had a Prices Justification Tribunal as it then existed making significant efforts to improve, remedy and redress that situation. We had a potentially very effective ongoing operation as was demonstrated as recently as 1 April this year when, in the report released by the PJT, we saw it allowing only a 0.25c per litre increase in motor spirit prices as contrasted with the increases that were actually sought by the oil companies which ranged from 0.9c to 3.25c per litre. We had a situation of the PJT removing an amount from the list price of motor spirit which was providing a return on investment in retail outlets. It said it had reviewed in the process the whole basis of petroleum prices and, as a maximum justified wholesale price, allowed 0.35c per litre less than would have been the case if the review of the basis for the prices had not been undertaken.

So as recently as April this year the PJT demonstrated itself to be a very effective regulatory organisation with respect to an industry which manifestly cries out in the public interest for that kind of control. So it cannot be said that this legislation was necessary to fill any regulatory vacuum that needed to be filled in the public interest. We had the PJT. As we have debated earlier tonight, the justification for its abolition simply does not add up.

That is the general context in which this Bill is being debated. That is the general combination of reasons why the Opposition takes the attitude it does towards it. In addition to those general reasons, as I foreshadowed at the outset, it is our view also that the Bill contains a number of specific individual defects in terms of its internal operation to the extent that it provides grossly excessive ministerial discretions. The way it is set up, the Minister may direct the Commissioner on how he is to conduct an inquiry and what he is to take into account. Again, the way it is set up, the Minister may appoint anyone to conduct inquiries with no requirement that such persons have no conflicting pecuniary interest. For example, there is no inhibition in the Bill as it is presently drawn on appointing even the head of the Shell company in Australia for that task. The discretions in the Bill are created in such a way that the Minister may refuse to allow the Authority to conduct an inquiry without his giving reasons for such refusal. As this legislation is set up, the Minister decides what is to be done, how it is to be done and who will do it. We suggest that the public can have little faith that political pressure in this respect will not be applied.

I have endeavoured to describe as briefly as possible, given the time constraints which we are all under, the basics of the Opposition's attitude on this matter. In essence I suppose our point can be summarised as follows: We oppose the abolition of the PJT because of the implications of that not only for the petroleum industry but also for pricing policy and industry generally. In the specific context of the petroleum industry we support the findings of the Collins Royal Commission on the need for an agency to deal with all aspects of distribution, marketing and pricing. The amendment to the motion for the second reading of this Bill makes those concerns of the Opposition clear. Accordingly, I move:
Leave out all words after 'That', insert 'The Senate is of the opinion that-

(a) the Bill should be withdrawn and redrafted to extend the role of the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority to that of an independent regulatory agency for the petroleum and petroleum products industries as recommended by the 4th Report of the Royal Commission on Petroleum (the Collins Report), with functions to include:
(i) restructuring, monitoring and regulating the pricing system,
(ii) the rationalisation, where necessary, of retail outlets,
(iii) the regulation of dealer-company relationships, and
(iv) the development of a conservation program; and

(b) The Government should be condemned for its decision to abolish the Prices Justification Tribunal which was carrying out the functions of the proposed Petroleum Products Pricing Authority and calls upon it to retain a reformed Tribunal for such purposes as the provision of effective powers to monitor and inquire into the justification of prices in all oil products and other goods exempted by this Bill'.

I turn now even more briefly to the other Bill in this odd package of Bills which we are debating cognately-the Australian Capital Territory Gaming and Liquor Authority Bill. The situation is that we have a Bill which is designed to amalgamate three existing Australian Capital Territory statutory authorities-the Australian Capital Territory Totalisator Agency Board, the Liquor Licensing Board and the Poker Machine Licensing Board of the Capital Territory. By that means it is claimed to rationalise the number of statutory authorities in the Territory, to bring together a range of like and interrelated functions, leading to a more effective and efficient co-ordination of gambling and liquor controls. It is claimed that administrative efficiencies will flow from this amalgamation. That is not a claim the Opposition is disposed to contest in any way. It seems reasonable; it seems plausible.

As far as that goes, we have no opposition whatsoever to the concept of this Bill. It seems to be one of the more legitimate ways in which perhaps a public administration conscious government could wield a razor. However, we are concerned with the fact that the Bill stops there. In our second reading amendment that we proposed to this Bill, it is made clear that we regard the Bill as deficient to the extent that it makes no explicit provision for the way in which the profits raised by these organisations, now to become a single organisation, will be distributed in the larger interests of the Australian Capital Territory community. It is the case at the moment that about $2m a year is being allocated within the Australian Capital Territory as a result of the activities of these gambling and other organisations. In our view, it is important that those funds be allocated in accordance with the wishes of the Australian Capital Territory people. Accordingly, we will be moving a second reading amendment to the Australian Capital Territory Gaming and Liquor Authority Bill. Because of the detailed drafting necessary to accomplish our purpose and because of the shortage of legislative draftsmen the amendment could not be completed in time for this evening's debate. However, it will read:

Leave out all words after 'that', insert 'the Bill be withdrawn and re-drafted to provide that the dispersal of funds raised by the Authority, other than those committed to the racing industry, will be in accordance with determinations of the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly but limited to purposes associated with sport, recreation, culture, welfare and community related activities in the Australian Capital Territory.''.

I have given the reason the Opposition takes the attitude it does toward these Bills. Although we feel quite strongly, particularly about the Petroleum Products Pricing Bill, because of time constraints we will not seek a division on this legislation at the second reading stage because we have some further points to make at the Committee stage. It might be desirable to conclude this matter before the Senate's scheduled rising time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Government will not accept either amendment to these Bills at the second reading stage. The amendment put forward by Senator Evans to the Petroleum Products Pricing Bill 1981 is against the general thrust of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, an object of which was to reduce the unnecessary regulation in business. Clearly what the Prices Justification Tribunal has done in the past-I speak of the time before the 1979 amendments-has been aimed clearly towards a very high level of regulating activity. Since then we have seen its role changed to that of a price surveillance body. In that sense it will be seeking certainly to maintain an overview of the Australian economy, making sure that it has that power to perceive price changes which are beyond the norm and to report thereon. Of course, this will be now defined in terms of the petroleum industry. This is something which I believe the community has learned to accept-indeed to demand-in today's climate of possible shortages and dislocations in the supply of petroleum products.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to other matters concerning dealerships and the retailing of petroleum products, the Government legislated last year in respect of this matter. We now know that that legislation has been accepted in the general community. The amendment also speaks of the development of a conservation program. It should be clear that an important aim of the Government's crude oil pricing policy is the conservation of scarce liquid fuel resources. The Government recognises the significance of petroleum products prices to the economy and its energy policy, and is therefore retaining surveillance of these prices through the new authority which is to be established in place of the activities of the former Prices Justification Tribunal. For those reasons the Government rejects the amendments.

I just mention in respect of Senator Evans's proposed amendment to the Australian Capital Territory Gaming and Liquor Authority Bill that he seeks to put the actual decision-making process in relation to the funds that may accumulate as a result of the activities of the Authority into the hands of the House of Assembly. Clearly, that is beyond its generally accepted powers in the community which are, of course, advisory only at this stage of the game. The Government rejects that proposed amendment.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 2, clause 3, lines 33 to 35, leave out paragraph (c) of the definition of 'petroleum product'.
(2) Page 3, clause 4, sub-clause (1), line 4, after 'company', insert 'or by a trading entity in which a company has a beneficial financial interest'.
(3) Page 6, clause 12, sub-clause (2), lines 9 and 10, leave out 'being an interest that could conflict with the proper performance of his functions in relation to that inquiry,'.

(4) Page 6 clause 12, sub-clause (3), lines 14 and 15, leave out 'unless his interest is disclosed in any report in which he participates', insert 'being an interest that could conflict with the proper performance of his functions in relation to this Act'.
(5) Page 8, clause 16, sub-clause (3), line 12, leave out ', With the approval of the Minister,'.
(6) Page 8, clause 16, sub-clause (5), lines 17 to 21, leave out the sub-clause, insert the following sub-clauses:

'(5) In the performance of its functions, the Authority shall have regard not only to the need for the company or companies concerned to achieve a level of profitability that is sufficient to enable the company or companies to maintain an adequate level of investment and employment but also to the desire of the Government of the Commonwealth, in pursuing the general objectives of national economic and social policy, to implement an equitable anti-inflation policy and, in particular, the desire of the Government of the Commonwealth to subject prices to public scrutiny so as to ensure-

(a) that companies are in a position of public accountability which parallels that of unions' requirements to justify their members' wage levels before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission; and

(b) that unreasonably high profits are not being made at the expense of the consumers and that unnecessarily high costs, either as the result of inefficiency or other unjustified reasons, are not being passed into prices.
(6) In sub-section (5)-
''unnecessarily high costs'' includes such items as costs arising from-
(a) excessive transfer prices between related companies;
(b) excessive royalty payments and the like to overseas parent companies;
(c) exceptional wages and salary increases;
(d) unnecessarily high interest payments and rents;
(e) unnecessary advertising and packaging expenses;
(f) inefficient operations, and;
(g) the refusal to make proper allowances for productivity improvements; and

''unreasonably high profits'' includes levels of profitability, resulting from the abuse of a strong market position, that are more than sufficient to enable the company or companies to maintain an adequate level of investment and employment.''.
(7) Page 14, clause 20, sub-clause (1), Line 19, leave out '$10,000', insert '$100,000'.

I shall speak very briefly to the amendments. The first amendment would remove the discretionary power of the Minister to exempt any product from the process of price scrutiny for the purposes of the Act. The second amendment would extend the scope of the Authority's power to include a trading entity in which a company has a beneficial financial interest. The purpose of the Bill, as we see it drafted at the moment, could be hindered by the use of non-corporate entities such as trusts or partnerships. They could be used to get around the operation of the Act. We see it as being desirable at this stage to block off that loophole. We also see it as being almost certainly within the Commonwealth's constitutional power to do so, to the extent that although corporations themselves are not directly being regulated by this kind of provision, parent corporations in effect are the ultimate beneficiaries of it. That would seem to attract the necessary power.

Amendments (3) and (4) are designed to provide the same direct or indirect pecuniary interest provisions as exist in the Prices Justification Act. We disagree with the way in which-again, without going into detail to try to explain it-the Government's provisions are drawn to the extent that they seem to allow both members of the proposed new Commission to have and to hold interests which are incompatible with the particular purposes that the Bill is designed to serve provided those interests are disclosed. They also go further than that, to the extent that they enable particular commissioners to participate very directly in the performance of particular functions in which there is a manifest conflict of interest, provided that is disclosed. I do not like either of those provisions.

Amendment (5) eliminates the requirement for a Minister to agree to an inquiry being conducted. Amendment (6), itself a very long amendment which I am now tempted to read into the record-I will not do so-provides guidelines to the Authority as to the definition of a justified price. Amendment (7) increases the penalty for increasing prices after notice has been served on a company from $10,000 to $100,000. That might sound a large amount but it is not when one considers that it has not been increased since 1973 and that the Trade Practices Act has equivalent penalties of $250,000.
Consideration interrupted.

INTERJECT.PARA: That I do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Messner) read a third time.
Motion (by Senator Messner) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I realise that the hour is late and that the Senate was sitting until the early hours of this morning; so I shall not keep it very long. Questions have been asked in this place about the Springbok tour of New Zealand and the effect that it will have on the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting and the Commonwealth Games. The Foreign Minister, the honourable Tony Street, said that he is very concerned about the tour. He has repeatedly expressed the Government's support for the efforts of the New Zealand Government to have this ill-timed and ill-considered tour called off.

SPEECH.PARA: The very crux of the situation is the autocratic attitude of the New Zealand Rugby Football Union Council to have the tour of New Zealand by South Africa continue in the face of international criticism. The Council, of course, defends its attitude by using the hackneyed and hypocritical phrase that politics has no place in sport. It refuses to cancel the Springbok tour. I ask honourable senators to recall the time when the Council exclued Maori players from the All Blacks touring side when requested to do so by the South African Government. I put it to you, Mr Deputy President, that the Council has double standards. How can it possibly draw any distinction? Did it regard blatant discrimination of this kind as a political act or a sporting act? I leave the question to honourable senators to decide and rightly condemn what I believe is an exercise in duplicity and deceit.

I sound a warning that if this tour proceeds it will result in violence and dissension in New Zealand and cause irreparable damage to New Zealand's already somewhat tarnished international reputation. It is a sad day when a sporting body can hold a nation to ransom. I condemn the Council for its stupidity and selfishness. Its high handed attitude will alienate African countries and force them to retaliate and strain, I believe, the very fabric of the Commonwealth severing ties which bind the nations which make up this powerful body.

As I said, this is not the first instance when the unity of the Commonwealth has been threatened by the singularly bloody-minded attitude of the Council to maintain its links with South Africa-the very home of apartheid. This determination to proceed against the weight of public opinion and the wishes of the New Zealand Government has resulted in the Gleneagles agreement. In a nutshell, the New Zealand Rugby Council does not, I believe, give a damn about the views of the Commonwealth. This is not surprising as it also rejects the views of the New Zealand Government and the majority of the many fair-minded New Zealanders. The Council also rejects the weight of public opinion as expressed by newspaper editorials and polls and rejects the views of municipal authorities, trade unions and church leaders alike.

I draw the attention of honourable senators to two important points that the Council has lost sight of in its determination to keep its eye on the ball; as a result it is completely offside in its dogmatic attitude. The first is that whether the Council's actions have political implications is not a matter it can control. I make that assertion in a world where playing sport against South Africa can be interpreted only as an act of comfort for and acceptance of a universally condemned system of government. Therefore the New Zealand Council cannot expect its Simon Pure interpretation of its actions to attract any reaction other than derision and anger. The other point that the Council has conveniently overlooked is that, in continuing to carry on with this tour against all criticism and the weight of public and international opinion, it is committing what can be seen only as a political act and not a mere sporting act. I cannot be convinced-I know that honourable senators will be likewise unconvinced-that for this pious body to persevere in the face of all political considerations raised is, and can be termed only, a political act. It is a political act and, to me, a dangerous political act, one which seeks to elevate sporting interests to an unparalleled and unreal position of importance above and beyond every other aspect of national policy. It is a selfish act and one which affects not only New Zealand but also all other nations within the fragile framework of the Commonwealth. The New Zealand Council, with its insular and self-serving attitude, demonstrates its complete and utter disregard for the very future of this great institution of the Commonwealth of Nations. The Council certainly is not its brother's keeper. I am also at a complete loss to understand and interpret the New Zealand Commonwealth Games Association's attitude to this ill-conceived tour. It appears to me to be adopting a rather ostrich-like attitude. This Pontius Pilate attitude is, thank heavens, in complete contrast to that of the New Zealand athletes union which recently passed a motion calling on the Council to withdraw its invitation to the South African rugby team. It is indeed heartening to see that there are still many nationally minded men in sporting administrations in our sister country who have their values and priorities clearly determined as to what constitutes acts of a sporting or political nature. I congratulate this body for its forthright stand on this issue.

I also point out that the President of the Australian Commonwealth Games Association, Mr Les Martyn, has recently made a statement about the possible-or should I more correctly say, the probable-effects of this tour on the future of the Commonwealth Games. Yet in spite of all this public and private weight of criticism, the President of the New Zealand Commonwealth Games Association remains silent. His silence alone, I believe, condemns him and can only be construed as a tacit approval of this tour.

In summary, I make the following points: Firstly, the New Zealand Rugby Union Football Council has made up its mind in what can only be described as a highly selfish, reckless and badly informed manner that the tour will proceed and is resolute in this determination; and, secondly, to his credit, the New Zealand Foreign Minister, Mr Talboys, has waged an almost single-handed campaign to stop the tour. I have raised these matters in the belief that our Foreign Minister, Mr Tony Street, was correct when he said that plain speaking is called for from time to time in relations between two nations, even between two nations as close as Australia and New Zealand. Mr Street has not pussyfooted around. He has laid the serious consequences directly on the line even at the risk of offending our sister nation.

I charge the New Zealand Rugby Union Football Council with utter selfishness, stupidity and a complete and utter disregard for the rights and interests of the majority. I also sound a warning that, if racial issues and sporting contacts feature prominently at the forthcoming Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting at the expense of other issues, that situation will be and can only be attributed to the Springbok tour of New Zealand, a tour by a nation whose apartheid policies are not acceptable to the world as a whole or to the Commonwealth in particular. I reject and openly condemn and deride the New Zealand Rugby Union Football Council. I trust that its administration will be able to live with the consequences of this exercise in what I can only term stupidity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Tonight, Senator Bonner has addressed himself to one of the great issues of the world. This matter lies very close to our own doorstep. It is a matter of the greatest consequences and certainly of the greatest concern to this Government in relation to its position with regard to the forthcoming Springbok tour of New Zealand. As Senator Bonner pointed out, certainly very considerable concern has been expressed by this Government to the Government of New Zealand in relation to this matter. I think that the statements made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) certainly clearly demonstrate this Government's position. Unfortunately, I was not aware that this matter was coming forward tonight. I was unable to alert the Minister representing the Minister of Foreign Affairs in this place to the import of Senator Bonner's remarks in greater detail. I undertake to convey the import of his remarks to her and to the Foreign Minister, Mr Street, and to ensure for him that his speech receives attention and a reply.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.13 p.m.
