QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 10 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the National Health and Medical Research Council studying a series of articles now appearing in New Scientist which suggest that the tranquiliser 'Diazepam' (Valium) promotes cancer of the breast and prostate gland.
(2) Is this apparent promotion related to an increase of the hormonal stimulator 'Prolactin'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. However the articles have been examined by officers of the Drug Evaluation Section and the Adverse Drug Reactions Section of the Department of Health.

(2) Insufficient data are available to the Department at this stage to enable an informed comment to be made. The Department is continually monitoring statements made relating to this matter and is seeking further data in an endeavour to clarify the position.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 7 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Did the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, on a recent visit to Britain give an assurance to Mr David Howell, Britain's Energy Secretary, that plans for establishing a uranium enrichment plant in Australia were going ahead; if so, (a) how far advanced are the plans; (b) where will the plant be constructed; (c) who will supply the finance to build the plant; and (d) to which countries will the enriched materials be sold.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that Mr Anthony did not give an assurance to Mr David Howell that plans for establishing a uranium enrichment plant in Australia were going ahead. In his discussions with Mr Howell, Mr Anthony informed him that the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia (UEGA, comprising BHP, CRS, WMC, Peko) was undertaking an assessment of the possibilities of establishing a commercial enrichment plant and that the Government hoped to receive a report from UEGA in the following month. That report has now been received and examined by the Government, and the Government has authorised UEGA to proceed with a full Feasibility Study. Aspects such as siting, financing and marketing are expected to be given consideration during the course of that Study.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 12 May 1981:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 13 May 1981.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) As a result of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, is the Education Research and Development Committee to be abolished.
(2) What were the functions of that institution.
(3) Was it performing its functions inadequately in any way and, if so, in what way was it inadequate.
(4) What action is proposed to take over the functions originally performed by the Education Research and Development Committee.
(5) As a result of the action, what Government services can be expected to be affected, and in what way will they be affected.

(6) As a result of the action will any information which was available in the past not be available; if so, what is the nature of that information, and in what ways has it proved useful when it was available.

(7) As a result of the Review will any informed advice or co-ordinating capacity which was available in the past not be available; if so, what is the nature of that informed advice or co-ordinating capacity, and in what ways has it proved useful when it was available.
(8) What is the estimated saving in abolishing the Education Research and Development Committee.
(9) What is the estimated short and long term cost of not having the services of the Education Research and Development Committee available to the Government and the community.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) The functions of the Education Research and Development Committee (ERDC) were:
(a) to advise on priorities in education research;

(b) to examine and to make recommendations to the Minister for Education for the financial support of research proposals, either submitted to it by or on behalf of individuals or groups, or proposed by the Committee;
(c) to advise the Minister for Education on any other means for the improvement of educational research, its development and the application of results in Australia;
(d) to be available for consultation on educational research matters;
(e) to foster the training of Australian education researchers.
(3) ERDC performed its functions in an entirely adequate manner. As a result of its work, both Commonwealth and State authorities have a sound basis on which to plan future research programs.

(4) and (5) National research into education will in future be decided as part of a Commonwelth annual review of overall research undertakings. While Commonwealth involvement in fostering and co-ordinating education research will be reduced, the States are expected to take a more active role in education research, determining their own priorities.

(6) and (7) Reports from ERDC provided information to educators and educational administrators which influenced, directly or indirectly, decisions being made about education in Australia. The ongoing Commonwealth commitment to educational research into issues of national significance, as a complement to the effects of the States, will ensure that relevant findings continue to be available to educators. Co-ordination of the educational research effort will continue, both through the Australian Education Council and through informal channels.

(8) ERDC operated on an annual budget, the level of which varied from year to year. Its budget for 1980-81 was $1.173m and this will be fully expended. Savings will ultimately be of this order, once commitments have been met. There will also be staff savings of the order of $207,630.

(9) ERDC made a valuable contribution to Australian educational research. Its programs and activities will influence Australian education for many years. Ongoing Commonwealth and State programs will in the short term complement the work already done. In the longer term, the Commonwealth will ensure that priority research continues, to enable sound educational decisions to be taken by Australian authorities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is Havelock House (Australian Capital Territory) to be sold to the private sector.
(2) What money is expected to be raised by this decision.
(3) Will the Government receive any advice as to when to sell Havelock House so as to achieve the best price.
(4) Will sale of Havelock House be delayed if it appears that the Commonwealth is not in a position to receive the best price, as is consistent with sound business practice.
(5) What investigations have been made concerning the prices which consumers will pay for the services of Havelock House as a result of its sale.
(6) Can the Minister assure the Parliament that prices will not rise, with consequent adverse affects on inflation as a result of the sale of Havelock House.
(7) What assurances can the Minister give that services to the public will not deteriorate as a result of the sale.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Havelock House is to be placed on the market.
(2) This cannot be estimated at this stage.

(3) and (4) In accordance with practice, the property will be valued by the Australian Taxation Office before being placed on the market, and a decision made as to sale in the light of any offers received.

(5), (6) and (7) Havelock House is at present primarily a guest house for public servants. If it is sold, it will be for the new owner to determine what services it will offer, the consumers of those services, and the prices to be charged.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 28 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What are the names of all private employment agencies engaged by the Department of Finance to recruit staff between December 1976 and November 1977.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: No private employment agencies were engaged by the Department of Finance to recruit staff between December 1976 and November 1977.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 31 March 1981 (Hansard, page 886) Senator Colston asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question, without notice, concerning the aerial spraying of the sugar crop in Queensland with herbicides.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

I am aware of the statement made by Sir Joseph McAvoy, Chairman of the Queensland Cane Growers Council, in which he asked the small number of cane growers applying agricultural chemicals from the air to change to ground application.

Although Sir Joseph's statement as reported in the Australian newspaper on 3 April 1981 made no specific reference to 2,4-D or 2,4,5-T, these chemicals are registered by the appropriate State authorities for weed control in cane fields.

In relation to the health risk to local residents and other consumers, it should be noted that these matters have been reviewed by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NH & MRC) and it is considered that there should be no hazard to human health provided the chemicals in question are used as directed and in accordance with good agricultural practice. The whole question of the use of phenoxyacetic acid herbicides such as 2,4-D and 2,4,5-T, is under continual review by the NH & MRC.

Aerial spraying of agricultural chemicals is also being considered as a special topic by a working party established by the NH & MRC to determine what additional precautions may be needed in relation to this method of application.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1280) Senator Robertson asked me a question, without notice, concerning superannuation arrangements for permanent part time employees in the Northern Territory Public Service. The following further information is provided on the matters raised by Senator Robertson:

ANSWER.PARA: By way of background, employees of the Northern Territory are not, of course, Commonwealth employees but, as a means of providing them with superannuation cover, the Northern Territory was prescribed as an 'approved authority' for the purposes of the Superannuation Act 1976.

The superannuation scheme provided under the Act was designed for Commonwealth employees and in particular for those in full time employment. Permanent part time employment is not a feature of Commonwealth sector employment at this stage.

It would be inappropriate for the Commonwealth Government to consider extending the Superannuation Act to part time employees of the Northern Territory before permanent part time employment has been introduced in the Commonwealth sector and before the Government has decided whether to extend superannuation cover to any part time Commonwealth employees. I am not in a position to indicate the timing of any Government consideration of superannuation for Commonwealth part time employees because this will depend, in the first instance, on decisions by Commonwealth employing authorities, such as the Public Service Board, regarding the introduction of permanent part time employment.

My Department has examined the arrangements made by the South Australian Government for providing its permanent part time public servants with superannuation cover. I am informed that they might be of some assistance if, in the event of the introduction of permanent part time employment in the Commonwealth sector, the Government were to consider providing superannuation cover for part time employees.

I have suggested to the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory that, in view of the priority the Northern Territory attaches to permanent part time employment, the Northern Territory Government may prefer to introduce its own separate superannuation arrangements for permanent part time employees in the Territory.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1381) Senator Wheeldon asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in the Senate. The question concerned press reports alleging recent immigrants from the United Kingdom are members of the National Front. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I have seen reports of a disturbance at the Perth Concert Hall on 22 April, during a performance by a British musical group, 'Madness', and noted that some of the press reports allege that youths known as 'skinheads' were involved in the disturbance; that many were members or supporters of the National Front organisation; and that some were recent immigrants from Britain.

I have no information which supports the contention that many of the youths who adopt the so called 'skinhead' mode of dress and behaviour are immigrants from Britain or are linked with the National Front. It is understood, however, that, as a result of the disturbance on 22 April, two youths were arrested. One was Australian born, and the other, a 14 year old boy, was born in Britain.

While applicants for entry to Australia are not normally asked whether they are associated with the National Front such association is likely to come to light as a result of overseas screening procedures and would be given appropriate weight in the decision to approve or refuse an application for entry to Australia.

The National Front organisation has been active in promoting racial intolerance in Britain and has support from a small minority in Australia. The objectives of the National Front are in opposition to the Government's aim of the development and community acceptance of the multicultural nature of Australian society and the preservation of social harmony and cohesion. Its activities are condemned by the Government and by all who believe in equal treatment for all members of the community.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 May 1981 (Hansard, page 2151) Senator Sibraa asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in the Senate. The question concerned Lebanese refugees. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is following events in the Lebanon with concern. We continue to be hopeful that a satisfactory solution will be found to the present tensions.

Australia responded generously to the tragic events that occurred in the Lebanon in 1976-77. 16,000 migrants arrived in that period, and there has been a continuing inflow since then. We have taken steps to provide most practicable facilities for visitor and migrant applicants since then through the Chancery in Beirut, the Immigration Office in Damascus and nearby posts. While the service necessarily cannot be ideal, it has been maintained with the greatest possible convenience to applicants in extremely difficult circumstances.

In referring to the Lebanese in Lebanon as refugees the question misinterprets the situation in Lebanon and the likely status of Lebanese presently displaced in that country. The United Nations Convention on the Status of Refugees requires that people seeking refugee status be outside their country and be unwilling or unable to return for fear of persecution. People displaced by civil strife and fighting are not necessarily refugees within the meaning of the Convention definition. It is also unlikely that those persons who have left Lebanon recently because of civil conflict could meet the Convention requirements for status.
